Direction: Choose the correct answer from the alternatives given:

Match column I with column II and select the correct option from the given codes.

Column I
(Scientists)

Column II
(Discoveries)

A.

Alec Jeffreys

(i)

Lac operon

B.

F. Sanger

(ii)

Annotated DNA sequences

C.

Jacob and Monod

(iii)

DNA fingerprinting

D.

Avery, MacLeod and McCarty

(iv)

Transforming principle

Alec Jeffreys is a British geneticist, who developed techniques for genetic fingerprinting and DNA profiling which are now used worldwide in forensic science to assist police detective work and to resolve paternity and immigration disputes. F. Sanger developed the Sanger dideoxy method of sequencing DNA and also is credited for the sequencing of fragments of automated DNA sequences called annotated DNA sequences. This was very helpful for the human genome project that could sequence the entire genetic makeup of the human being.  In 1961, Francois Jacob and Jacques Monod proposed the operon model of gene regulation in bacteria. The model was based on their study of the genes in E. coli that code for enzymes that affect the breakdown of lactose also called the Lac Operon. Avery, MacLeod and McCarty experimentally proved that DNA is the substance or the genetic material that causes transformation in bacteria. 

So, the correct option is 'A – (iii), B – (ii), C – (i), D – (iv)'.
A mass of dividing, undifferentiated cells in a tissue culture is called __________.

A mass of dividing, undifferentiated cells in a tissue culture is called 'A Callus'.

Plant callus is a growing mass of unorganized plant parenchyma cells. In living plants, callus cells are those cells that cover a plant wound. In biological research and biotechnology, callus formation is induced from plant tissue samples (explants) after surface sterilization and plating onto tissue culture medium in vitro. Plant callus is usually derived from somatic tissues. The tissues used to initiate callus formation depends on plant species and which tissues are available for explant culture. The cells that give rise to callus and somatic embryos usually undergo rapid division or are partially undifferentiated such as meristematic tissue. Specific auxin to cytokinin ratios in plant tissue culture medium give rise to an unorganized growing and dividing the mass of callus cells. Callus cultures are often broadly classified as being either compact or friable. Friable calluses fall apart easily and can be used to generate cell suspension cultures. Callus can directly undergo direct organogenesis and/or embryogenesis where the cells will form an entirely new plant.
Kohler and Milstein developed biotechnology for production of:

Monoclonal antibodies are monospecific antibodies that are made by identical immune cells that are all clones of a unique parent cell. In 1975, Georges Kohler and Cesar Milstein succeeded in making fusions of myeloma cell lines with B cells to produce hybridomas that made antibodies to known antigens. Monoclonal antibodies were first produced by applying the techniques of somatic cell genetics to antibody-producing cells. The cells that produce antibodies (B cells) are short-lived in culture. Thus, attempts to maintain B cells in culture and harvest antibody specificities failed for many years until Cesar Milstein and George Koehler succeeded in immortalizing B cells via somatic cell hybridization.
The __________ enzyme is used to cut DNA at specific point.

Restriction endonucleases are enzymes which scan the DNA molecule for a particular nucleotide sequence. These are called recognition sequences. Once the endonuclease finds this sequence it halts and cuts the strand.

"co" in EcoRI stands for 'coli'.

EcoRI is a restriction enzyme. Restriction enzymes or restriction endonucleases are endonucleases that have the ability to cut at a specific site within DNA. Restriction enzymes were first isolated in 1963 as an enzyme that restricted growth of bacteriophage in E. coli. These enzymes are named in a specific manner.

For example, the name 'EcoRI' has been given on the basis of the following:

  • The first letter "E" comes from the initial of the genus from which it is isolated i.e., Escherichia.
  • The second two letters "co" refers to the species from which it is isolated i.e., Escherichia coli.
  • The letter "R" is derived from the strain of bacteria from which it is isolated i.e., RY13.
  • The last roman numeral "I" denotes the order in which the enzymes were isolated from that strain.
Which one of the following is true to cDNA?
It is the imaginary form of DNA
By using reverse transcriptase enzyme cDNA can be converted into DNA
By using mRNA, cDNA can be synthesized

cDNA or the complementary DNA is called so because it is synthesized by using mRNA as the template. This process is called reverse transcription and it is mediated by the enzyme reverse transcriptase. cDNA can be made double-stranded by following the normal process of DNA replication. cDNA is preferably synthesized during the biotechnological processes as it contains only the coding sequences. So, it can be directly inserted in the host cell without any worries of introns.

So, the correct answer is 'By using mRNA, cDNA can be synthesized'

Consider the following statements regarding plant biotechnology:

1. Plant biotechnology can reduce a number of undesirable food components, such as one of the major allergenic proteins in rice or the major allergens in peanut or soybeans.

2. Components such as caffeine from coffee beans can be eliminated by using plant biotechnology.

Select the correct answer using the code given below:

Plant biotechnology is a set of techniques used to adapt plants for specific needs or opportunities. Plant biotechnologies that assist in developing new varieties and traits include genetics and genomics, marker-assisted selection (MAS), and transgenic (genetic engineered) crops.

  • Plant biotechnology can reduce a number of undesirable food components, such as one of the major allergenic proteins in rice or the major allergens in peanut or soybeans.
  • Components such as caffeine from coffee beans can be eliminated or reduced to provide a coffee with no or a very low caffeine level without using chemical extraction
  • Plant breeding and biotechnology can be used to improve energy crops to increase yield, improve tolerance to pests and drought, to alter the characteristics of the plants (e.g. percentage of lignin, oil content, cell structure) making it more efficient to convert them to liquid biofuels.
  • Plant breeding promotes the most essential traits for a bioenergy crop such as high yield of biomass, but also improvements such as single annual harvest, recycling more nutrients back into roots before harvest, delayed harvest or disease resistance.

Many of the breeding and development efforts for bioenergy crops emphasize perennial crops and target lands that are marginal or less ideal for food or livestock production, such as land that is excessively wet or dry, acid soils, or highly erodible soils.
The techniques of using live organisms of enzymes from organism to produce products and processes useful to human is called:

Biotechnology is the use of living systems and organisms to develop or make products, or any technological application that uses biological systems, living organisms, or derivatives thereof, to make or modify products or processes for specific use.
_______ is the right granted by a government to an inventor to prevent others from the commercial use of his invention.
Patents are the right granted by a government to an inventor to prevent others from the commercial use of his invention. It is a form of intellectual property that gives legal rights to the inventor.
GEAC makes decisions regarding the validity and the safety of which kind of organisms?

GEAC makes decisions regarding the validity and the safety of genetically modified organisms. It works under the Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change and takes decisions regarding the validity of GM research and safety of introducing GM products for public services.
What is the primary function of monoclonal antibodies in medicine?
Detection of specific molecules in the body

Monoclonal antibodies are laboratory-produced molecules that can bind to specific targets, such as antigens or proteins. In medicine, they are used for targeted detection of molecules, such as tumor markers or pathogens, in diagnostic tests like ELISA.

Ethidium bromide is an intercalating agent commonly used as a fluorescent tag (nucleic acid stain) in molecular biology laboratories for techniques such as agarose gel electrophoresis. It is commonly abbreviated as "EtBr", which is also an abbreviation for bromoethane. When exposed to ultraviolet light, it will fluoresce with an orange colour, intensifying almost 20-fold after binding to DNA. It fluoresces at the wavelength at 254 nm.

In RNA, uracil binds to adenine via two hydrogen bonds. In DNA, the uracil nucleobase is replaced by thymine. Uracil could be considered a demethylated form of thymine. Each nucleotide in RNA contains a ribose sugar, with carbons numbered 1' through 5'. A base is attached to the 1' position, in general, adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), or uracil (U). Adenine and guanine are purines, cytosine and uracil are pyrimidines.

Which of the following fatty acids are end products of carbohydrate fermentation by rumen microorganisms?

a. Acetic acid

b. Caproic acid

c. Butyric acid

d. Caprylic acid

Acetic acid, caproic acid and butyric acid are the end products of carbohydrate fermentation by rumen microorganisms.

Carbohydrate fermentation is the process microorganisms use to produce energy. Most microorganisms convert glucose to pyruvate during glycolysis; however, some organisms use alternate pathways. A fermentation medium consists of a basal medium containing a single carbohydrate (glucose, lactose, sucrose, mannitol etc.)
Cysteic acid is a naturally occurring amino acid that is found in:

Cysteic acid is a naturally occurring amino acid that is found in sheep's fleece.

Cysteic acid is an amino sulfonic acid that is the sulfonic acid analogue of cysteine. It has a role as an animal metabolite. It is an alanine derivative, an amino sulfonic acid, a carboxyalkanesulfonic acid, a cysteine derivative and a non-proteinogenic alpha-amino acid.
Which one of the following is an aldopentose?

D-arabinose is an aldopentose.

Aldopentose: A pentose with a (potential) aldehyde group at one end.

Pentose: A five-carbon monosaccharide which in its linear form contains either an aldehyde group at position 1 (aldopentose) or a ketone group at position 2 (ketopentose).

Nucleoproteins like histones can be more easily obtained from:

a. Yeast cells

b. Thymus gland

c. Mesophyll cells

d. Cheek cells

Nucleoproteins like histones can be more easily obtained from yeast cells and thymus gland.

Nucleoproteins is a conjugated protein consisting of a protein linked to a nucleic acid, either DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) or RNA (ribonucleic acid). The protein combined with DNA is commonly either histone or protamine; the resulting nucleoproteins are found in chromosomes.
In which carbohydrates are S-type glycosidic bonds found?

S-type glycosidic bonds found in thioglycosides carbohydrates.

S-type glycosidic bonds: In which the oxygen of the glycosidic bond is replaced with a sulfur atom.

Glycosidic bond: A covalent bond that joins the hemiacetal group of a saccharide molecule and the hydroxyl group of some organic compound e.g., an alcohol. 

Chemical reaction between an amino acid and a reducing sugar, which is important in the food industry as a form of non-enzymatic browning.
Which of the following amino acids is a conditionally essential amino acid?

Arginine, a semi essential or conditionally essential amino acid in humans, is one of the most metabolically versatile amino acids and serves as a precursor for the synthesis of urea, nitric oxide, polyamines, proline, glutamate, creatine, and agmatine.
Which nitrogenous base on deamination yields xanthine?

Guanine deamination yields xanthine.

Guanine is subsequently converted to xanthine by the enzymes guanine deaminase and xanthine oxidase (also known as xanthine dehydrogenase), respectively. Xanthine from either source is then converted directly to uric acid, again by the action of xanthine oxidase.
Which of the following naturally occurring amino acids acts as a part of pantetheine and coenzyme A?

Beta-alanine is a naturally occurring amino acids acts as a part of pantetheine and coenzyme A.

The IUPAC name for Beta-alanine is 3-aminopropanoic acid. Unlike its counterpart α-alanine, Beta-alanine has no stereocenter.
Which of the following statements is true about candelilla wax?
It is a hard yellowish brown wax.
It is the only water soluble wax.

Candelilla wax is a hard yellowish brown wax.

Candelilla wax is a wax derived from the leaves of the small Candelilla shrub native to northern Mexico and the southwestern United States, Euphorbia cerifera and Euphorbia antisyphilitica, from the family Euphorbiaceae. It is hard, brittle, aromatic, and opaque to translucent.
Which of the following statements is false about D-galactose?
It is obtained on hydrolysis of lactose.

It is completely fermented by yeast is false about D-galactose.

D-Galactose, also known as alpha-D-gal or ALPHA D-galactose, belongs to the class of organic compounds known as hexoses. These are monosaccharides in which the sugar unit is a is a six-carbon containing moeity. D-Galactose is an extremely weak basic (essentially neutral) compound.
Which of the following amino acids has a breaking action on the alpha-helix structure of protein?

Proline has a breaking action on the alpha-helix structure of protein.

Proline is an amino acid, or a building block for protein. The body can make proline on its own, but it is also consumed in the diet. A typical diet contains about 5 grams of proline daily. The primary sources are protein-rich foods including meat, fish, and dairy.
Which of the biological functions can be attributed to amino acid isoleucine?
Recovery of muscle tissue after physical stress

Recovery of muscle tissue after physical stress is the biological functions can be attributed to amino acid isoleucine.

Isoleucine, as one of the branched chain amino acids, is also critical in physiological functions of the whole body, such as growth, immunity, protein metabolism, fatty acid metabolism and glucose transportation. Isoleucine can improve the immune system, including immune organs, cells and reactive substances.
Cholesterol translocation from outer to the inner membrane of mitochondria is done by:

Cholesterol translocation from outer to the inner membrane of mitochondria is done by cardiolipin.

Cardiolipin is an important component of the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it constitutes about 20% of the total lipid composition. It can also be found in the membranes of most bacteria. The name "cardiolipin" is derived from the fact that it was first found in animal hearts.
When starch is treated with iodine solution, its colour changes to

Starch is the storage food reserve of a plant which is mainly present in the leaf. When its presence is tested by Iodine, It forms a blue- black color complex of starch Iodide. The iodine/starch complex has energy level spacings that are just so for absorbing visible light giving the complex its intense blue color.
A flower is a modified shoot. Which of the following parts of a flower is made-up of one to many stamens?

Androecium part of the a flower is made-up of one to many stamens.

The third whorl of a flower is called the androecium. Androecium, is made up of male reproductive units called stamens. They produce sperm cells packaged inside pollen grains. An androecium is usually made up of multiple stamina (plural of stamen); each is composed of two parts, the filament and the anther.
A dithecous anther consists of ____ microsporangia and _____ in each lobe.

A stamen or male reproductive organ of a flower is made up of two parts- a stalk-like filament and a knob like terminal anther. Each anther has two lobes which are attached at the back by a sterile band called connective. When both the anther lobes are present, the stamen is called bithecous(or dithecous). A dithecous anther is tetrasporangiate having four microsporangia. Each lobe has two microsporangia separated by a strop of sterile tissue. When a single anther lobe is present, the stamen is termed as monothecous.
The germ pores in the pollen grain are the regions :
That can withstand high temperature and strong acids and alkalies
Through which sperms are released into the female gametophyte
Which are made up of lignin and suberin

The pollen grains are the male gametophytes. The pollen grains have two protective layers. 

The inner is the thin layer which is called as intine. The outer is a tough and hard layer called as exine. 

There is a presence of the compound sporopollenin on the outer exine which provides resistance to the pollen grain from the destructive agents. 

The sporopollenin is absent at certain regions. These regions are called as the germ pores. 

This is the region through which the germ tube emerges out during pollination.
Filament is the long and slender stalk. Its proximal end is attached to the:

Filament is the long and slender stalk. Its proximal end is attached to the thalamus.

Thalamus is defined as a kind of modified stem and is present near the stalk of the flower. Near the stalk they divide to form nodes and internodes. Thalamus is used to supply nutrients. It acts as a base of the flower.

Which of the following wall layers help(s) in dehiscence of anther and perform(s) the function of protection?

A. Epidermis

B. Tapetum

C. Endothecium

D. Middle layer

Epidermis is the outermost, protoderm-derived layer of cells covering the stem, root, leaf, flower, fruit, and seed parts of a plant. The epidermis and its waxy cuticle provide a protective barrier against mechanical injury, water loss, and infection.

Endothecium is the fibrous tissue of the inner wall of an anther.

The middle layer is an essential cell layer of the anther wall located between the endothecium and tapetum in Arabidopsis.
Exine is made up of sporopollenin. Which of the following is not a property of sporopollenin?
It cannot be degraded by any known enzyme.
It can withstand strong acids and alkali.

Exine of a pollen grain is made up of sporopollenin which is resistant to high temperature, strong acid or alkali as well as enzymatic degradation.

Sporopollenin is absent in the region of germ pores or germinal furrows.

The outer wall or exine of pollen grains contains sporopollenin. It is one of the most resistant organic compounds known. It protects pollen grains from external factors such as temperature, acid, alkali, etc. Because of sporopollenin, pollen grains are preserved as fossils.
Which of the following represents the basal part of the ovule and is opposite to the micropylar end?

Chalaza represents the basal part of the ovule and is opposite to the micropylar end.

Chalaza is the basal part of the ovule in plants, where nucellus and integuments join. It is present opposite to the micropylar end of an ovule. Nutrients from plants are transported to nucellus through chalaza. The chalazal end of cells in the embryo sac develops into three antipodal cells.

Match the following:
A. Unitegmic ovules 1. They are the ovules with two integuments. Example: Monocots
B. Bitegmic ovules 2. They are the ovules without integument. Example: Santalum
C. Tritegmic ovules 3. They are the ovules with one integument. Example: Higher dicots
D. Ategmic ovules 4. They are the ovules with three integuments (rarely ovule). Example: Asphodelus

A. Unitegmic ovules - They are the ovules with one integument. Example: Higher dicots.

B. Bitegmic ovules - They are the ovules with two integuments. Example: Monocots.

C. Tritegmic ovules - They are the ovules with three integuments (rarely ovule). Example: Asphodelus.

D. Ategmic ovules - They are the ovules without integument. Example: Santalum.
In which type of ovule, the body of ovule becomes curved so that the micropyle and chalaza do not lie in the same straight line?

Amphitropus ovule: The body of the ovule is very much curved that the embryo sac and the ovule itself take the shape of a horseshoe.

The body of the ovule is curved so much that it induces curvature in the embryo sac. Examples are Lemna, Poppy, Alisma, etc.

A bisexual flower which never opens is cleistogamous. It is a condition in which flower does not open. It is an adaptation seen in plants to ensure self-pollination. In such flowers, the anthers and stigma lie close to each other. When anther dehisces in the flower buds, pollen grains come in contact with stigma to effect pollination.
Which of the following pollination occurs by snails and slugs?

Flowers that are pollinated with snail and slug are known as malacophily and pollination is called as malacophilous.

Pollination can occur through various agents including wind, water, birds, animals, bats, molluscs, etc.

Which of the following statements is/are false?

A. The fusion of two male gametes with two different cells of different female gametophyte is called double fertilisation.

B. Fertilisation is porogamous if the pollen tube enter the ovule through chalaza or integuments.

C. Entry of pollen tube into style is facilitated by secretion of pectinases and hydrolytic enzymes.

False Statement - The fusion of two male gametes with two different cells of different female gametophyte is called double fertilisation.

Double fertilization is a chief trait of flowering plants. In the phenomena, one female gamete unites with two male gametes. One of the male gametes fertilizes the egg resulting in the formation of a zygote and the other unites with 2 polar nuclei for the formation of an endosperm.

Double fertilization provides stimulus to the plant resulting in the ovarian development to fruits and the development of ovules into the seed. When the haploid male gametes and female gametes fuse, the diploid state of the plant is restored.
In which of the following, the first mitotic division of primary endospermic cell is accompanied by cytokinesis and further nuclear divisions are not accompanied by cytokinesis?

in Musa the first mitotic division of primary endospermic cell is accompanied by cytokinesis and further nuclear divisions are not accompanied by cytokinesis.

Musa is one of two or three genera in the family Musaceae. The genus includes flowering plants producing edible bananas and plantains. Around 70 species of Musa are known, with a broad variety of uses.

Seeds which store food in endosperm are called endospermic seeds. Which of the following are endospermic seeds?

A. Castor

B. Gram

C. Pea

D. Maize

Maize and Castor are endospermic seeds.

Endospermic seeds are those that have an endosperm in the mature seed. It is fleshy, oily, surrounds the embryo, and functions as the sole food storage organ. Inside the seed coat, a thin and papery cotyledon is present. Monocot plants have endospermic seeds.
Formation of fruit without fertilization Is known as:

Parthenocarpy refers to the development of fruit without fertilization. The process produces a sterile fruit that lacks seeds. This means that the pollination results in a production of berries that are completely seedless.

Varieties of the pineapple, banana, cucumber, grape, orange, grapefruit, persimmon, and breadfruit exemplify naturally occurring parthenocarpy.

Match the following:

A. Apogamy1. It is the formation of an embryo sac directly from a nucellus cell or diploid megaspore mother cell. 
B. Apospory2. It is the formation of gametophyte directly from a sporophyte without the formation of spores. 
C. Recurrent agamospermy3. It is the formation of sporophyte directly from a gametophyte without the formation of gametes

A. Apogamy - It is the formation of sporophyte directly from a gametophyte without the formation of gametes.

B. Apospory - It is the formation of gametophyte directly from a sporophyte without the formation of spores. 

C. Recurrent agamospermy - It is the formation of an embryo sac directly from a nucellus cell or diploid megaspore mother cell.
An embryo develops from diploid cell of nucellus or integument in:

An embryo develops from diploid cell of nucellus or integument in opuntia.

Embryony :-It is also known as saprophytic budding. Embryo arises from diploid saprophytic cells such as nucellus or integuments (other than egg), e.g., Citrus, Opuntia, Mango.

The polyembryony phenomenon was discovered by Leeuwenhoek in 1719, who observed the formation of two plantlets from the same citrus seed.

Among different ways of polyembryony, activation of some sporophytic cells of the ovule in the formation of embryo is more common. The embryos arising from the maternal sporophytic cells (outside the embryo sac) are called adventive embryos.

In haploid parthenogenesis, a normal haploid egg develops into a haploid embryo. Haploid parthenogenesis occurs in which of the following plants?

A. Banana

B. Cucumber

C. Solanum

D. Oenothera

Haploid parthenogenesis occurs in Solanum and Oenothera plants.

In haploid parthenogenesis, a rare form of parthenogenesis that occurs in a few species of bees, nematodes, and plants, offspring develop from haploid eggs to produce haploid adults.
Which of the following is not a method of removing sexual incompatibility?
Application of sodium citrate solution to stigma
Application of sodium citrate solution to stigma is  not a method of removing sexual incompatibility.
The flower which do not open at all are called:

The flower which do not open at all are called cleistogamous flower.

Cleistogamy or automatic self-pollination describes the trait of certain plants to propagate by using non-opening, self-pollinating flowers. Especially well known in peanuts, peas, and beans, this behavior is most widespread in the grass family.
Which type of flower have ovary superior?

In hypogynous flower ovary is located at highest position on thalamus of flower. Other floral parts are below it. These kinds of flower are called ovary superior.

A superior ovary is found in types of fleshy fruits such as true berries, drupes, etc. A flower with this arrangement is described as hypogynous.

Insect-pollinated flowers are colourful and contain nectar.

Insect-pollinated flowers usually possess sticky and heavy pollens with a rough surface that allow them to stick to insects easily. Flowers also have sweet nectar that attracts insects that go from flower to flower to pollinate the flowers.
Which of the following occupies central position in flower:

Bisexual flower have four main parts. Pistil or carpel is located at center followed by stamen, carpel and sepals. Pistil contains stigma, style and ovary.

Pistil, the female reproductive part of a flower. The pistil, centrally located, typically consists of a swollen base, the ovary, which contains the potential seeds, or ovules; a stalk, or style, arising from the ovary; and a pollen-receptive tip, the stigma, variously shaped and often sticky.
During Hybridisation process anther of bisexual flower is removed before it dehisces is called

During Hybridisation process anther of bisexual flower is removed before it dehisces is called emasculation.

Hybridisation is the process to develop hybrid plants with desired traits. In bisexual flower, the stamen is removed with the help of forceps to avoid self-pollination.
Which of the following states of cell cycle is attained when the cell has undergone differentiation?

The cell cycle mainly consists of 4 stages \({G}_{1}, {~S}, {G}_{2}\), and \({M}\). The \({G}_{0}\) phase also known as the extended \({G} 1\) phase is a period in which the cell exits from the cell cycle. In this stage, the cell exists in a quiescent state and does not divide.
Which of the following is true about meiosis?
Meiosis maintains constant number of chromosomes in an organ.
Meiosis provides opportunity for the exchange of genes.
Meiosis causes genetic variations among the species.

In sexually reproducing organisms, meiosis produces haploid gametes which later on fuse to form the diploid organism. Thus, there is a regular alteration between haploid gametes and diploid adult, this is possible due to meiosis. 

Meiosis involves pairing of homologous chromosomes, crossing over between homologous chromosomes leading to exchange of segments between non sister chromatids of a homologous pair of chromosome and finally separation of homologous chromosomes.
Crossing over takes place at a stage between:

Crossing over takes place at a stage between zygotene and diplotene.

Prophase 1 is the first stage of meiosis and is divided into five phases, namely Leptotene, Zygotene, Pachytene, Diplotene and Diakinesis. 

During pachytene, chromosomes condense. Crossing over takes place during this stage and at the end, chiasma is formed between non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes.
The colchicine prevents the mitosis of cells at which of the following stage?

A cell is treated with drugs such as Colchicine, vincistrine, the assembly of the microtubules is inhibited, while the dis-assembly continues leading to continues disorganization of microtubules. 

Colchicine is an alkaloid. It can be extracted from corms of plant Colchicum autumnale and C. luteum. Colchicines prevent spindle formation during mitotic metaphase. 

Thus, it prevents the separation of chromosomes during anaphase stage.

The nucleus is found in all the eukaryotic cells of the plants and animals. The size of the nucleus is directly proportional to that of the cytoplasm. The nucleus is composed of the following structures:

Nuclear envelope or karyotheca: The nuclear membrane or karyotheca forms an envelope-like structure called a nuclear envelope around the nuclear contents. The nuclear envelope separates the nucleoplasm from the cytoplasm.

Nucleolus: The nucleus contains a large, spherical, and acidophilic dense granule as nucleolus. It was first described by Fontana in 1781. The nucleolus is composed of the following four zones - Granular, amorphous, fibrillar zone and nuclear associated chromatin

Nuclear matrix or nucleoplasm: The space between the nuclear envelope and the nucleolus is filled by a transparent, semisolid, granular substance or matrix known as nucleoplasm.

Chromatin fibres: The nucleoplasm contains many thread-like, coiled and much-elongated structures which take the basic stains such as basic fuchsin. These thread-like structures are known as chromatin fibres. During cell division ( meiosis and mitosis ) chromatin fibres become thick ribbon-like structures which are known as chromosomes.
Which statement is not true for karyotype?
It provides information about chromosome number, relative size, position of centromere, etc.
It is described in the form of idiogram.
Cells are treated with colchicine at metaphase.

C-banding brings about AT rich region is not true for karyotype.

A karyotype test looks at the size, shape, and number of your chromosomes. Chromosomes are the parts of our cells that contain our genes. Genes are parts of DNA passed down from our mother and father. They carry information that determines our unique traits, such as height and eye color.
Colchicine is a root extract of Colchicum autumnale. It inhibits cell cycle during the stage of:

Colchicine is a root extract of Colchicum autumnale. It inhibits cell cycle during the stage of M phase.

It can be extracted from corms of plant Colchicum autumnale and C. luteum. Colchicine prevent spindle formation during mitotic metaphase. Thus, it prevents the separation of chromosomes during anaphase stage.
Which of the following processes takes place during the G2 phase of cell division?
Synthesis of RNA, proteins, nucleotides and amino acids
Synthesis of factors required for initiation and completion of mitosis and checks for any abberrations resulting from DNA synthesis
Synthesis of RNA and proteins leading to the growth of cell to normal size
Synthesis of DNA leading to chromosomal replication

Synthesis of factors required for initiation and completion of mitosis and checks for any abberrations resulting from DNA synthesis is the process takes place during the G2 phase of cell division.

G2 phase is a period of rapid cell growth and protein synthesis during which the cell prepares itself for mitosis. Curiously, G2 phase is not a necessary part of the cell cycle, as some cell types (particularly young Xenopus embryos and some cancers) proceed directly from DNA replication to mitosis.

Consider the following statements:

Segmental allopolyploids are the polyploids in which:

1. The chromosomes are derived from different genomes

2. The chromosomes form multivalents during meiosis

3. The genomes involved are not quite different from one another

Which of the statements given above are correct?

Segmental allopolyploids are the polyploids in which the chromosomes are derived from different genomes and the genomes involved are not quite different from one another.

Segmental Allopolyploidy: Some degree of homology (partial homology) may exist between some chromosome of one genome and those of the other genome. Therefore, in such polyploids both bivalents and multivalents are formed. This type of chromosome pairing is called heterogenetic pairing or allosyndetic pairing.
DNA molecules of each chromosome become double in:

DNA molecules of each chromosome become double in S phase.

S phase is the period of wholesale DNA synthesis during which the cell replicates its genetic content a normal diploid somatic cell with a 2N complement of DNA at the beginning of S phase acquires a 4N complement of DNA at its end.
In which of the following phases of meiosis I does synapsis occur?

In meiosis I, synapsis formation occurs in the zygotene stage of prophase-I. 

It is the second stage of prophase-I. During this stage, the chromosomes start pairing together and this process of association called synapsis. Such paired chromosomes are called homologous chromosomes. This synapsis is accompanied by the formation of synaptonemal complex formed by bivalent or tetrad chromosomes.
What is the correct sequence of prophase I of meiosis I?
Prophase I of meiosis is the first stage of meiosis I and is divided into five different phases in the following order; Leptotene, Zygotene, Pachytene, Diplotene and Diakinesis.
Which one is the longest phase of cell cycle?

G1 phase is typically the longest phase of the cell cycle. 

This can be explained by the fact that G1 follows cell division in mitosis G1 represents the first chance for new cells have to grow. Cells usually remain in G1 for about 10 hours of the 24 total hours of the cell cycle.

A stage in cell division is shown in the figure. Select the answer which gives the correct identification of the stage with its characteristics.

(1) Late anaphase Chromosomes move away from equatorial plate, golgi complex not present
(2) Cytokinesis Cell plate formed, mitochondria distributed between two daughter cells
(3) Telophase Endoplasmic reticulum and nucleolus not reformed yet
(4) Telophase Nuclear envelop reforms, golgi complex reforms

The figure shows a stage of telophase in cell division.

Telophase is the fifth and final phase of mitosis, the process that separates the duplicated genetic material carried in the nucleus of a parent cell into two identical daughter cells. Telophase begins once the replicated, paired chromosomes have been separated and pulled to opposite sides, or poles, of the cell.
In which of the following ways mitosis and meiosis are similar?
Both are preceded by the replication of DNA
Both occur in all kinds of cells
Both include the separation of the chromosomes

Mitosis and meiosis are two types of cell divisions, commonly seen in organisms.

Mitosis is responsible for the growth of organisms while meiosis is a specialized type of cell division seen in germ cells during the formation of gametes which leads to the formation of haploid gametes.

Both types of cell division occur following DNA replication. 

In mitosis, DNA replication is followed by cell division. Each time DNA replicates it is followed by cell division.

In meiosis, two divisions occur called Meiosis I and II, following one round of DNA replication. In both meiosis and mitosis, chromosomes separate. In mitosis centromere splits and the two sister chromatids move to opposite poles as the chromosomes of daughter cells.

In meiosis during meiosis I there is no splitting of centromere and one chromosome of each homologous pair moves to the opposite pole.

Thus, the chromosome number is reduced to half. In meiosis II, which occurs in both the daughter cells produced after meiosis I, centromere splits as in mitosis thus the chromosome number remains the same as at the start of meiosis II, i.e., half the original parent cell

Plants show mitotic divisions in haploid cells and diploid cells.

Haploid describes a cell that contains a single set of chromosomes. The term haploid can also refer to the number of chromosomes in egg or sperm cells, which are also called gametes. In humans, gametes are haploid cells that contain 23 chromosomes, each of which a one of a chromosome pair that exists in diplod cells.

Diploid describes a cell that contain two copies of each chromosome. Nearly all the cells in the human body carry two homologous, or similar, copies of each chromosome. The only exception is cells in the germ line, which go on to produce gametes, or egg and sperm cells.
What is the average cell cycle span for a mammalian cell?

The average cell cycle span for a mammalian cell is about 24 hours. The cells remains in the G1 phase for about 10 hours. The duration of S phase or the Synthetic phase varies with respect to the total DNA present in a cell.
The number of chromosome and the amount of DNA are changed in:

S phase marks the period during which DNA synthesis or replication takes place. During this time the amount of DNA per cell doubles. If the initial amount of DNA is denoted as 2C then it increases to 4C and even in anaphase the chromosome numbers are changed.
In yeast the cell cycle is progressed through:

The duration of cell cycle can vary from organism to organism and also from cell type to cell type. For example, normal human cells in culture, divide once in approximately every 24 hours but yeast can progress through the cell cycle in only about 90 minutes.

M phase represents mitosis phase.

It is characterized by  karyokinesis. It is a relatively short period of the cell cycle. M phase is complex and highly regulated. The sequence of events is divided into phases, corresponding to the completion of one set of activities and the start of the next. These phases are sequentially known as prophase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase.
How many chromosomes are present in each cell of onion root tip?

Onion root tip cells have 16 chromosomes in each cell, same as the number of chromosomes in somatic cells. The number of chromosomes in the cell will be 16 at G1 phase, after S phase and after M phase.

In animal cells, during G2 phase proteins are synthesized.

During G2 phase, cell increases in size, and centrosomes of animal cells, that were duplicated during S phase, are positioned at opposite locations in the cytoplasm. During M phase, centrosomes polymerize the mitotic spindle.
In cell cycle, which stage is also called as resting phase?

The interphase is also called as the resting phase. 90% of cell cycle is formed by interphase. Interphase is the phase of the cell cycle in which the cell spends and performs the majority of its time. 

Then, in preparation for cellular division, it increases in size. Interphase is also considered to be the living phase of the cell, in which the cell obtains nutrients, grows, reads its DNA, and conducts other normal cell functions.
In animal cells, the mitotic division is seen in:

In animal cells, the mitotic division is seen in diploid somatic cells.

Diploid somatic cell: Somatic cells are diploid, meaning they contain two sets of chromosomes, one inherited from each parent. DNA mutations in somatic cells can affect an individual, but they cannot be passed on to their offspring.
In which stage, the cells remain metabolically active but do not proliferate?

G0 phase is also called a quiescent phase. At this phase, the cell remains metabolic active but there is no longer proliferation. 

It is a period of resting stage for a cell, where the cell is neither dividing nor preparing to divide and no longer proliferate unless called to do so depending on the requirement of the organism.

S phase marks DNA replication and chromosome duplication.

S phase is the period of wholesale DNA synthesis during which the cell replicates its genetic content; a normal diploid somatic cell with a 2N complement of DNA at the beginning of S phase acquires a 4N complement of DNA at its end.
Which one proceeds reformation of nuclear envelope during M phase of cell cycle?
Decondensation of chromosomes with appearance of nuclear lamina
Transcription from chromosomes and reassemble of nuclear lamina

After anaphase, when the chromatids have moved towards the opposite poles, furrowing starts in an animal cell to separate the two cells. Before the nuclear membrane reappears, the chromatids decondense and acquire back their chromosome original state and reassemble themselves. 

After that, the nuclear membrane is developed to enclose the chromatin material and separate it from the cytoplasm. Since the cell division is in progress, the transcription process cannot take place.
The stage of inactivation of cell cycle due to non-availability of mitogens and energy rich compounds is called:

The stage of inactivation of cell cycle due to non-availability of mitogens and energy rich compounds is called quiescent phase.

Quiescent phase is the stage wherein cells remain metabolically active but do not proliferate unless called to do so. Such cells are used for replacing the cells lost during injury.
Changes occurring at anaphase, when chromosomes move to the opposite poles
Over all changes occurring in nucleus during the cell division

Karyokinesis is also called direct nuclear division, because the nucleus passes through a series of uninterrupted changes before forming two daughter nuclei. Though, karyokinesis is a continuous process, it has been divided into four phases for the sake of convenience. They are prophase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase.
Each chromosome composed of one chromatid in:

Each chromosome composed of one chromatid in anaphase II because the centromeres separate, and the two chromatids of each chromosome move to opposite poles on the spindle. The separated chromatids are now called chromosomes in their own right.
The building block of nucleic acid is:

Nucleotides, the building blocks of nucleic acids, consist of a nitrogenous base (adenine, guanine, cytosine, thymine in DNA, or uracil in RNA), a pentose sugar (deoxyribose or ribose), and a phosphate group. They polymerize via phosphodiester bonds to form the backbone of DNA and RNA, encoding genetic information through the sequence of bases. This versatility facilitates crucial cellular processes such as replication, transcription, and translation.
Each strand of DNA has a typical structure. Which of the following statements correctly explains its structure?
The sugar-phosphate chain on the outside and the bases on the inside are held together by weak hydrogen bonds.
The sugar-phosphate chain on the inside and the bases on the outside are held together by weak hydrogen bonds.
The sugar-phosphate chain on the outside and the bases on the inside are held together by strong hydrogen bonds.
The sugar-phosphate chain on the inside and the bases on the outside are held together by strong hydrogen bonds.

In DNA, the sugar-phosphate backbone forms the outer structure of the double helix, with nitrogenous bases positioned internally. Base pairing via hydrogen bonds (A with T and C with G) results in the ladder-like structure of the helix, where bases stack internally and the sugar-phosphate backbone comprises the sides. This arrangement gives DNA its characteristic double helical shape.
Which of the following base pairs in DNA are correct?

Guanine-Cytosine represents a correct base pair in DNA. In DNA, the base pairing occurs between adenine (A) and thymine (T), forming two hydrogen bonds, and between guanine (G) and cytosine (C), forming three hydrogen bonds. This complementary base pairing ensures the stability and fidelity of the DNA molecule.
In the Griffith experiment, which of the following resulted in the death of the mice?
Live S strain bacteria → Inject into mice
Live R strain bacteria → Inject into mice
Heat-killed S strain bacteria → Inject into mice
Heat-killed R strain bacteria → Inject into mice

Griffith performed the transformation experiment in mice using the R and S strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae. S strain is generally pathogenic and R strain is non-pathogenic. However, the heat-killed S strain cannot cause the disease. So when R strain and heat-killed S strain bacteria were injected separately, the mice stayed alive. But when injected together, the mice died. This was because, R strain bacteria got “transformed” into S strains, and caused the disease. Heat-killed R strain does not affect the mice and the mice live.
In which of the following processes does copying of genetic information from one strand of DNA into RNA take place?

Transcription involves RNA polymerase binding to DNA at the promoter, unwinding the double helix, and synthesizing mRNA. This process copies genetic information from DNA into mRNA, facilitating gene expression. It's a crucial step in genetic information flow within cells.
Which of the following is/are the characteristic(s) of genes?

Genes are segments of DNA that serve as the basic units of heredity. They possess several key characteristics:

Replication and transmission to progeny, ensuring the inheritance of genetic information from one generation to the next. 

Mutability, as genes can undergo changes or mutations over time, contributing to genetic diversity and evolution. 

Storage of hereditary information, as genes encode the instructions necessary for the development, functioning, and regulation of organisms. 

So, all options accurately describes the characteristics of genes, encompassing their roles in replication, transmission, mutability, and storage of hereditary information.
Which of the following does not define the transcription unit in a DNA?
The transcription unit consists of promoter structural gene and terminator. The inducer (lactose/ allolactose) is not a component of the transcription unit.
Which of the following RNA polymerase enzyme catalyses the formation of precursor of mRNA (hnRNA)?

A primary transcript is the single-stranded ribonucleic acid product synthesized by transcription of DNA, and processed to yield various mature RNA products such as mRNA, tRNA, rRNA. The primary transcripts designated to be mRNAs are modified in preparation for translation. For example, a precursor messenger RNA (pre-mRNA) is a type of primary transcript that becomes a messenger RNA (mRNA) after processing. RNA polymerase II of eukaryotes transcribes the primary transcript, which is destined to be processed into mRNA.
In a genetic code, some codons do not code for amino acids that function as stop codons. Which of the following does not belong to this group?

In the genetic code, UAG, UAA, and UGA are stop codons, also known as termination codons or nonsense codons. These codons signal the termination of translation, leading to the release of the polypeptide chain from the ribosome. In contrast, UUU (uracil-uracil-uracil) is the codon for the amino acid phenylalanine. Therefore, UUU does not belong to the group of stop codons.
Which of the following codes has a dual function?

The codon AUG has a dual function. It codes for amino acid methionine and it also acts as initiator codon. AUG codes for the amino acid methionine, and so all protein translation begins with methionine. Methionine is specified by the codon AUG, which is also known as the start codon. Consequently, methionine is the first amino acid to dock in the ribosome during the synthesis of proteins.
In point mutation, how many base pairs are inserted or deleted?

In point mutation, a single nucleotide base pair is either substituted, inserted, or deleted from the DNA sequence. This alteration can lead to changes in the corresponding mRNA codon during transcription, potentially resulting in changes to the amino acid sequence of the encoded protein. Therefore, point mutations typically involve the alteration of only one base pair.

Which of the following statement(s) are correct with respect to mutation?

I. Insertion or deletion of 3 bases or its multiple does not change the reading frame from that point onwards

II. Mutation may occur due to the defects in the duplication of DNA

III. Mutations can be caused by certain chemicals

Mutation is an alteration in the genetic material of a cell of a living organism that is more or less permanent. It may occur due to the defects in the duplication of DNA, certain chemicals, radiations etc.

The division of the polynucleotide molecule into sets of three consecutive nucleotides (triplet) that are non-overlapping is called the reading frame. When the triplets either specify amino acids or terminate protein synthesis, they are known as codons. Addition or deletion of nucleotides in count of 3 or its multiples does not affect the reading frame as there is direct addition or deletion of one codon consisting of three nucleotides.
It binds with an amino acid at its \(3^{\prime}\) end.
It has a codon at one end which recognizes the anticodon on messenger RNA.
It looks like a clover leaf in the three dimensional structure.

All tRNAs have about 73 to 93 nucleotides that fold into four base-paired stems and three loops, a structure which looks like a clover leaf in two dimension and. it is "L" shaped in three-dimensional structure. The 3' end has CCA sequence. Attachment of an amino acid to the 3 adenosine yields an aminoacyl-tRNA. Transfer-RNA has 7-15% post-transcriptionally modified bases. Dihydrouridine (D) is nearly always found in the D-loop and ribothymidine (T) and pseudouridine in the T psi C loop. The D-loop serves as Aminoacyl synthetase recognition and binding loop while the T psi C loop binds the charged tRNA-amino acid to the ribosome. The anticodon loop has triplet at the tip which base pairs with the corresponding codon in mRNA.

Which of the following sequences of the steps involved in the process of polymerisation of amino acids to form a polypeptide is correct?

(1) Activation of amino acids, Termination of polypeptide synthesis, Elongation of polypeptide synthesis, Initiation of polypeptide synthesis
(2) Initiation of polypeptide synthesis, Activation of amino acids, Elongation of polypeptide synthesis, Termination of polypeptide synthesis
(3) Termination of polypeptide synthesis, Elongation of polypeptide synthesis, Activation of amino acids, Initiation of polypeptide synthesis
(4) Activation of amino acids, Initiation of polypeptide synthesis, Elongation of polypeptide synthesis, Termination of polypeptide synthesis

Translation proceeds in three phases:

Initiation: The ribosome assembles around the target mRNA. The first tRNA is attached at the start codon.

Elongation: The last tRNA validated by the small ribosomal subunit (accommodation) transfers the amino acid it carries to the large ribosomal subunit which binds it to the one of the precedingly admitted tRNA (transpeptidation). The ribosome then moves to the next mRNA codon to continue the process (translocation), creating an amino acid chain.

Termination: When a stop codon is reached, the ribosome releases the polypeptide. The ribosomal complex remains intact and moves on to the next mRNA to be translated.

Match the following:

1.Splicinga.Addition of methyl guanosine triphosphate at 5'–end
2.Cappingb.Addition of adenylate residues at 3'–end
3.Tailingc.Removal of non-coding introns

The correct answer is : 1 - c, 2 - a, 3 - b.

Splicing: During the process of splicing, introns are removed from the pre-mRNA by the spliceosome and exons are spliced back together. Splicing occurs in the nucleus before the RNA migrates to the cytoplasm.

Capping: The capping process replaces the triphosphate group with another structure called the "cap". The cap is added by the enzyme guanyl transferase. This enzyme catalyzes the reaction between the 5' end of the RNA transcript and a guanine triphosphate (GTP) molecule.

Tailing: Tailing is an enzymatic method for adding a non-templated nucleotide to the 3' end of a blunt, double-stranded DNA molecule. Tailing is typically done to prepare a T-vector for use in TA cloning or to A-tail a PCR product produced by a high-fidelity polymerase (not Taq) for use in TA cloning.
The tendency of offspring to differ from parents is called:

The tendency of offspring to differ from parents is called variation. It is the degree by which progeny or offspring differ from their parents. These variations could either be genotypic variations (difference in genetic makeup) or phenotypic variations (different traits). The difference that exists between progeny and parents is known as variation.
The physical expression or appearance of a character is called as:

The physical appearance of a character is called as phenotype. It is defined as the physical expression of a trait or character of an individual. The phenotype is determined by both their genomic makeup( genotype) and environmental factors. Example: The tallness of a pea plant is a physical expression of an individual.
The alternate forms of a gene is called:

The alternate forms of a gene are called alleles. An allele is a variant form of a gene. Some genes have a variety of different forms, which are located at the same position, or genetic locus, on a chromosome. Humans are called diploid organisms because they have two alleles at each genetic locus, with one allele inherited from each parent.
Which of the following is not a correct statement with respect to DNA?

DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) is not a basic substance. It is a complex molecule composed of nucleotides, which are made up of a phosphate group, a sugar molecule (deoxyribose), and one of four nitrogenous bases (adenine, guanine, cytosine, or thymine). DNA is the hereditary material found in almost all living organisms and plays a fundamental role in genetic inheritance and protein synthesis. It was first identified by Friedrich Miescher in 1869.
The best method to determine the homozygous and heterozygous of an individual is:

Homozygous and heterozygous of an individual is determined by test cross method in which homozygous recessive is crossed with F1 hybrid individual.

The test cross is fundamental tool devised by Gregor Mendel. In its simplest form, a test cross is an experimental cross of an individual organism of dominant phenotype but unknown genotype and an organism with a homozygous recessive genotype (and phenotype).
Three different genera namely Solanum, Petunia and Datura are belongs to which family?

Families are characterized on the basis of both vegetative and reproductive features of plant species.

Among plants for example, three different genera Solanum, Petunia and Datura are placed in the family Solanaceae. 

Among animals for example, genus Panthera, comprising lion, tiger, and leopard are put along with genus, Felis(cats) in the family Felidae.
Which taxonomical aid preserves the specimens of various plants and animals in a preservative solution?

Biological museums are generally set up in educational institutions. Museums have a collection of preserved plants and animal specimens for study and reference. They preserve specimens in the container or jar in a preservative solution.
A pair of contrasting characters in a key is:

The contrasting characters in a key which are generally in a pair is called couplet. It represents the choice made between two opposite options.

Couplet is a pair of contrasting characters used as a tool for identification key to help in identification of a newly discovered organism.
The epithet of 'Darwin of 20th century' was bestowed to:
Ernst Mayr is known as Darwin of 20th century. He is known as he contributed a lot to the science. He was a leading evolutionary biologist in his time. He prompted and dispersed Darwin's Hypotheses.
Choose the correct sentence from the following:
Angiosperms can be classified into two orders
Human beings are members of primata family

Mangoes belong to genus Mangifera which consists of about 30 species of tropical fruiting trees in the flowering plant family Anacardiaceae.

Diptera is the order of housefly.

Human beings are members of Hominidae family.
Which of the following taxonomic rank contain organisms most similar to one another?

Species is the lowest category aming given options. As we go higher taxonomic rank of classification like class to a lower one like species, common features of organisms increases. 

Genus includes the various related species, family includes various related genus, order includes various related families and class includes various related orders.
Which of the following character forms the basis of Order polemoniales?

Floral characters form the basis of Order polemoniales.

It is a large order of dicotyledonous herbs, shrubs, or trees having flowers with the stamens adnate to the corolla lobes and a single superior compound ovary.

Plant families Convolvulaceae and Solanaceae are included in the order Polemonials based on the floral characters.
Which of the following sentences gives strength to the sentence that reproduction cannot be the all defining characteristic of living beings?

Reproduction cannot be an all-inclusive defining characteristic of living organisms.

There are many organisms which do not reproduce like mules, sterile worker bees and infertile human couples, etc.

Organisms reproduce by asexual means like bacteria, Amoeba, etc.
A metabolic reaction can be said to be non-living when?

An isolated metabolic reactions that happen outside the body of an organism which is performed in a test tube is neither living or non-living.

Metabolic reactions cannot happen in a cell-free system. While isolated in-vitro reactions carried out in laboratories cannot be termed as metabolism because they are conducted in a controlled environment and are simulated. But such reactions can be termed as living reactions because they are the reactions going on inside a living system.
Variety of organisms existing on the earth, their interrelationships and their relationship with the environment is called as:

Biodiversity is the variation in living organisms from all sources such as terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. It also involves the interaction of the biotic and abiotic factors with each other. Biodiversity is responsible for maintenance of balance in the ecosystem.
'Systema Naturae' by Carl Linnaeus was about?
Grouping of organisms into categories based on observable characters.

'Systema Naturae' by Carl Linnaeus showed evolutionary relationships among organisms.

In his book “Systema Naturae” (1735), Carl Linnaeus gave the hierarchical system of classification of the natural world into the plant kingdom, the animal kingdom and mineral kingdom. He understood the importance of floral characters and classified plants based on the number of stamens present in them. It is also known as the sexual system of classification.
Which of the following is a specific epithet?

According to rules of binomial nomenclature first word in the scientific name is the generic name (represents genus ) and it starts with capital initial. The second word is specific epithet which starts with a small initial. 

Only Option C follows these rules.

Note that option A seems like a correct option but it has exchanged a generic name and specific epithet. The correct name for mango is 'Mangifera indica'.

The International Code of Botanical Nomenclature (ICBN) is the set of rules and recommendations dealing with the formal botanical names that are given to plants. Its intent is that each taxonomic group ("taxon", plural "taxa") of plants has only one correct name, accepted worldwide.
ICBN is the code for naming of?

ICBN stands for International Code of Botanical Nomenclature. This organisation has the following roles, - It sets the recommendations and rules for formal botanical names which are given to the plant. - It ensures that there is a single accepted name given to every plant.
In which of the following taxon, are dogs and cats grouped together?

Dogs and cats are grouped together in order.

Cats and dogs are part of the same group at five levels: both are in the domain Eukarya, the kingdom Animalia, the phylum Chordata, the class Mammalia, and the order Carnivora.
Which of the following sentence is true about Sequoia dendron?
It has the heaviest wood in India.
It has the heaviest wood in world.

"It has wood without resin" sentence is true about Sequoiadendron.

  • Sequoiadendron is a genus of evergreen trees, with two species, only one of which survives to the present: Sequoiadendron giganteum, extant, commonly known as wellingtonia, giant redwood and giant sequoia, growing naturally in the Sierra Nevada of California.
  • Giant sequoias grow to an average height of 250 to 275 feet (76-84 m) and 15 to 20 feet (5-7 m) d.b.h. 
  • Giant sequoia regenerates primarily by seed, although occasionally it may reproduce naturally by vegetative methods.  Giant sequoias up to about 20 years of age may produce stump sprouts subsequent to injury. Giant sequoia of all ages may sprout from the bole when old branches are lost to fire or breakage.
Elaters for seed dispersal are present in:

Elaters for seed dispersal are present in liverworts.

Marchantia is a liverwort. Its sporophyte contains elongated cells with spiral thickenings on its wall called elaters. These elaters are hygroscopic in nature. The resulting twisting movement helps in dispersal of spores.

The manoxylic wood is found in pines. The wood is formed by one ring due to the presence of persistent cambium. In this wood, the pith and cortex are broad, wood is soft, parenchyma is broad, and cambium is short lived.
Which of the following genera consists of parasitic algae?

Cephaleuros is a genus of parasitic thalloid algae comprising approximately 14 species. Its common name is red rust. Specimens can reach around 10 mm in size. Dichotomous branches are formed. The alga is parasitic on some important economic plants of the tropics and subtropics such as tea, coffee, mango and guava causing damage limited to the area of algal growth on leaves (algal leaf spot), or killing new shoots or disfiguring fruit. Members of the genera may also grow with a fungus to form a lichen that does not damage the plants.
Production of spores of two different sizes and sexes by the sporophytes of land plants is termed as:

The production of spores of two different sizes and sexes by the sporophytes of land plants is known as ‘Heterospory’, could be a development during which 2 styles of spores square measure borne by the identical plant. The smaller one is understood as a spore and therefore the larger one is understood as a macrospore. The spore germinates to create the male plant life and therefore the macrospore germinates to create the feminine plant life. The male plant life releases the male gametes and these reach the feminine plant life to fuse with the egg. The event of the fertilized ovum takes place within the feminine plant life.

This retention and germination of the macrospore among the sporangium guarantee correct development of the fertilized ovum. The fertilized ovum develops into longer-term plant life. The evolution of the seed habit is expounded to the retention of the macrospore.

Heterospory is thought of as a very important step in evolution because it could be a precursor to the seed habit.
Pollen grain of Cycas are shed at stage of:

Pollen grain is the first cell of the gametophyte. The microspore germinates in situ i.e., while within the microsporangium. Each microspore divides asymmetrically into a 2-cells: a smaller prothallial cell and a larger antheridialcell. The prothallial cell does not divide further while the antheridial cell divides into a smaller generative cell near the prothallial cell and a larger tube cell. Finally pollination takes place at 3-celled stage.
Phylloglossum is a small plant superficially resembling a tiny grass plant. It is closely related to genus _______.

Phylloglossum is a small plant superficially resembling a tiny grass plant. It is closely related to genus Huperzia.

Huperzia is a genus of lycophyte plants, sometimes known as the firmosses or fir clubmosses; the Flora of North America calls them gemma fir-mosses.[2] This genus was originally included in the related genus Lycopodium, from which it differs in having undifferentiated sporangial leaves, and the sporangia not formed into apical cones. The common name firmoss, used for some of the north temperate species, refers to their superficial resemblance to branches of fir (Abies), a conifer.
develop on the new shoots after injury

Scale leaves in genus Pinus are brown, non-green and small.

In pinus, two types of leaves are formed by normally foliage leaves and scaly leaves.

  1. Scaly leaves: a scalelike structure that is morphologically a leaf often reduced in size (as a bud scale, various bracts, or the leaves of various conifers)
  2. Foliage leaves: an ordinary green leaf as distinguished from floral leaves, scales, and bracts.
The scientist(s) who gave artificial system of classification is/are:

The artificial system of classification is given by Carolus Linnaeus. He is also known as the father of systematic botany. He established the artificial system based on the exclusive characters of flowers.

Under this system of classification the flowering plants are classified into 24 classes on the basis of their floral as well as morphological characters.

Some of these includes:

  • The nature of anther and filaments.
  • The arrangement of anther and filament on a flower.
  • The number of stamens present in a flower.
  • On the basis of addition and Cohesion arrangement.
The neck canal cells are absent in the archegonia of:

During the development of archegonium in Cycas, 2-8 archegonia develop at the micropylar end of the female gametophyte. All the necks of archegonia open into an archegonial chamber formed by a depression in female gametophyte. Each archegonium develops from a single superficial cell called archegonial initial. It gets enlarged and divides transversally into outer primary neck cell and inner central cell. The primary neck cell divides anticlinally to form two neck cells. The inner central cell enlarges and its nucleus divides into venter canal nucleus afcnd egg nucleus. Soon the venter canal nucleus disorganises. Thus, a mature archegonium has two neck cells and an egg. Neck canal cells are not formed.
Cleavage polyembryony is seen in which tier of Pinus zygote?

Cleavage polyembryony is seen in the embryonal tier of the Pinus zygote.

The cells of the embryonal tier divide further into proximal secondary suspensors, which split apart, and four distal embryos are formed. Because of the splitting process this type of polyembryony is called “cleavage polyembryony”.
Sulphur shower is a phenomenon exhibited by:

The sulphur shower is a phenomenon exhibited by Pine trees.

As the pollen cones mature, they discharge large quantities of pollen grains into the air and it appears as a yellow cloud of yellow of winged pollen grains. This is called Sulphur Shower and occurs during spring. Pollen grains are released and carried by wind to the female cones.
In Funaria, stomata are present on the:

In Funaria, stomata are present on the Apophysis.

The mature sporophyte in Funaria is distinguishable into foot, seta and capsule. The capsule is distinguished into opercular region theca region and apophyseal region Apophyseal region is lowermost part of the capsule. The epidermis of the apophyseal region has stomatal aparrures. Each stoma has two guard cells which at later stages fuse to form a single annular guard cell.
Angiosperms are similar to gymnosperms with respect to:

Gymnosperms are the non-flowering plants that produce naked seeds. The angiosperms have plant parts including the leaves, stems, and roots. The plant parts of gymnosperms are also the same as the angiosperms which include the leaves, stems, and roots. Gymnosperms produce naked seeds with no outer covering.
In Selaginella, glassopodium is found in:

In Selaginella, glossopodium is found in ligules.

The ligule is a water-absorbing structure that helps in keeping the leaf and sporangium moist. The ligule is made up of vacuolated cells which are elongated.

Selaginella is found in the tropical regions of the world. Few species are found in the arctic-alpine zones. It is a creeping plant with simple and scale-like leaves on the branching stem. The roots arise from the branching stem. The stem is aerial and creeping horizontally or erect or sub erect on the substratum.
The correct sequence of meninges from outer to the inner side is:

The correct sequence of meninges from outer to the inner side is dura mater- arachnoid mater- pia mater.

The outer layer of the meninges is called the dura mater. It is tough and thick and it can restrict the movement of the brain within the skull. This protects the brain from movements that may stretch and break brain blood vessels. The middle layer of the meninges is called the arachnoid. The inner layer, the one closest to the brain, is called as the pia mater.
Which of the following is not an ear ossicle?

Humerus is not an ear ossicle.

The ossicles (also called auditory ossicles) are three bones in either middle ear that are among the smallest bones in the human body. They serve to transmit sounds from the air to the fluid-filled labyrinth (cochlea). It refers to the malleus, the incus and the stapes of the middle ear. 

The humerus is a long bone in the arm or forelimb that runs from the shoulder to the elbow. It connects the scapula and the two bones of the lower arm, which consists of the radius and ulna.
The dorsal root of spinal cord contains ________.

The dorsal root of spinal cord contains Somatic sensory fibres.

A posterior root ganglion (spinal ganglion) (also known as a dorsal root ganglion), is a cluster of nerve cell bodies (a ganglion) in a posterior root of a spinal nerve. The axons of posterior root ganglion neurons are known as afferents. The posterior root ganglia lie along the vertebral column by the spine. The nerve endings of posterior root ganglion neurons have a variety of sensory receptors that are activated by mechanical, thermal, chemical, and noxious stimuli.

Thus, dorsal root ganglia contain cell bodies of sensory neurons. Axons of these sensory neurons travel into the spinal cord via the dorsal roots.
The part of the brain where the centre for hunger and thirst is ;located is:

The cerebrum is the uppermost part of the brain.It is also called the telencephalon and it is the largest part of the brain.The cerebrum develops prenatally from the forebrain.The cerebrum is divided into two cerebral hemispheres – left and right.The cerebrum controls reading, learning, thinking, speech, emotions, and planned muscle movements such as walking.This part also controls the vision, hearing and other senses.
Which of the following forms the cerebrospinal fluid?

Choroid plexus forms the cerebrospinal fluid.

Thin transparent pia mater is situated close to the surface of the brain and spinal cord. In both places, the pia mater merges with the thin dorsal surface of the brain, forming the choroid plexus.

 Let’s first understand about all the options given above

The brain is surrounded by three membranes called Meninges these are Dura mater, Arachnoid mater and pia mater.

The outer dura mater is the hard, white membrane under the skull.

Intermediate arachnoid layer with fibrous tissue.

Multipolar nerve cells are present in brain.

Multipolar neurons are found in the brain and spinal cord. they have more than 2 dendrites and an axon. The Cochlea and retina have bipolar neurons whereas dorsal root ganglia have pseudounipolar neurons ie. they have single axon with 2 branches a proximal one and a distal one

So, the correct answer is 'Brain'
Which of the following is a neurotransmitter released exclusively into the neuromuscular synapse?

Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter released exclusively into the neuromuscular synapse.

Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter released into a neuromuscular synapse. It conveys the signal from the brain to the muscles resulting in an effector response. Usually, neurotransmitters are released into the synaptic cleft and they stimulate the adjacent dendrite and new electric impulses are formed. Dopamine, epinephrine and norepinephrine are examples of such neurotransmitters.
The damage to ear by sudden explosion (loud sound) is prevented by:

The damage prevented by: Eustachian tubes, Tensor tympani muscles, Stapedius muscles.

Tensor tympani are the muscles located in the ear above the osseous portion of the auditory tube. The role of these muscles are to dampen the sound or vibrations produced by chewing. Thus, the muscles are involved in the reduction of the perceived amplitude of sounds. The stapedius muscles are similar in function to the tympani muscles. They reduce the amount of sound entering the inner ear. The function of these muscles along with the eustachian tube is to protect the internal ear form loud noises.
The part of the brain where the centre for hunger and thirst is ;located is __________.

The part of the brain where the centre for hunger and thirst is ;located is Hypothalamus.

HypothalamusHypothalamus is the small region of the brain.The hypothalamus is located at the base of the brain near the pituitary gland.Hypothalamus plays a crucial role in many important functions such as releasing hormones, regulating body temperature, maintaining daily physiological cycles, controlling appetite and thirst, managing sexual behavior, regulating emotional responses, etc.
Choose the incorrect statement for Autonomic nervous system:
Consists of ganglia formed by pre and post ganglionic neurons
Consists of sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous system

Incorrect statement for Autonomic nervous system Acts on skeletal muscles.

The autonomic neural system controls and coordinates involuntary activities of various organs. It transmits impulses from the CNS to the involuntary organs and smooth muscles of the body. The autonomic neural system is further classified into sympathetic neural system and parasympathetic neural system.
Rods contain visual purple or rhodopsin. When light falls on rhodopsin, it is ________.

Rods contain visual purple or rhodopsin. When light falls on rhodopsin, it is bleached.

Opsins are the light-sensitive proteins of rods. Binding of opsin to retinal (a chromophore) makes rhodopsin which serves as a visual purple pigment of rod cells. Bright light causes breakdown of rhodopsin into opsin and retinal thereby making it bleach out.
In mammals, the ___________ connects the limbic system to other parts of the brain.

In mammals, the epithalamus connects the limbic system to other parts of the brain.

The function of the epithalamus is to connect the limbic system to other parts of the brain. Some functions of its components include the secretion of melatonin and secretion of hormones from the pituitary gland by the pineal gland circadian rhythms), and regulation of motor pathways and emotions.
If a person has lost his memory in an accident, which of the following part of the brain have gotten injured?

If a person has lost his memory in an accident that means the cerebrum has gotten injured. 

The cerebrum or cortex is the largest part of the human brain, associated with the higher brain function such as thought and action. 

The cerebrum is divided into four regions called lobes that control senses, thoughts, and movements. The four lobes are the occipital, temporal, frontal, and parietal lobes. 

Although each lobe has a different task to perform, they all must work together.
There are how many pairs of cranial nerves in a human?

Pairs of cranial nerves in a human is 12.

Cranial and spinal nerves are part of peripheral nervous system. The 12 pairs of cranial nerves are part of peripheral nervous system and are mostly concentred with head, neck and facial region of the body (vagus nerve X being the part of autonomous division serves as an exception). These are namely olfactory, optic, vestibulocochlear, vagus, oculomotor, trochlear, abducens, spinal accessory, trigeminal, facial, glossopharyngeal and hypoglossal nerves. Spinal nerves are attached to spinal cord. There are total 31 spinal nerves which are grouped as cervical (C1 to C8), thoracic (T1 to T12), lumber (L1 to L5), sacral (S1 to S5), and coccygeal nerves (C1).
The term 'bag of worms' is associated with the damage of ____________.

The term 'bag of worms' is associated with the damage of oculomotor nerve.

The hypoglossal nerve is one of 12 cranial nerves. It's also known as the 12th cranial nerve, cranial nerve 12 or CNXII. This nerve starts at the base of your brain. It travels down your neck and branches out, ending at the base and underside of your tongue.
Nissl’s grains are mainly present in cyton and dendrite. These granules are rough endoplasmic reticulum with rosettes of free ribosome, the site for protein synthesis. It is absent in axon.
In the prosencephalon, first and second ventricles open into third ventricle by :
In prosencephlon, the first and second ventricles open into third ventricles by foramen of Monro. It is the opening that connects the left and right sides of lateral ventricle in brain.
The property which doesn’t belong to nerve fibres is :
Nerve fibres are specialized to transmit impulses form one part of the body to other. Nerve fibres do not shows the property of elasticity and contractility.
Hypothalamus helps to maintain homeostasis by controlling hunger, thirst, blood pressure, temperature feelings etc. So it is an important link between

One of the most important functions of the hypothalamus is to link the nervous system to the endocrine system via the pituitary gland (hypophysis). The hypothalamus is located below the thalamus and is part of the limbic system
Brain stem is the support system of brain and is the collective name for :

The brainstem (or brain stem) is the posterior part of the brain, adjoining and structurally continuous with the spinal cord. In the human brain the brainstem includes the midbrain, the pons, and the medulla oblongata. Sometimes the diencephalon, the caudal part of the forebrain, is included.
Motor neuron carry impulse from CNS to effector. Axon carry impulse away from cyton. Afferent neuron carry impulse from receptor to CNS and dendrite carry impulsetowards cyton.
Complete the following hierarchical chart showing parts of nervous system :
