Human nervous system consists of central nervous system and peripheral nervous system. Peripheral nervous system includes 12 pairs of cranial nerves emerging from brain and 31 pairs of spinal nerves arising from spinal nerve.

In the following figure a synapse is shown :

i & ii (from up to down)

1) (i) is presynaptic membrane and (ii) is postsynaptic membrane. 

2) synaptic vesicles are in postsynaptic knob.

3) neurotransmitter receptors are located on postsynaptic membrane.

The synapse is formed by the membranes of apre-synaptic neuron and a post-synaptic neuron, which may or may notbe separated by a gap called synaptic cleft. The neurotransmitter receptors are located on postsynaptic membrane.
Due to refractory period , a nerve fibre in human body on an average transmits about :
Refractory period is the time taken to nerve become ready to conduct other impulse. Due to this refractory period, a nerve fibre in human body on an average transmits about 1000 impulses per seconds.

Read the following about the surface of cerebral hemispheres

i. Is made up of the pia matter.

ii. Is greatly convoluted and called the cerebral cortex.
Statement i) is correct and ii) is wrong.
Statement i) is wrong and ii) is correct.
The layer of cells which covers the cerebral hemisphere is called cerebral cortex and is thrown into prominent folds.

The autonomic nervous system or ANS :

i. Is truly autonomic i.e. independent of the CNS.

ii. Is also known as the VNS.

iii. Transmit impulse from CNS to involuntary organs and smooth muscles.

The autonomic nervous system or ANS is the division of peripheral nervous system that influences the function of internal organs. ANS is also known as VNS. These nerves transmit impulse from CNS to involuntary organs and smooth muscles.
Label the arrows in the given diagram of brain from top to bottom :
The part of human brain shown above has marked as cerebellum, pons and medulla oblongata of hind brain.
The band of nerve fibers that joins the two cerebral hemisphere in mammals is :
The corpus callosum (CC) is the largest of the commissural fibres, linking the cerebral cortex of the left and right cerebral hemisphere.
Cerebral vermis is located in the medial, cortico-nuclear zone of the cerebellum. It is constricted between lobe of cerebellum.
The retina contains which of the following neural cells?

The retina contains neural cells Ganglion cells, Photoreceptor cells, Bipolar cells.

The retina is contained of three layers of neural cells that are located from inside to outside in the order of - ganglion cells, bipolar cells and photoreceptor cells. The photoreceptor cells are further classified into two types - rods and cones.
Which of the following is/are not associated with the human male reproductive system?

Bartholin glands is not associated with the human male reproductive system.

The male reproductive system is mostly located outside of the body. These external organs include the penis, scrotum and testicles. Internal organs include the vas deferens, prostate and urethra. The male reproductive system is responsible for sexual function, as well as urination.
Which of the following is the most anteriorly placed structure in the female perineum?

Mons pubis is the most anteriorly placed structure in the female perineum.

The mons pubis is the coarse hair-bearing prominent area of skin and fatty tissue overlaying the symphysis pubis and other pubic bones that is bounded superiorly by the pubic hairline and inferiorly by the clitoris.
What are the cysts containing sticky gel-like substance in an ovary called?

The cysts containing sticky gel-like substance in an ovary is called cystadenomas.

Ovarian cystadenomas are common benign epithelial neoplasms which carry an excellent prognosis. The two most frequent types of cystadenomas are serous and mucinous cystadenomas whereas endometrioid and clear cell cystadenomas are rare.
Which placenta is found in guinea pigs and rats?

Hemochorial placentation is found in guinea pigs and rats.

The rat possesses hemochorial placentation with deep intrauterine trophoblast cell invasion and trophoblast-directed uterine spiral artery remodeling; features shared with human placentation. Recognition of these similarities spurred the establishment of in vitro and in vivo research methods using the rat as an animal model to address mechanistic questions regarding development of the hemochorial placenta. The purpose of this review is to provide the requisite background to help move the rat to the forefront in placentation research.
In which of the following stages of vaginal birth does the head of embryo turn through 45 degrees?

In Restitution stage of vaginal birth, the head of embryo turns through 45 degrees in the stage of restitution.

Restitution: This is the spontaneous realignment of the head with the shoulders. The fetal head turns through 45 degrees to restore its normal relationship with the shoulders, which are still at an angle.
Which of the following hormones attains a peak level in the middle of the menstrual cycle (around the 14th day)?

LH hormones attains a peak level in the middle of the menstrual cycle.

The level of different hormones control the processes and phases in the menstrual cycle. The level of LH is at the highest level at the middle of the menstrual cycle. This occurs during the follicular phase when the FSH acts on the follicle leading to their development as Graafian follicle and then ovulation occurs due to increased level of LH.

The females of placental mammals exhibit cyclical changes in the activities of ovaries and accessory ducts as well as hormones during the reproductive phase. What is this process called in non-primate mammals?

Oestrus cycle is the period in the sexual cycle of female mammals, except the higher primates, during which they are in heat—i.e., ready to accept a male and to mate. One or more periods of estrus may occur during the breeding season of a species.

Clupein protein is found in human sperms.

It is highly basic arginine rich protein that replaces histones in sperm heads enabling DNA to pack in an extremely compacted form.
Trophoblast cells in contact with embryonal knob are called:

Trophoblast cells in contact with embryonal knob are called cells of rauber.

'Cells of Rauber' are trophoblast cells that are in contact with the inner mass of blastocyst. They are in contact with embryos and when the developing embryo reaches the uterine cavity after five to six days of fertilization, it is called blastocyst. A blastocyst is usually made up of a hundred cells.

Estradiol is secreted by:

A.Theca interna

B.Graafian follicle

C.Primary follicle

D.Theca externa

Estradiol is secreted by graafian follicle and theca externa.

The graafian follicle is a fluid filled cavity which is present adjacent to the oocyte. It contains Granulosa and theca cells which continuously divide. It produces estrogen. The production of estrogen requires both the cells of the theca interna and granulosa cells.

The theca externa is a connective tissue layer derived from fibroblast-like cells that produce extracellular matrix factors, such as collagen. The theca interna and externa also contain a rich supply of blood vessels called the vascular tissue that brings nutrients, oxygen, and immune cells to the growing follicles.
In mammals, decidua basalis is a part of:

In mammals, decidua basalis is a part of placenta.

The maternal component of the placenta is known as the decidua basalis. It is cast off when the placenta is expelled. The thickened superficial endometrial layers become the decidua.
Role of corpus luteum if fertilisation of the egg occurs is:

Role of corpus luteum if fertilisation of the egg occurs is retention of pregnancy.

If the egg gets fertilized, corpus luteum will release progesterone for about 12 weeks. Around week 12 in first trimester of pregnancy, the organ that holds the developing fetus (placenta) will start to produce enough progesterone for the fetus so that the corpus luteum doesn't need to anymore.
If the inguinal canal fails to close, it will lead to:

If the inguinal canal fails to close, it will lead to hernia.

An indirect hernia occurs when the inguinal canal fails to completely close during fetal development, leaving an opening for abdominal contents to protrude through the defect.
Which of the following events is affected by the presence and distribution of yolk in the egg?

Pattern of cleavage is affected by the presence and distribution of yolk in the egg.

Absence of yolk (as in human egg) results in cleavage of entire egg into equal or unequal blastomeres and is referred to as equal (sea cucumber) or unequal holoblastic (amphibians) cleavage. Presence of yolk allows cleavage of yolk free region of egg only which is termed as meroblastic cleavage.
Which of the following female reproductive organs is homologouos to penis in males?

Female clitoris is homologouos to penis in males.

They are responsible for the orgasm experienced by one during coitus. In males, the growth of the penis occurs rapidly. It leads to the formation of the penile shaft and then to the penile raphe. In females, it is noted that growth occurs rather less rapidly which leads to the formation of a small clitoris. In females, the urethral folds do not fuse as in males, which leads to the formation of labia minora.
The living organism can be unexceptionally differ from non-living on the basis of:

The living organism can be unexceptionally differ from non-living on the basis of reproduction.

The living and non-living shows a number of different features including respiration, nutrition, growth and stimulus but reproduction is most distinctive feature to classify into living and non-living.
Most of animals are unisexual but a few are bisexual too as:

Most of the animals are unisexual but earthworms are bisexual.

Most of animals possess either male or female reproductive organs, so they are unisexual except earthworm that contains both male and female reproductive parts in same individual.
Genetic variation is created and inherited during:

During sexual reproduction, gamete carrying different genetic combination unit together and variation in offspring is created that is inherited from generation to next generation.

Genetic variation is increased by meiosis.

Recombination or crossing over occurs during prophase I. Homologous chromosomes – 1 inherited from each parent – pair along their lengths, gene by gene. Breaks occur along the chromosomes, and they rejoin, trading some of their genes.
When two parents participate in reproductive process and also involve fusion of their gametes, it is called:

When two parents participate in reproductive process and also involve fusion of their gametes, it is called sexual reproduction.

In sexual reproduction male and female gametes are produced by male and female organism. The fusion of gametes results into zygote formation that finally develops as new offspring.

The life span of parrot is about 140 years. 

It is much more than other common animals living in our surrounding. Even more than human being life span. Life span is the period from birth to death. Small parrots, such as lovebirds, hanging parrots, and budgies, have shorter lifespans up to 15–20 years. Major Mitchell's cockatoo is a oldest living parrot.
The endometrium in female is the lining of:

The innermost lining of uterus is called endometrium. 

It is spongy layer that breakdown during menstrual cycle along with mucus through vagina. Its functions to prevent adhesions between the opposed walls of the myometrium, thereby maintaining the patency of the uterine cavity. During the menstrual cycle or estrous cycle, the endometrium grows to a thick, blood vessel-rich, glandular tissue layer.
The opening of vagina is often covered partially by a membrane called:

Vagina is partially covered by a membrane called hymen. 

The hymen is generally torn during first coitus. It may be also broken due to active participation in sports like cycling and horse riding. Hymen is a piece of tissue covering or surrounding part of vaginal opening. It's formed during development and present during birth. It thins over time and tears. Some people will feel pain or bleed when their hymen breaks, but most will not notice.
Which of the followings are called dual gland?

Testis and ovary are called as dual gland as they perform two functions. They release gametes and also secretes hormone.

The gonads, the primary reproductive organs, are the testes in the male and the ovaries in the female. These organs are responsible for producing the sperm and ova, but they also secrete hormones and are considered to be endocrine glands.
The part of fallopian tube closest to ovary is:

The part of fallopian tube closest to ovary is infundibulum.

Fallopian tube or oviduct of human female is divided into three parts, Infundibulum, ampulla and isthmus. The infundibulum is closet to ovary.
Prostate gland and  Seminal vesicle perform the function of:
Nutrition and fluid medium for sperm movement

Prostate gland and seminal vesicle perform the function of penetration of ovum.

Seminal vesicle and the prostate glands add their secretions so that the sperm is in a fluid state that makes their transport easier and provides nutrition.
Biradial symmetry and lack of cnidoblasts are the characteristics of:

Biradial symmetry and lack of cnidoblasts are the characteristics of Ctenolana and Beroe.

Biradial symmetry and lack of cnidoblasts are the characteristics of Ctenoplana and Beroe. They both belong to phylum- Ctenophora. They are called comb-bearers and comb-jellies. The external surface of the body bears eight median comb plates. They are biradial symmetrical animals. Cnidoblasts are absent in the ctenophores.
Classification of phylum Porifera is based upon:

Porifera is the phylum composed of the sponges. Their body is composed of any minute pores. The classification of phylum Porifera is based upon the spicules. They are divided into 3 classes:

1. The class Calcarea contains the organisms in which the skeleton is made up of calcareous spicules. e.g., Leucosolenia

2. The class Hexactinellida contains the organisms in which the skeleton contains six rays of siliceous spicules. e.g., Euplectella

3. The class Demospongiae contains the organisms in which the skeleton is either absent or present. The skeleton contains spongin fibres or silicious spicules or both. e.g., Oscarella
In which one of the following sets of animals do all the four give birth to young ones?

Kangaroo, Hedgehog, Dolphin, Loris animals do all the four give birth to young ones.

Birds and mammals are animals adapted for the terrestrial mode of life. All birds lay eggs, both flight as well as nonflight like Kiwi, Penguin and Ostrich. Mammals are characterised by the presence of mammary gland and placenta. They produce young one and nourishes them through mammary gland e.g., kangaroo, hedgehog, lion, cat, bat, loris etc. Platypus is a primitive egg-laying mammal, dolphin and whale are young one producing or aquatic mammal.
Two common characters found in centipede, cockroach and crab are:

Two common characters found in centipede, cockroach and crab are Jointed legs and chtinous exoskeleton.

They all belong to the phylum Arthropoda( Joint appendages).

1. Appendages - Some or all the segments bear appendages. The appendages are jointed. It is variously modified for feeding, walking, jumping, swimming, clinging, sensory reception, copulation and defence.

2. Body wall- The body wall consists of a thick, chitinous cuticle and a single layered epidermis. The hard cuticle restricts growth and is periodically changed during growth. The process is called moulting or ecdysis.

Madreporite is associated with Water vascular system.

The madreporite is a lightcolored calcareous opening used to filter water into the water vascular system of echinoderms. 

It acts like a pressure-equalizing valve. The water vascular system of the sea star consists of a series of seawater-filled ducts that function in locomotion and feeding and respiration. 

Its main parts are the madreporite, the stone canal, the ring canal, the radial canals, the lateral canals, and the tube feet. 

The sieve-like madreporite allows entry of seawater into the stone canal, which connects to the ring canal around the mouth.
A flagellated cavity in coelenteron of all cnidarians

Siphonoglyph is Flagellated groove in gullet of Metridium.

Siphonoglyph is flagellated groove in the gullet of Metridium. It is a longitudinal flagellated chamber which is found in most of the cnidarians in the classes Scyphozoa and Anthozoa. The siphonoglyph is a ciliated groove at one or both ends of the mouth of sea anemones and some corals. The siphonoglyph extends into a pharynx and is used to create currents of water into the pharynx. These water currents are important for respiration and maintenance of internal pressure. The presence of a siphonoglyph (or two siphonoglyphs) in several anthozoans  introduces an element of bilateral symmetry into the particular species' body plan.

Skeleton of sponge is Endoskeleton.

The sponges possess an endoskeleton in the form calcareous spicules (made up of calcium carbonate), siliceous spicules (made up of silica) and spongin fibres. Since there are no visceral organs in the skeleton of sponges, their skeleton can not be categorised into external or internal category.
In some animal groups, the body is found divided into compartments with serial repetition of at least some organs. This characteristic feature is called:

Some animal groups, the body is found divided into compartments with serial repetition of at least some organs. This  feature is called Metamerism.

In some animals, the body is externally and internally divided into segments with a serial repetition of at least some organs. For example, in earthworm, the body shows this pattern called metameric segmentation and the phenomenon is known as metamerism or true segmentation. Metamerism is found in 3 animal phylums-Annelida, Arthropoda and Chordata.

The body wall of hydra is Monoblastic.

Hydra belongs to the phylum Cnidaria. They are diploblastic in nature i.e, they have two body layers. an outer layer called epidermis and an inner layer called the gastrodermis which lines the stomach and in between is a gel-like substance called mesoglea.

A free living roundworm is Strongyloides stercoralis Rhabditis Loa

Free-living worm species do not live on land, but instead, live in marine or freshwater environments, or underground by burrowing. Free living organisms are not directly dependent on another organism for survival whereas parasitic organisms are directly dependent on other organisms for their survival.

Strongyloides stercoralis is a unique nematode having both parasitic and free-living cycles rhabditis bovis are tiny nematodes that spend their entire life cycle in the ear. These animals are free living.

In most of the invertebrates, the excretory structures are simple tubular forms whereas vertebrates have complex tubular organs called kidneys. Shark is a vertebrate and has kidneys as excretory structures.

Protonephridia or flame cells are the excretory structures in Platyhelminthes (Flatworms, e.g., Planaria), rotifers, some annelids and the cephalochordate Amphioxus. Protonephridia are primarily concerned with ionic and fluid volume regulation, i.e., osmoregulation.

Which of the following do not support coevolution?

Coevolution describes the cases when two or more species reciprocally influence each other's evolution. Coevolution is likely to occur when different species have close ecological interactions with each other. These ecological relationships include:

1. Predator-prey and parasite-host relationships

2. Competitive species relationships

3. Mutualistic species relationships

4. Commensalism

Mutualism is the relationship between two or more species in which all are benefitted by one other.

Parasitism is the interaction between two individuals where the parasite gets the benefit at the expense of the host.

Commensalism is the relationship between two different organisms where one is always benefitted and other is neither benefitted nor harmed. 

So all the options given in the question support the coevolution.
Why do humans and chimpanzees share 98% of their genomes?
Because humans inherited genomes from chimpanzees
Because they have a common ancestor

Human and chimp DNA is so similar because the two species are so closely related. Humans, chimps and bonobos descended from a single ancestor species that lived six or seven million years ago. As humans and chimps gradually evolved from a common ancestor, their DNA, passed from generation to generation, changed too.
In which period did the first mammals appear?

The first Mammals appeared on earth long before the extinction of dinosaurs. In early years, dinosaurs and mammals existed together in the late Triassic about 200 million years ago. The first mammals appeared in the late Triassic age. So, option (A) is correct.

The Jurassic era also known as the age of reptiles which lasted for about 56 million years. During this period, the large reptile also known as dinosaurs existed. So, option (B) is incorrect.

Option C: The Cretaceous era was the period in which larger continents broke into smaller ones, causing land shift and remodeling the shape and tone of life on earth. During this era, the infamous Tyrannosaurus rex existed as well. No mammals existed during this period. So, option (C) is incorrect.

Option D: The tertiary (66 million years ago to present) is one of the two periods that exist in the Cenozoic era from 66 million years to 2.6 million years. The second one is called the quaternary period (2.6 million years ago to present). The mammals are more diversified and evolved in this period. So, option (D) is incorrect.

Thus, the correct answer is option (A) Triassic.
Experiment to prove that synthesis of organic compound formed the basis of life was performed by:

Man has always been curious about how this world has been formed and also about the existence of life on our Earth. As far as the origin of life is considered, it has remained the curiosity for intellectuals at all times. Despite advancements in various fields like biochemistry, astrobiology, geography, molecular biology, etc. scientists are unable to ascertain the truth. Various theories and hypotheses have been proposed to find the probable answer to this question.

Stanley L.Miller and his teacher Harold C.Urey provided the first experimental evidence in support of the chemical evolution theory of Oparin. They designed a glass-apparatus called spark-discharge apparatus.

Two genetically different organisms show similar adaptations due to:

The organs which are different anatomically but similar functionally are called analogous organs. Eg. Wings of butterflies & birds, Eyes of octopus & mammals, Flippers of penguins & dolphins. All these have different anatomical structures but they perform the same function like Wings of butterfly & birds differs in structure but both perform the function of flight.

Due to their same function, different structures evolve similarly. This is known as convergent evolution. In convergent evolution, the species of different ancestry start sharing analogous traits because of selection pressure or shared environment.

Thus two genetically different organisms like a bat & an insect having different skeletal structures adapt their wings to fly due to convergent evolution.

Who is popularly known as the father of Evolutionary Biology?

Evolutionary biology: It is a field of science that deals with the study of evolutionary processes like natural selection, speciation & common descent that has led to the diversification of life on earth.

Charles Darwin is known as the father of ''Evolutionary Biology''.

Darwin proposed a theory of evolution called natural selection in the year 1859. According to it those populations which are a better fit (reproductively fit) in an environment will be selected by nature and will survive more. Charles Darwin wrote a book named ''The origin of species'' which is considered to be the foundation of evolutionary biology.
In the context of biology, the term adaptive radiation refers to:
the process of evolution of different species in a given geographical area starting from a point and radiating to other habitats.
the process by which the species in different geographical areas adapt to similar conditions of solar insolation.
the part of Photosynthetically Active Radiation (PAR) that is utilized by the primary producers and is available to the herbivores.
the emergence of a dominant species due to extinction of other species as a result of harmful radiation in an area.

The process of evolution of different species in a given geographical area starting from a point and literally radiating to other areas of geography is called adaptive radiation. Hence, option 1 is correct.

Adaptive radiations are best exemplified in closely related groups that have evolved in a relatively short time.

A striking example is a radiation, beginning in the Paleogene Period (beginning 66 million years ago), of basal mammalian stock into forms adapted to running, leaping, climbing, swimming, and flying.

Other examples include Australian marsupials, cichlid fish, and Darwin’s finches (also known as Galapagos finches).

The phenomenon of adaptive radiation was first observed by Darwin when he travelled to a place called Galapagos Island.

There he observed that there were finches with different types of beaks. So, he concluded that all of these finches radiated on the same island from a single ancestor Finch. All of these finches developed beaks according to the kind of food available to them.

Hence, they evolved from conventional seed-eating finches to vegetarian and insectivorous finches. They later came to be known as Darwin’s finches.

Darwin's finches are a group of about fifteen species of passerine birds. They often are classified as the subfamily Geospizinae. It is still not clear to which bird family they belong, but they are not related to the true finches. They were first collected by Charles Darwin on the Galapagos Islands during the second voyage of the Beagle. All are found only on the Galapagos Islands, except the Cocos finch from Cocos Island. Darwin's finches are examples of adaptive radiation and divergent evolution.
Speciation is the formation of one or more new species from an existing species. A new species or organism is formed when?
A series of mutation occur so that an organism becomes different from the others in population, but it still shows successful interbreeding.
Climate changes drastically leading to structural changes in the given population.
A group of organisms isolated from the rest of the species by geographical barrier.

Speciation is the evolutionary process by which new biological species arise. The biologist Orator F. Cook was the first to coin the term 'speciation' for the splitting of lineages or "cladogenesis," as opposed to "anagenesis" or "phyletic evolution" occurring within lineages. Whether genetic drift is a minor or major contributor to speciation is the subject matter of much ongoing discussion.

There are four geographic modes of speciation in nature, based on the extent to which speciating populations are isolated from one another: allopatric, peripatric, parapatric and sympatric. Speciation may also be induced artificially, through animal husbandry, agriculture or laboratory experiments.

Which of the following theories are related to the evolution of life?

A. The theory of natural selection

B. Mutation theory of evolution

C. Theory of inheritance of acquired characteristics

D. Theory of segregation

The theory of evolution by natural selection, first formulated in Darwin's book "On the Origin of Species" in 1859.

It is the process by which organisms change over time as a result of changes in heritable physical or behavioural traits. Changes that allow an organism to better adapt to its environment will help it survive and have more offspring.

Hugo de Vries (1901) put forward a theory of evolution, called mutation theory.

The theory states that evolution is a jerky process where new varieties and species are formed by mutations (discontinuous variations) that function as the raw material of evolution.

Mutations or discontinuous variations are the raw material of evolution.

Mutations appear all of a sudden. They become operational immediately.

Unlike Darwin’s continuous variations or fluctuations, mutations do not revolve around the mean or normal character of the species.

The same type of mutations can appear in a number of individuals of a species.

All mutations are inheritable.

Mutations appear in all conceivable directions.

Lamarck is best known for his Theory of Inheritance of Acquired Characteristics, first presented in 1801 (Darwin's first book dealing with natural selection was published in 1859)

If an organism changes during life in order to adapt to its environment, those changes are passed on to its offspring.

Lamarck also said that body parts that are not being used, such as the human appendix and little toes are gradually disappearing. Eventually, people will be born without these parts.

Lamarck also believed that evolution happens according to a predetermined plan and that the results have already been decided.

The theory of segregation deals with the meiosis (cell division) of human and does not deal with the evolution of life. This theory is given by Mendel.
When comparing two animals, we can say they have analogous organs, if the organs ______.
perform different functions in both animals but are anatomically very similar
perform the same function in both animals but are anatomically very different
perform the same function in both animals

The correct answer is to perform the same function in both animals but is anatomically very different.

Homologous organs:

These organs are similar in origin and structure but perform different functions.

For example, the Forelimbs of frogs, lizards, bats, and humans have the same basic structural plan but different functions.

The wings help in flight whereas the human forearm helps in various activities.

Analogous organs:

These organs have similar functions but are different in structure and origin.

For instance, the wings of a bat and a bird are similar in function, but this similarity does not mean that these animals are more closely related.

 The wings of a bat are just the folds of skin that are stretched between its fingers whereas the wings of birds are modified forearms covered in feathers. 

Thus, we can say that analogous organs perform the same function in both animals but are anatomically very different.
How does pruning of plants promote branching?

Cytokinin is a class of plant growth substances that promotes cell division or cytokinesis in plant roots and shoots. They are involved primarily in cell growth and differentiation but also affect apical dominance, axillary bud growth, and leaf senescence. Pruning of plants promotes branching because the axillary buds get sensitized to cytokinin.

Morphactins is a synthetic growth regulators.

Morphactins are a group of substances that act on morphogenesis and modulate the expression of plants.  Chemically, they are the derivates of fluorene compounds.  Fluorene by itself is inactive, but the addition of the COOH group in the 9th position makes it active. The majority of morphactins, as synthetic compounds, have very diverse effects on plant growth and development.  Ex. Chloroflurenol, Flurenol, Methyl benzilate, Methyl chloroflurenol, Methyl dichloroflurenol.
Long day plants under short day conditions
Short day plants under long day conditions

Gibberellins are plant chemicals that regulate a variety of formative processes such as stem stretching, germination, torpidity, flowering, flower improvement, and leaf and natural product senescence. GAs is one of the most well-known plant chemicals.

Gibberellins (GAs) work not only to promote the development of plant organs but also to accelerate stage progression during development. Their contribution to bloom initiation in difficult days (LD) and biennial plants is grounded, and there is growing knowledge of the components by which botanical enlistment is accomplished.

Biosynthesized geranyl diphenyls are diterpene plant chemicals, a typical C20 precursor for diterpenoid, which control and improve various parts of development, including seed germination, stem extension, blooming biogenic product progression, and quality guidelines on the aleurone layer. These gibberellic acids come from higher plants and organisms, but also from microorganisms.

Gibberellic acid is a plant chemical that aids in stem development. Darting refers to rapid blooming with cell division and cell lengthening. Long days or cold treatment are required for shooting. Under normal conditions, the use of gibberellic corrosives can cause blooming. Under short-day conditions, it induces flowering in short day plants.

Gibberellin is a chemical present in seeds, young leaves, and roots of plants. Gibberella fujikuroi is a chemical-producing parasite in the phylum Ascomycota that causes rice plants to grow excessively and yield ineffectively.
Which of the following statement is not correct?
Auxins are effective in producing parthenocarpic fruit
Only gibberellins are effective in producing parthenocarpic fruit

Gibberellins are another kind of promoter PGR. There are more than 100 gibberellins reported from widely different organisms such as fungi and higher plants. They are denoted as GA1, GA2, GA3, and so on. Gibberellins, Auxin, etc. are effective in producing parthenocarpic fruit. Therefore statement (C) is INCORRECT.

Auxins refer to a group of plant growth hormones or regulators (PGR). Auxin (from Greek ‘auxein’ : to grow) was first isolated from human urine. The term ‘auxin’ is applied to the indole-3-acetic acid (IAA), and to other natural and synthetic compounds having certain growth-regulating properties. Seedless fruits are called parthenocarpic fruit which can be produced by a spray of auxin(IAA). Therefore statement (A) is CORRECT.

Fruits are the results of fertilization, there are a few species in which fruits develop without fertilization. Such fruits are called parthenocarpic fruits. Such fruits are seedless. Therefore statement (C) is CORRECT.

Fruits are the results of fertilization, there are a few species in which fruits develop without fertilization. Such fruits are called parthenocarpic fruits. Therefore statement (D) is CORRECT.

Example of artificial auxins are:

(a) IPA

(b) PAA

(c) NAA

(d) 2, 4, 5 - T

(e) 2, 4 - D

Please note that there are 2 sets of information given in the question. The first set (options a-e) mentions the names of compounds. The second set (options 1-4) mentions the combinations of the first set of options.

  • Auxin refers to a group of plant hormones that regulate plant growth.
  • Based on their origin, auxins can be divided into:
    • Natural Auxins - They occur naturally in the plant and affect physiological functions. E.g. - IAA, IBA.
    • Artificial Auxins - These are synthetically-derived chemical compounds that resemble IAA in biological activity. E.g. - NAA.
  • Artificial auxins are widely used in horticultural practices, as weedicides, rooting agents, and defoliating agents.
  • IPA
    • Indole-3-pyruvic acid (IPA) is an intermediate in the IAA biosynthesis pathway.
    • Hence, it is not an artificial auxin.
  • PAA
    • Phenylacetic acid (PAA) is a natural auxin.
  • NAA
    • Naphthalene acetic acid (NAA) is an artificial auxin that is used as a rooting agent.
  • 2,4,5-T
    • 2,4,5 - Trochlorophenoxyacetic acid is an artificial auxin that is used as a herbicide.
  • 2,4-D
    • 2,4 - Dichlorophenoxy acetic acid (2,4-D) is an artificial auxin that is widely used as a herbicide.

Thus the answer will be (c), (d), and (e).

Find the correct match:

a)

Apoptosis

i)

Cellular contents leak out

b)

Necrosis

ii)

Passive process

  

iii)

Plasma membrane intact

  

iv)

Death of single cell

Please note that options in one column may be matched with multiple options from the other column, as in this question. This is a specific format of question and not an error.

Apoptosis:

  • It is a natural physiological process involving a series of events to get rid of unwanted cells.
  • The process is also known as programmed cell death and is mediated by activating the intracellular death program when the cell is no more required.

Necrosis:

  • It is an uncontrolled cell death caused due to cell injury by pathological processes.
  • It is carried out as a defense response to a pathogen attack.
ApoptosisNecrosis
It occurs through the shrinking of cytoplasmIt occurs through swelling of the cytoplasm
Plasma membrane remains intact causing no leakage of cellular contentPlasma membrane bursts open due to swelling, causing the cellular content to leak out
It is an active process as it is ATP-dependentIt is a passive process as it is ATP-independent
It is a naturally occurring physiological processIt is a pathological process caused by external agents.
It is a localized process that destroys individual cellsIt affects a group of cells
Cells are usually phagocytized by neighboring cellsCells are phagocytized by phagocytes.
It is a beneficial process for the growth and development of the organismIt is a harmful process and takes place as a defense response to a pathogen attack

From the above table we can conclude:

  • Apoptosis leads to the death of single cells and the plasma membrane remains intact due to the shrinking of cells.
  • Necrosis is an active process in which cellular contents leak out due to the swelling of cells.

Thus, the correct match for (a) should be (iii) and (iv), and (b) should be (i) and (ii).

In 1928, Dutch botanist Fritz W. Went finally isolated auxin diffused out from the tip of oat coleoptiles in the gelatin block. Following Went's success, auxin, indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) was then isolated first from human urine, then from fungi, and finally from higher plants.

Auxin is a plant hormone that is found at the growing apices of plant stems and roots.

It has the following functions:

  • It shows apical dominance due to which growing apical buds inhibit lateral buds.
  • It initiates rooting in stem cuttings.
  • It promotes flowering and prevents early fruit drop.
  • It promotes the abscission of mature leaves and fruits.
  • It is usually represented by indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) and other compounds that resemble IAA.

IAA was first isolated from human urine by Kogl, Haagen-Smit and Erxleben. Though IAA is a phytohormone, it is also found in human urine. It is formed due to the breakdown of serotonin in the liver. It was initially called as 'heteroauxin', but later named by its chemical name. It has the chemical formula of C10H9NO2. It is the most naturally occurring auxin in higher plants and fungi. Other auxins occurring naturally include indole-3-butyric acid (IBA) and phenylacetic acid.

  • Coleoptiles of oat (Avena sativa) seedlings were used by F. W. Went for his Avena-Curvature test (1928).
  • It was shown that the tip of the coleoptile contained some substance that can cause the bending of the entire coleoptile.
  • Auxin was later isolated from the oat coleoptiles.
Which of the following is essential for fruit ripening?

The following are plant growth regulators or phytohormones that control various developmental as well as physiological functions of a plant:

Auxin:

  • It helps in cell elongation, growth, and differentiation.
  • It is present mainly at the root and shoots apices.
  • It is responsible for the phenomenon of apical dominance, where the apical buds inhibit the growth of lateral buds.
  • It results in increasing the height of a plant due to apical dominance.
  • It can also initiate root growth in stem cuttings.
  • It may also promote flowering and prevent early fruit drop.

Cytokinin:

  • It is mainly associated with cell division and is present in regions of rapid cell division.
  • It helps to overcome apical dominance and promotes lateral shoot growth.

Ethylene:

  • It is a gaseous phytohormone produced in the tissues undergoing senescence.
  • It helps in fruit ripening and other senescence-related activities.
  • It breaks seed and bud dormancy to initiate germination in some species.
  • It also induces leaf epinasty under stress conditions.
  • The triple response of ethylene includes reducing the rate of elongation, increasing lateral expansion, and swelling of the region below the hook in seedlings.

Abscisic acid:

  • As the name suggests, it helps in abscission and dormancy.
  • It inhibits plant growth, metabolism, and seed germination.
  • It also plays an important role in the closure of stomata under stress conditions.
An increase in the length of a plant can be measured by an instrument called:

An auxanometer is an apparatus for measuring the increase of growth in plants. In the case of an arc-auxanometer, there is a thin cord fixed to the plant apex on one end and a dead-weight on the other with a pointer indicating against an arc scale. In some forms, it passes over a pulley that has a pointer attached to it.

Formula for measuring the plant length by Auxanometer:

Actual growth in length = Distance travelled by the pointer × Radius of the pulley length of the pointer
The phenomenon of responding to an external stimulus like light is known as:

Phototropism is one of the many plant tropisms or movements which respond to external stimuli. Growth towards a light source is called positive phototropism, while growth away from light is called negative phototropism.
The senescence observed in banana and gladiolus is:

Senescence refers to a number of controlled processes which finally culminate in the death of the plant part. There are different forms of senescence that are observed in plants during aging. In certain plants, the senescence process starts from the apical part of the shoot. This type of senescence is known as top senescence. This occurs after the process of flowering and fruiting plants like bananas.
The dormancy taking place in non-dormant and post dormant seeds is:

Secondary dormancy occurs in some non-dormant and posts dormant seeds that are exposed to conditions that are not favorable for germination, like high temperatures. It is caused by conditions that occur after the seed has been dispersed.
In the process of plant micropropagation, the technician in the laboratory forgot to add cytokinins to the culture medium. After somedays he observed:
a number of shoots from the callus
a number of roots from the callus

Co-ordination in plants:

  • It was generally agreed that the growth of plants depends on the salts of soil and environmental conditions.
  • But today it was established that some chemical substances also affect the growth of plants.
  • These chemical substances are synthesized in one part of the plant and influence the growth of the plant at a site remote from it.
  • They diffuse out from the point of synthesis to the site of action.
  • The shoot bends towards which regulates and controls light the growth of plant parts is called plant hormones. 
  • The plant hormones that promote growth are:
    • Auxin
    • Cytokinins
    • Gibberellins
  • The plant hormones that inhibit growth are:
    • ​Abscisic acid

Cytokinin is also a plant hormone that promotes growth. They are found in fruits and seeds. The callus develops shoot in the presence of cytokinin because it plays an important role in the cell division mechanism. It also plays an important role in organ differentiation such as shoot, leaves, etc. So, if we forgot to add cytokinin to the culture medium in the plant micropropagation process, then there will be delayed organogenesis in the callus, and it doe not develop shoot bud. 

Thus, the correct answer is delayed organogenesis in the callus.
With which of the following is the Richmond Lang's effect associated?
Stimulation of rosette plants to grow normal

Leaf senescence is a complex process which involves biochemical and physiological changes. It takes place as a response to environmental stress and an age-dependent genetic activity. Cell organelles break down when they get mature and constituent materials are transported from leaves to other parts of the plants.

The Richmond Lang effect was discovered in the year 1967 by Richmond and Lang. According to this effect, the lag of senescence of the leaves and other parts of the plants occurs with the help of the application of plant growth regulator cytokinin.

Cytokinin are the plant hormones that influence the development, plant growth and physiology that including chloroplast differentiation and delay of senescence. Senescence is biological ageing that involves the gradual deterioration of functional characteristics. It is a cellular response that is characterised by the stable growth arrest of the plant cell.

Retarding senescence leads to the delay of chlorophyll (green colour pigment) degradation rate, the yellowing colour of the leaves and keeping it active for a longer time.

It influences the synthesis of proteins and minerals and also mobilizes nutrients. The hormone causes a delay in the process of senescence and ageing.

In the Richmond Lang effect, there is a prevention of degradation of the proteins and immobilisation of the nutrients. The molecules that include chlorophyll pigments in the plant leaf are not degraded. This helps in the prevention of ageing and falling of the plant leaves.
Which of the following plant hormones restricts the shoot branching?

Strigolactones are signaling compounds made by plants. They have two main functions: first, as endogenous hormones to control plant development, and second as components of root exudates to promote symbiotic interactions between plants and soil microbes. Some plants that are parasitic on other plants have established a third function, which is to stimulate the germination of their seeds when in close proximity to the roots of a suitable host plant. It is this third function that led to the original discovery and naming of strigolactones.
How many cells per hour can a single maize root apical meristem give?

Growth is measured by a variety of parameters some of which are: an increase in fresh weight, dry weight, length, area, volume, and cell number.

one single maize root apical meristem can give rise to more than17,500 new cells per hour, whereas cells in watermelon may increase in size by up to 3,50,000 times. In the former, growth is expressed as an increase in cell number; the latter expresses growth as an increase in the size of the cell.
The process of de-specialization of differentiated cells so that they become undifferentiated and meristematic is called:

The process of de-specialization of differentiated cells so that they become undifferen­tiated and able to divide is known as dedifferentiation.

Dedifferentiation is a cellular process by which cells grow in reverse, from a partially or terminally differentiated stage to a less differentiated stage within their own lineage. In general, the phenomenon is manifested by a change in shape, gene expression pattern, protein expression pattern, and function. It involves the activation of certain genes which not only reverse differentiation but also stimulate cell division. Cork cambium, wound cambium and inter-fascicular vascular cambium are always produced through dedifferentia­tion.
The undifferentiated mass of parenchymatous cells are called:

Plant callus (plural calluses or calli) is a growing mass of unorganized plant parenchyma cells. In living plants, callus cells are those cells that cover a plant wound. “Callus” in the early days of plant biology referred to the massive growth of cells and accumulation of callose associated with wounding. Today the same word is used more broadly, and disorganized cell masses are collectively called callus.
The correct sequence leading to the growth curve:

Growth curve, in biology, is a curve in graph form that shows the change in the number of cells (or single-celled organisms) in an experimental culture at different times. Growth curves are also common tools in ecological studies; they are used to track the rise and fall of populations of plants, animals, and other multicellular organisms over time. The classic growth curve, as exemplified by a newly established bacterial colony, is divided into four phases, in order of their appearance: (1) lag phase; (2) log (logarithmic), or exponential, phase; (3) stationary phase; and (4) death, or decline, phase.

The term auxin has been derived from the Greek word “auxein” which means “to grow”. It is known to be the first plant hormone that was discovered.

Auxins are a group of compounds that include indole-3-acetic acid (IAA), and other natural and synthetic compounds that have certain growth-regulating properties. They are one of the various plant growth regulators(PGRs). They are generally produced by the growing apices of the stems and roots; from where they migrate to the other regions of their action. Auxins can be natural or synthetic. Indole Acetic Acid(IAA) and indole butyric acid (IBA) are some natural auxins that have been isolated from plants.

Some synthetic auxins include NAA (naphthalene acetic acid) and 2, 4-D (2, 4-dichlorophenoxyacetic) which are used for various purposes.

Functions:

Physiological:

Cell Elongation: Auxin promotes elongation and growth of stems and roots and enlargement of fruits by overall enlargement of cells in all directions,

Apical Dominance: In many plants, the apical bud grows while the lower axillary buds are suppressed. This is an effect of the auxin(IAA) of the axillary bud. This can be proven but removing the apical bud which then results in the growth of lateral buds.

Control abscission layer: Auxin inhibits the abscission of young leaves and fruits in normal amounts. An abscission layer is produced only when the auxin content is reduced below the minimum level which ultimately leads to the fall of ripe fruits.

There are many other uses:

Rooting: Auxin stimulates root formation in woody stem cuttings.

Flowering: The dilute solutions of synthetic auxins are sprayed on fruits like litchi and pineapple which induce flowering in them. However, in most plants, flowering will be inhibited by spraying a high concentration of auxins.

Parthenocarpy: Auxins in diluted form can be used to produce parthenocarpic or seedless fruits. It has been proven that naturally parthenocarpic fruits like bananas and grapes have higher internal production of auxins.

Weedicides: Spraying synthetic auxins like 2,4-D is a procedure commonly used as weedicides. They are used to remove many broad-leaved weeds or dicotyledonous weeds while sparing the monocot plants.

Except for auxin, there are four other plant hormones called gibberellins, cytokinin, abscisic acid, and ethylene. Together they are called Plant Growth Regulators (PGRs). Some of them cause the plants to grow, while others like abscisic acid promote senescence. i.e. promote falling of leaves and fruits. Ethylene is the only gaseous hormone.
__________________ is the loss of differentiated cells’ regained ability to divide. It enables differentiated cells in the plant body to operate as functionally specialised cells.

Redifferentiation is the loss of differentiated cells’ regained ability to divide. It enables differentiated cells in the plant body to operate as functionally specialized cells. The treated differentiated cells revert to the redifferentiated form, performing a specific function, after preparing the plant body for physiological or structural change by dedifferentiation.

After cell division, the dedifferentiated vascular cambium, for example, redifferentiates into secondary xylem and phloem. The cells of the secondary xylem and secondary phloem, on the other hand, are incapable of further cell division, and after maturation, these cells execute duties such as food and water conduction while maintaining the structural integrity of the plant.
Measurement and the comparison of total growth per unit time is called:

The simplest index of plant growth; a rate of change in size, an increment in size per unit of time. Most commonly applied to total dry weight or total leaf area per plant.

The formula is Absolute change = New value - Previous value. Use the original value for dividing the absolute change: You can get the growth rate by dividing the absolute change by the previous value. 

The formula is:

Growth rate = Absolute changePrevious value
The formation of interfascicular cambium in plants is due to:

Interfascicular cambium and cork cambium are formed due to cell dedifferentiation. Differentiation The process which leads to the maturation of cells is called differentiation. During differentiation, a few or major changes happen in the protoplasm and cell walls of the cells.
Heterophyllous development due to the environment is an example of:

Heterophylly is the development of different types of leaves on the same plant. It is an example of plasticity, the ability of plants to form different kinds of structures in response to environmental factors (like climate, water availability) or phases of life. As in the diagram (figure b), the plant buttercup has different morphological structures depending on the environment it presents. In the terrestrial habitat, it has expanded leaves and in the marine habitat, it bears dissected leaves. Similarly, in larkspur (figure a), the leaves in the juvenile phase have different shapes than that of the adult phase.

Senescence is the complete loss in the power of cell division and is generally associated with aging.

Dormancy is the state in which normal physical functions are suspended for a time period.

Gibberellic acid is a Terpene.

All known gibberellins are diterpenoid acids that are synthesized by the terpenoid pathway in plastids and then modified in the endoplasmic reticulum and cytosol until they reach their biologically-active form. All gibberellins are derived via the ent-gibberellane skeleton, but are synthesized via ent-kaurene.
The PGR used to initiate flowering and for synchronizing fruit-set in pineapples is:

Ethylene initiates flowering and synchronizes fruit-set in pineapples. It is a gaseous plant growth regulator which also hastens the ripening of fruits and promotes abscission and senescence of leaves and flowers. It is commonly used in the form of Ethephon which releases ethylene slowly from an aqueous solution.

Cytokinin does not help in promoting leaf senescence.

Cytokinin production slows down the process of senescence. However, the accumulation of sugars during senescence, due to the breakdown of accumulated starch or the preferential export of N2 from the leaf, can block the effect of cytokinin, especially in low light.

Ethylene is regarded as a multifunctional phytohormone that regulates both growth, and senescence. It promotes or inhibits growth and senescence processes depending on its concentration, timing of application, and the plant species.
In most situations, which of the following acts as an antagonist to GAs?

In most situations, ABA acts as an antagonist to GAs. Gibberellins are plant hormones that regulate and stimulate the growth of main stems, especially when applied to the whole plant. They regulate various processes, including stem prolongation, germination, flowering, leaf, and fruit aging.

Gibberellin or Gibberellic Acid (GA) is produced in embryos, roots, and young leaves and it stimulates growth. Gibberellin is responsible for seed germination. The hormone ABA (Abscisic acid) inhibits seed germination. Gibberellin delays aging in plants. Abscisic acid promotes the aging of leaves. Gibberellin is commercially obtained from fungi. It is used to facilitate the germination of seeds. It breaks the discontinuation of seeds as opposed to Abscisic acid, which induces inactivity of buds and seeds. Due to their opposite effect on plant growth, ABA (abscisic acid) acts as an antagonist to gibberellins.

Gibberellic acid (GA) was discovered by Kurosawa, a Japanese Botanist in 1938. Chemically speaking, gibberellins are actually acidic. It is sprayed on the grapevines and used to enlarge them. It is used on cucumber plants to produce all-male flowers.
An S-shaped graph produced on plotting growth against time is called:

Plant growth rate be termed as the increase in growth per unit time.

The rate of growth of a plant or plant part is not always uniform during its lifespan. Sometimes it is slow and at other times rapid. If we plot the increase in cell number (growth rate) against time, a typical S-shaped curve is obtained. This has been called as the growth curve or sigmoid growth curve by Sachs (1873) as the shape of the curve obtained was sigmoid.

The growth curve has three phases of growth:

(i) Lag Phase- This is the initial phase of growth where the rate of growth is very slow.

(ii) Log or Exponential Phase-Rate of growth rapidly increases during this phase.

(iii) Stationary Phase- The rate of growth starts decreasing and finally stops.
At the root apex, the cells of the meristematic region are not characterized by:
A cell wall that is primary in nature

At the root apex, the cells of the meristematic region are not characterized by abundant plasmodesmata connections.

Meristematic tissue is a group of similar and immature cells that are in a continuous state of division. These tissues are found in growing regions of plants. This tissue is characterized by small cells, thin cell walls, large conspicuous nuclei, and no intercellular spaces. Cells are rich in protoplasm with abundant mitochondria. The cells have primary cell walls made up of cellulose. It has abundant plasmodesmata connections.
As a result of binary fission number of individuals produced by one fission is:

As a result of binary fission number of individuals produced by one fission is two.

Binary fission is the process of asexual reproduction in which the parent cell divides to form two daughter cells. The nucleus divides and then the cells divide to produce two cells. These daughter cells are produced from the single parent and contain the exact copy of genes as the mother cell.

Asexual reproduction takes place in lower animals. It is a type of reproduction in which off springs are produced from a single parent cell and has the same genetic code as the parent. The new organisms are produced by somatic cells, hence it has another name called Somatogenic Reproduction.
An alternation of asexual and sexual generations where both the enervation are diploid and the haploid stage is represented only by the gametes:

An alternation of asexual and sexual generations where both the enervation are diploid and the haploid stage is represented only by the gametes called Metagenesis. The two phases, or generations, are often morphologically, and sometimes chromosomally, distinct. Alternation of generations is the type of life cycle that occurs in those plants and algae in the Archaeplastida and the Heterokontophyta that have distinct haploid sexual and diploid asexual stages.
Which mode of reproduction present in Amoeba?

Binary fission and multiply fission mode of reproduction present in Amoeba.

The binary fission is a type of asexual reproduction in which two daughter cells are produced from single parents. The amoeba reproduces through binary as well as multiple fission. Binary fission is a type of cell division, in which cells increase in size and then divide to form the new cells.
Among the following which one is not a method of vegetative propagation?

Sowing is not a method of vegetative propagation.

The most common forms of vegetative propagation are grafting, cutting, layering, tuber, bulb or stolon formation, suckering and tissue culture. Sowing is the process of planting. An area or object that has had seeds planted in it will be described as a sowed area.
In all the methods of asexual reproduction:
Offspring's produced are genetically different to the parents
Offspring's produced are genetically identical to the parents
Offspring's produced are genetically same to the parents

In all the methods of asexual reproduction Offspring's produced are genetically different to the parents.

Asexual reproduction produces offspring that are genetically identical to the parent because the offspring are all clones of the original parent. This type of reproduction occurs in prokaryotic microorganisms (bacteria) and in some eukaryotic single-celled and multi-celled organisms.
Common method of asexual reproduction is by:

Common method of asexual reproduction is by Budding.

Budding is a form of asexual reproduction that results from the outgrowth of a part of a cell or body region leading to a separation from the original organism into two individuals. Budding occurs commonly in some invertebrate animals such as corals and hydras.
What is true in process of fertilization?
Only one sperm reaches the egg and enters it
The entry of sperm activities at the egg for completing meiosis
Two haploid nuclei fuse and to Immediately, divided to produce two nuclei which are again haploid
Only the acrosome of the sperm enters the egg.

The entry of sperm activities at the egg for completing meiosis is true in process of fertilization.

The entry of sperm activates the egg for completing meiosis. Fertilization is the fusion of gametes (male and female) to develop a new individual organism. About once a month, an egg is released from one of a woman's two ovaries. This is called ovulation. The egg then enters the nearby fallopian tube that leads to the uterus. If one of the sperm cells penetrates the egg, the egg is fertilized and begins developing.
Cells become variable in morphology and functions in different region of the embryo, The process is:

Cells become variable in morphology and functions in different region of the embryo, The process is called Differentiation.

After formation of three primary germ layers (i.e., ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm), cells of these three layers become variable in morphology, shape, size and more specified to form organs so as to meet out the future functional needs of the foetus, this process is called differentiation.
Plant having column of vascular tissues bearing fruits and having a tap root system is:

Plant having column of vascular tissues bearing fruits and having a tap root system is called Dicot.

Dicotyledoneae is the group of angiosperm with two cotyledons, flower bi or pentamerous, leaves net-viened, stern with open collateral vascular bundle arranged in a ring and roots form tap root system. Dicots typically also have flower parts (sepals, petals, stamens, and pistils) based on a plan of four or five, or multiples thereof, although there are exceptions.

Plant embryo develops from Zygote.

The DNA from the ovule and pollen combine to form a diploid, single-cell zygote that will develop into an embryo. The first cell division of a zygote is asymmetric, resulting in an embryo with one small cell (the apical cell) and one large cell (the basal cell). In vascular plants embryo formation, or embryogenesis, usually occurs within a few hours after fertilization, with the first cell division that cleaves the zygote, or fertilized egg, into two daughter cells.

Embryo of flowering plant is always Diploid (2n).

The plant life cycle alternates between haploid and diploid generations. Embryonic development is seen only in the diploid generation. The embryo, however, is produced by the fusion of gametes, which are formed only by the haploid generation.

Plant embryo is a mass of Miniature plant. The plant embryo, sometimes called the seed embryo, is the part of a seed or bud that contains the earliest forms of a plant's roots, stem and leaves. The embryo develops after a fertilized adult plant flowers, and is generally contained within a seed or bud.

Stamen is a modification of Microsporophyll.

The female reproductive organ of a flower is called a carpel. The leaf-like organ which contains microsporangia is known as microsporophyll. Modification in the microsporophyll results in the formation of stamens. Stamens are the male reproductive organ of the plant.

Zygote is formed inside the female gametophyte.

A zygote forms when a sperm penetrates the outer surface of an egg. This happens in the fallopian tube. While the zygote stage is very brief, lasting only the early days of conception, it is important. The single-celled zygote contains all of the genetic information required to form a fetus.

A microspore is a first cell of male gametophyte.

After meiosis, the haploid microspores undergo several changes to give rise to pollen grains which later produce the sperm cells or male gametes. In this process, the microscope is the first haploid cell produced and hence, is considered as the first cell of the male gametophyte.

An anther consists of four microsporangia.

Stamen, the male reproductive part of a flower. In all but a few extant angiosperms, the stamen consists of a long slender stalk, the filament, with a two-lobed anther at the tip. The anther consists of four saclike structures (microsporangia) that produce pollen for pollination.

Cells of nucellus are always Diploid.

The nucellus encloses the embryo sac and this acts as the nutritive tissue to the nucleus and the embryo sac. This nucellus is also helpful in providing the nutrients for the growth of the embryo. Hence the nucellus of the ovule is diploid in nature.

The embryo sac is produced from Megaspore.

A megaspore mother cell, or megasporocyte, is a diploid cell in plants in which meiosis will occur, resulting in the production of four haploid megaspores. In flowering plants the megasporangium is also called the nucellus, and the female gametophyte is sometimes called the embryo sac.

An egg apparatus contains: An egg + Two synergids

An egg apparatus is a group of three cells in the seven celled embryo sac of an angiosperm(seed plants). It comprises an egg cell and two associated cells called synergids. The Egg apparatus is located at the end of the embryo sac closer to the micropyle.

In angiosperm the endosperm nucleus is Triploid.

It is the main source of food for the embryo in angiosperms. The central cell is a highly active cell that performs several important functions in the embryo sac. The fusion of the secondary nucleus or the polar nuclei with the sperm nucleus gives rise to the primary endosperm nucleus, which is generally triploid.

Female gametophyte is also known as Embryo sac.

The female gametophyte is also commonly called the embryo sac or megagametophyte. The male gametophyte, also called the pollen grain or microgametophyte, develops within the anther and consists of two sperm cells encased within a vegetative cell (Gifford and Foster, 1989).

Embryo sac contains 1 egg.

The embryo sac or which is also called as the female gametophyte is an oval structure which is situated in the ovule of flowering plants. - There is only one egg in an embryo sac. - Number of embryo sacs present in an ovule is one. - Numbe of ovules in an ovary varies from plant to plant.

Carpel is formed of three parts.

The ovary containing the ovules, the style through which the pollen tubes grow, and the stigma on which the pollen grains germinate. A carpel is the female reproductive part of the flower —composed of ovary, style, and stigma— and usually interpreted as modified leaves that bear structures called ovules, inside which egg cells ultimately form.
The arrangement of flowers on the flora axis is known as:

An inflorescence is the arrangement of flowers on the floral axis of the plant. Two major types of the inflorescence are - 1. Racemose - the shoot axis continues to grow indefinitely and the flowers are borne in acropetal succession. Examples are radish, Lupin, and mustard. 2. Cymose - the main axis terminates into a flower and has a limited growth and the flowers are borne in a basipetal order. Examples are begonia, teak, and Solanum.
The unit of the female reproductive body in flower is:

The unit of the female reproductive body in flower is Carpel.

Gynoecium is the fourth whorl of a flower. Its individual unit is called megasporophyll or carpel. It consists of an ovary, stigma, and style. It is the female reproductive organ of the flower. The stigma is the top and sticky portion of a carpel. It is the site of pollination. The style of a carpel is a long tube that connects the stigma to the ovary. Ovary is the lowermost part of the carpel and contains the ovules.

After fertilization the ovule develops into seed.

Fertilization occurs when one of the sperm cells fuses with the egg inside of an ovule. After fertilization occurs, each ovule develops into a seed. Each seed contains a tiny, undeveloped plant called an embryo. The ovary surrounding the ovules develops into a fruit that contains one or more seeds.

Fruit is a modification of Ovary.

Botanically, a fruit is a mature ovary and its associated parts. Fertilization induces various changes in a flower: the anthers and stigma wither, the petals drop off, and the sepals may be shed or undergo modifications; the ovary enlarges, and the ovules develop into seeds, each containing an embryo plant.

The seed coat develops from outer integument.

The inner integument develops into a hard, grooved seed coat with the pericarp persisting only as a broken layer. Seeds of Eleutsine will not germinate until after the seed coat has been modified in some way. The seed coat develops from the maternal tissue, the integuments, originally surrounding the ovule. The seed coat in the mature seed can be a paper-thin layer (e.g. peanut) or something more substantial (e.g. thick and hard in honey locust and coconut), or fleshy as in the sarcotesta of pomegranate.
The process of conversion of a small cockroach into an adult cockroach is called as :

Metamorphosis is the sequential developmental stages which are characterized by the process of cell division, differentiation, and maturation. It includes morphological and genetical changes.

The life cycle of cockroach has three stages of metamorphosis as the egg, nymph, and the adult.
Which of the following diseases spreads through infected needles or blood transfusion?

AIDS spread through infected needles or blood transfusion.

AIDS (Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) is an infection that is caused by the Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). The causative agent of the disease is a virus and so the disease can spread from one person to the other by sexual contact. The disease also spreads through the use of the infected needles, syringes and blood transfusion from the infected person.
Which one of the following is a non-communicable disease?

Cancer is a non-communicable disease.

The communicable disease spreads from one person to another via any form of transmission where the non-communicable disease cannot spread from one person to the other. Cancer is a disease wherein cells grown uncontrollably giving rise to the tumor. This disease may be a hereditary disease or can be caused due to exposure to excessive sunlight, chemical, radioactive material, x rays, UV rays, etc. Thus, it is a non-communicable disease.

Amoebiasis is a parasitic infection most commonly caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The parasite may cause both intestinal and extra-intestinal disease. The intestinal disease manifests as fever, chills, bloody or mucoid diarrhoea, abdominal discomfort, or alternating diarrhoea with constipation. Flies can carry the parasites. Protect foods against fly contamination by shielding them with a cover to prevent fly contamination as flies are known to be carriers of parasites.

The disease pneumonia is caused by bacteria.

Pneumonia caused by bacteria is a respiratory disease characterised by inflammatory conditions of the lungs leading to cough, chest pain, fever, breathlessness. Immunisations have been employed for preventing the spread of this disease.
Which of the following pathogen causes typhoid?

Typhoid fever is caused by the bacterium Salmonella typhi. The infection can be recognized by rose colour spots of rash on the chest and skin. The bacterium is found in the intestines and blood of the infected person. The bacterium may also be found in the faeces of the infected person and may help in the spreading of the disease. The symptoms may also show fever, headache, nausea and loss of appetite.
A vaccine of a mixture of viruses that causes tetanus, diphtheria and whooping cough

The triple antigen DPT vaccine protects against 3 diseases, diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (or whooping cough). Diphtheria and tetanus are caused by bacterial toxins, inactivation of bacterial toxins produce toxoids that are no longer toxic but maintain the antigenic property and are used as a vaccine. Pertussis is a respiratory human disease. It is one of the most common vaccine-preventable childhood diseases.
Lipopolysaccharide is located on the surface of the bacteria.
A toxic protein that stays inside the bacterial cell.
Toxic protein that is excreted into the medium.

Bacterial endotoxin is a lipopolysaccharide is located on the surface of the bacteria.

Endotoxins are toxic substances bound to the bacterial cell wall and released when the bacterium ruptures or disintegrates. Endotoxins consist of lipopolysaccharide and lipoprotein complexes. Endotoxins are rarely fatal, although they often cause fever.

Diphtheria toxin was discovered by Émile Roux and Alexandre Yersin in the year 1888. It is the toxin secreted by the bacteria called Corynebacterium diphtheriae and causes diphtheria. It consists of a single polypeptide chain of 535 amino acids. This causes diseases to humans by entering through the cytoplasm and thereby inhibiting protein synthesis.
Which of the following are infectious and non-infectious diseases respectively?

AIDS and cancer are infectious and non-infectious diseases respectively.

Infectious diseases are those diseases that can spread from one person to another caused by organisms - such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites. AIDS which is caused by HIV is an infectious disease. Non-infectious diseases are those diseases that cannot spread from one person to another. They are neither contagious nor communicable. They arise from inside the body as a result of hereditary conditions or other causes, such as dietary deficiencies. Cancer is an example of non-infectious disease.
A communicable disease is generally caused by:
Communicable or Infectious diseases can be easily transmitted from one person to the other. These are caused by pathogenic microorganisms, such as bacteria, viruses, parasites or fungi.
The quickest method of plant breeding is:

The quickest method of plant breeding is mutation breeding.

Plant breeding is the technique used to improve the variety of plants for human welfare. Introduction, selection, hybridization and mutation breeding are the main methods of crop improvement along with polyploid breeding, tissue culture and genetic engineering. The introduction is the process of introducing new plants from their old locality to the new one. Selection is the oldest method of plant improvement in which suitable varieties are selected. It is of two types-natural and artificial. Hybridization is the production of new varieties by crossing two or more plants having a different genetical constitution. Mutation breeding is a quick way to introduce sudden changes in the genome of the plant.
The scientific process by which crop plants are enriched with certain desirable nutrients is called:

The scientific process of breeding crops or using genetically engineered crops with higher levels of selected micronutrients like vitamins and or minerals is called bio-fortification. It is the most practical means to improve public health. For example, Golden rice is enriched with Vitamin A.

Biofortification of rice, Cassava, Sweet potato etc with Iron.

Biofortification of wheat,  beans, Maize etc with Zinc.

A pure line breed refers to a group of identical individuals that always produce offspring of the same phenotype when intercrossed. This occurs only when they are homozygous. It is the type of breeding in which both the mating breeds are of pure lines, i.e., generations of homozygous individuals, which produce offsprings of only one type i.e., they breed true for their genotype and phenotype.
The new varieties of plants are produced by:

The new varieties of plants are produced by selection and hybridization.

Selection is a non-random process that leads to individuals of different genotypes being represented unequally in their progeny in later generations of a population of self-propagating units. Selection can be natural or artificial. Hybridization is the crossing of two varieties, species, or genera having desired genes by bringing together the useful characters of these into one progeny. Both, these processes produce new plant varieties.
Growth of specific plant structures on artificial medium
Growth and multiplication of cells on artificial medium
Maintenance, growth and differentiation of cells, tissues and organs on, artificial medium

Tissue culture is the maintenance, growth and differentiation of cells, tissues and organs on, artificial medium.

Tissue culture is a biological technique that involves the development of plants under controlled conditions on a nutrient culture medium of the known composition. The pant developed by the tissue culture is cloned and maintained by the process of micropropagation. Gottlieb Haberlandt was the first to attempt tissue culture. He was first to point out the possibilities of the culture of isolated tissues. The cultured cells forms callus. Callus when treated with auxin it promotes rooting and when it is treated with cytokinin it stimulates cell maturation, differentiation and finally, promotes the development of stem.
Part of the plant used in tissue culture
Part of the plant that expresses a specific gene

An explant is part of the plant used in tissue culture.

An explant is a part of the plant that is taken out and grown in special nutritive media under sterile conditions. This is the process to generate a whole plant in tissue culture.
In the poultry industry, the production of hatching eggs is more expensive than the production of market eggs mainly because:
The cost of males and their depreciation value is high.
Mortality among females is usually lower when they are mated with males.
A number of eggs produced by hatchery flock are to be sold only as market eggs.
Some of the eggs produced by hatchery flocks are not acceptable for incubation.

In the poultry industry, the production of hatching eggs is more expensive because it requires an optimum temperature for incubation. But the major factor is the weight of the hatching egg and chick weight. Under optimal egg storage and incubation conditions, chick weight is 67-69 per cent of egg weight at setting. Therefore, the more uniform the egg weight, the more uniform the chick weight. Breeder uniformity determines uniformity in the hatching eggs produced; the more uniform the breeder flock, the more uniform the egg weights. So, some of the eggs produced by hatchery flocks are not acceptable for incubation and is rejected. So, the production of hatching eggs is more expensive than the production of market eggs.
