Which of the following is a correct statement?
Apis Indica is the largest wild bee.
Wax is an excretory product of bees.

Statement (D) is correct, as Karl Von Frisch discovered the communication and transmission methods in the honey bee during a number of experiments and found out that when a foraging bee returns to the hive, it performs a 'waggle dance'. 

  • Statement (A) is incorrect, as drones of the honey bee are haploid and not diploid. They develop parthenogenetically from unfertilized eggs. 
  • Statement (B) is incorrect, as Apis dorsata laboriosa and not Apis indica, the Himalayan honey bee, is the world's largest honey bee.
  • Statement (C) is incorrect, as bee's wax is not waste material, it is secreted by special wax glands present in the abdomen. It is used for making the hives of honeybees.
Which of the following statement regarding SCP is incorrect?
SCP is not prepared from monocellular organisms.
SCP is obtained from algae and fungi.
Commercial SCP is based on mainly yeast and fungi.
Substrate for SCP is sawdust, paddy and straw.

Single-cell protein (SCP) is prepared from monocellular organisms. So, statement (A) is incorrect.

Single-cell protein (SCP) is protein-rich biomass that is used as food or feed. It is rich in good quality protein and poor in fats. It is prepared from monocellular microorganisms as well as from multicellular microorganisms. SCP is obtained from algae like Spirulina, fungi like yeast (Candida utilis), and bacteria like Methylophilus methylotrophus. Commercial SCP is based on mainly yeast and fungi. Mushroom is a fungus. It is eaten by many people and large-scale mushroom culture is a growing industry. Substrate for SCP is dust, paddy, straw, molasses. They produce large quantities of food rich in protein, minerals, fats, carbohydrates, and vitamins.

Source of SCP is spirulina.

Spirulina is a cyanobacterium widely used as a source of supplementary protein. It is single-celled and is widely used as an SCP or Single-cell protein supplement.
A nitrogen-fixing microbe associated with the fern Azolla in rice fields is:

A nitrogen-fixing microbe associated with the fern Azolla in rice fields is Anabaena.

Anabaena azollae, a cyanobacterium that lives in symbiotic association with the free-floating water fern Azolla. Anabaena azollae can grow phot-autotrophically and fixes atmospheric nitrogen. The inoculation of cyanobacteria in rice crops significantly influences the growth of rice crops by secretion of ammonia in floodwater.
Wastewater treatment generates a large amount of sludge, which can be treated by:

Anaerobic digestion is a collection of processes by which microorganisms break down biodegradable material in the absence of oxygen. The process is used for industrial or domestic purposes to manage waste and to produce fuels. So, Wastewater treatment generates a large amount of sludge, which can be treated by anaerobic digesters.
The addition of commercially prepared bacterial strains with specific catabolic activities to degrade wastes.
The metals are deposited as insoluble oxides and sulphides by the activity of bacteria.
Bioaugmentation is the addition of bacterial cultures to enhance the rate of degradation of a contaminant. It is used in municipal wastewater treatment to restart activated sludge bioreactors.
Sewage water can be purified for recycling with the action of:

Sewage water can be purified for recycling with the action of microorganisms.

Sewage pollution can be prevented by treating sewage before passing into the watercourse, in sewage or effluent treatment plants (ETP). The sewage is treated in ETP in three stages. Stage one is Primary Treatment which comprises physical processes like sedimentation. The Second Stage is aerobic and anaerobic biological degradation by microorganisms. The last or tertiary stage is physicochemical degradation for removing turbidity and dissolved substances.
The free-living fungus Trichoderma can be used for:

The free-living fungus Trichoderma can be used for the biological control of plant diseases.

Trichoderma species are free-living fungi that are very common in root ecosystems. They are effective biocontrol agents of several plant pathogens like Fusarium, Phytophthora, etc and are used in the treatment of plant diseases.
The chemical, which is used to destroy the pests
The living organism or their products which are used for the pest control

Biopesticides are the living organism or their products that are used for pest control.

Biopesticides are the types of pesticides produced by plants, bacteria and certain minerals. It is made up of living organisms or its product that destroys the pest without affecting plants.

Chlorine treatment disinfects water by killing germs.

Chlorine is a powerful disinfectant that can kill bacteria and viruses by destabilizing the chemical bonds of the pathogens. So, it is used in the purification of water.

Methanogenic bacteria (bacteria that produce methane) are not found in activated sludge. Methanogenic bacteria are anaerobic bacteria. The microbes found in activated sludge are aerobic bacteria that grow rapidly and form flocs. So, Methanogenic bacteria are not found in activated sludge.

Nif is a nitrogen fixation gene that occurs in Rhizobium. It fixes atmospheric nitrogen into a form of nitrogen available to living organisms. The Nif genes are found in both free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria and symbiotic bacteria associated with various plants.
Which of the following is the pair of biofertilizers for nitrogen fixation?

Azolla and blue-green algae are the pair of biofertilizers for nitrogen fixation.

The term biofertilizers refers to the substance containing living or dried powder of microorganisms, it may be used to include all organic resources (manure) for plant growth which are rendered in an available form for plant absorption through microorganisms or plant associations or interactions. Azolla and blue-green algae (BGA) are biofertilizers used in rice fields. They provide nitrogen to the plant and are used as an alternative to biofertilizers. The blue-green algae Anabaena has a symbiotic relationship with the water fern Azolla to produce and supply nitrogen to the host plants.

Red muscle fibres differ from white muscle fibres with regard to the presence of:

a. Myoglobin

b. Large number of mitochondria

c. Haemoglobin

d. Excess of lactic acid

Red muscle fibers differ from white muscle fibers with regard to the presence of Myoglobin and a large number of mitochondria.

Red muscles are named so because they are dense with capillaries and are rich in myoglobin and mitochondria – which gives it a characteristic red appearance. On the other hand, white muscles have comparatively less mitochondria and myoglobin, giving the muscles a “whitish” appearance.
Glenoid cavity for the articulation of the head of humerus is provided by:

Glenoid cavity for the articulation of the head of humerus is provided by pectoral girdle. Each scapula or pectoral girdle has a concave, articular surface called the glenoid cavity which articulates with the head of the humerus. The ball like the head of the humerus articulates with the glenoid cavity which creates a ball and socket joint that allows the upper limb great motility.
Which of the following statements is false about the human skeleton?
The number of paired facial bones is 14.
Each half of pelvic girdle is composed of 3 bones.

"The number of paired facial bones is 14." is false about the human skeleton. There are total of 14 facial bones.

In the human skull, the facial skeleton consists of fourteen bones in the face:

  • Inferior turbinal (2)
  • Lacrimal bones (2)
  • Mandible.
  • Maxilla (2)
  • Nasal bones (2)
  • Palatine bones (2)
  • Vomer.
  • Zygomatic bones (2)
Close to which bone does the Jacobson's organ lie?

Jacobson's organ lies close to the Vomer bone.

Jacobson’s organ, also called the vomeronasal organ, an organ of chemoreception that is part of the olfactory system of amphibians, reptiles, and mammals, although it does not occur in all tetrapod groups. It is a patch of sensory cells within the main nasal chamber that detects heavy moisture-borne odor particles. Airborne odors, in contrast, are detected by the olfactory sensory cells located in the main nasal chambers.
Which of the following muscles aids in walking?

The hamstring muscle aids in walking.

The hamstring muscle group (biceps femoris, semitendinosus and semimembranosus) work together to bend the knee of the leading leg while walking. The gluteus maximus works with the hamstrings to extend the hip of the rear leg during a stride. Both of these muscles are worked more intensely when walking on an incline.
Muscle that reduces the angle of a joint between two bones
Muscle that moves the bone or part towards median line

The masseter muscle is an example of muscle that lifts the part upwards.

The masseter muscle is one of the four muscles responsible for the action of mastication (chewing). When the masseter contracts it causes powerful elevation of the mandible causing the mouth to close.
Flagellar movement is seen in all of the following, except:

Flagellar movement is seen in all of the following, except Paramecium.

Flagella are found in many algae and some animal cells, such as sperm, in eukaryotes. Flagellar movement, or locomotion, occurs as either planar waves, oarlike beating, or three-dimensional waves. All three of these forms of flagellar locomotion consist of contraction waves that pass either from the base to the tip of the flagellum or in the reverse direction to produce forward or backward movement.
A joint in which the bones are united by fibrous connective tissue forming an interosseous membrane or ligament is found in all of the following, except:
Union of the styloid process and the hyoid bone
Between the root of a tooth and the socket in the maxilla
Fibrous union between the radius and ulna
Fibrous union between the tibia and fibula

A joint in which the bones are united by fibrous connective tissue forming an interosseous membrane or ligament is found in all of the following, except between the root of a tooth and the socket in the maxilla.

Fibrous joints are where adjacent bones are strongly united by fibrous connective tissue. The gap filled by connective tissue may be narrow or wide. The three types of fibrous joints are sutures, gomphoses, and syndesmoses. A suture is the narrow fibrous joint that unites most bones of the skull.
Which of the following sentences is true for cartilaginous joints?
They allow less movement than fibrous joints.

The sentence "Primary cartilages may ossify with age." is true for cartilaginous joints.

Primary cartilaginous joints are known as "synchondrosis". These bones are connected by hyaline cartilage and sometimes occur between ossification centers. This cartilage may ossify with age. Some examples of primary cartilaginous joints in humans are the "growth plates" between ossification centers in long bones.
Where is the vertical muscle (a type of intrinsic muscle) located?

Vertical muscle (a type of intrinsic muscle) is located in the middle of the tongue.

The vertical muscle of the tongue is one of the four intrinsic muscles of the tongue which alters the shape of the tongue mass, being entirely confined to the tongue without an extraglossal attachment.
The sacrum in females compared to that in males is:

The male sacrum is long, narrow, straighter, and has a pronounced sacral promontory. The female sacrum is shorter, wider, more curved posteriorly, and has a less pronounced promontory. The acetabula are wider apart and face more medially in females than in males.

Formation of actomyosin brings about muscle contraction with the release of energy. The ions required for this process are:

a. Calcium

b. Magnesium

c. Phosphorous

The ions required for this process are calcium and Magnesium.

Actomyosin is a complex molecule formed by one molecule of myosin and one or two molecules of actin. In muscle, actin and myosin filaments are oriented parallel to each other and to the long axis of the muscle.
Which of the following symptoms is observed in persons with carnitine palmityl transferase (CPT) deficiency?

Muscular fatigue after prolonged exercise are observed in persons with carnitine palmityl transferase (CPT) deficiency.

Carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT I) deficiency is a condition that prevents the body from using certain fats for energy, particularly during periods without food (fasting). The severity of this condition varies among affected individuals. Signs and symptoms of CPT I deficiency often appear during early childhood.
Spiral waves are produced during the locomotion of:

Spiral waves are produced during the locomotion of Euglena. Euglena belongs to kingdom Protista. They are the unicellular organisms. They use flagella for their locomotion. In Euglena, there are two flagella. One of them is equal in length to body while other is short.
Which muscle is associated with puckering of the lips?

The circular muscle around our mouth is Orbicularis Oris, which associated with puckering of the lips. Orbicularis oris muscle, also known as musculus orbicularis oris is a complex, multi-layered muscle which attaches through a thin, superficial musculoaponeurotic system to the dermis of the upper lip and lower lip and serves as an attachment site for many other facial muscles around the oral region.
The middleman between blood and tissues is:

Lymph is called the middleman between tissues cells and blood.

Lymph acts as middle man which transports food materials, oxygen, hormones etc to the body cells and brings carbon dioxide and other metabolic wastes from the body cells to blood and then finally pours the same into venous system. Also body cells are kept moist by the lymph.
Myoglobin is found in which part of the body?

Myoglobin is found in muscles. Myoglobin is a protein that's found in your striated muscles, which includes skeletal muscles (the muscles attached to your bones and tendons) and heart muscles. Its main function is to supply oxygen to the cells in your muscles (myocytes). All cells in your body need oxygen in order to function.

Sinus venosus is a characteristic of fishes, amphibians and reptiles.

The sinus venosus, or systemic venous sinus, is the cardiac chamber with myocardial walls located upstream of the right atrium in tetrapods and the single atrium in fish, amphibians and reptiles.
The blood vascular system of frogs is:

The vascular system of frog is well-developed closed type. It has lymphatic system also. The blood vascular system involves heart, blood vessels and blood. The lymphatic system consists of lymph, lymph channels and lymph nodes.
Small oval-shaped structures found in the lymphatic vessels are termed:

Small oval-shaped structures found in the lymphatic vessels are termed lymph nodes.

A small bean-shaped structure that is part of the body's immune system. Lymph nodes filter substances that travel through the lymphatic fluid, and they contain lymphocytes (white blood cells) that help the body fight infection and disease. There are hundreds of lymph nodes found throughout the body.
Sacculated, fusiform or cylindrical forms are the main forms of which of the following diseases?

Sacculated, fusiform or cylindrical forms are the main forms of 'Aneurysm' disease.

An aneurysm is an abnormal bulge or ballooning in the wall of a blood vessel. "A proportion of these patients will go on to have a rupture. And the challenge with rupture is that it's unpredictable."
In which of the following can erythroblastosis foetalis occur?

Erythroblastosis foetalis occur in Man Rh+ and Woman Rh-.

Erythroblastosis foetalis is a condition where the Anti-Rh antibodies produced in a mother with Rh-ve blood group will attack the foetal RBCs (hemolysis) and ultimately kills the foetus. Such a situation actually arises when an Rh− mother is impregnated by an Rh+ father resulting in the conception of an Rh+ baby.
Which of the following is an iron deficiency disease?

Microcytic anemia is an iron deficiency disease.

Microcytic anemia happens when something affects your body's ability to make healthy red blood cells, and you may not be able to prevent some of those things from happening. For example, iron deficiency is the most common cause of microcytic anemia.

Match the following:
a. Plasma B-cells 1. They produce more B-lymphocyte cells.
b. Memory B-cells 2. They secrete antibodies into the blood circulation.
c. Dividing B-cells 3. They do not produce antibodies, but become programmed to remember a specific antigen and
respond very rapidly to any subsequent infection.

The correct matching codes are: a - 1, b - 3, c - 2

  • Plasma cells are differentiated B-lymphocyte white blood cells capable of secreting immunoglobulin, or antibody. These cells play a significant role in the adaptive immune response, namely, being the main cells responsible for humoral immunity.
  • In immunology, a memory B cell (MBC) is a type of B lymphocyte that forms part of the adaptive immune system. These cells develop within germinal centers of the secondary lymphoid organs. 
  • After activation by antigens, the B cells divide rapidly, with the same binding site as the starting B cell. The activated B cells differentiate into plasma B cells, which have a powerful ability to secrete antibody.
The circulation of blood in the blood vessels is known as:

Coronary circulation is the circulation of blood in the blood vessels that supply the heart muscle (myocardium). Coronary arteries supply oxygenated blood to the heart muscle. Cardiac veins then drain away the blood after it has been deoxygenated.

Plasma proteins are made by the liver.

The reticuloendothelial cells of the liver are in charge of plasma protein synthesis in adults. The bone marrow, degenerating blood cells, general body tissue cells, and the spleen also contribute to the formation of plasma proteins. Gamma globulins originate from B lymphocytes, which in turn form immunoglobulins.
Lymphatic vessels arising in the intestinal villi is/are called:

Lymphatic vessels arising in the intestinal villi is called Lacteals.

Intestinal villi are the numerous small finger-shaped projections which increases the absorptive surface area. They contain abundant blood capillaries and lymph vessels called lacteals, They also possess countless minute microvilli which further add to the absorptive surface. They do not participate in the digestion of fats but helps in their absorption and various other food substances such as water, mineral, salts, amino acids, vitamins, etc.
The protein Alpha-1 antitrypsin is used to treat which of the following diseases?

Alpha-1 antitrypsin is a protease inhibitor and it is used to treat emphysema because it protects tissues from enzymes of inflammatory cells.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin also has been investigated in islet cell transplantation to treat type 1 diabetes.
Biconvex and nucleated red blood cells, heart with more than two perfect chambers, closed type of circulation and oviparity are all features of:

Biconvex and nucleated red blood cells, heart with more than two perfect chambers, closed type of circulation and oviparity are all features of salamander.

Salamanders are characterized by four short limbs, rounded snouts, long/slender bodies, and the presence of a tail in both larval and adult stages. Most salamanders undergo metamorphosis, starting life as an aquatic form and becoming terrestrial as adults.
Muscular walls of ventricles are thicker than walls of atria because ventricles have to:

The muscular walls of ventricles are thicker compared to atria as they have to pump blood out of the heart.

They pump blood at a higher pressure to ensure it reaches all parts of the body. The right ventricle pumps the oxygen-poor blood to the lungs through the pulmonary valve. The left atrium receives oxygen-rich blood from the lungs and pumps it to the left ventricle through the mitral valve. The left ventricle pumps the oxygen-rich blood through the aortic valve out to the rest of the body.
Which of the following blood components play a major role in blood coagulation?

Thrombocytes play a major role in blood coagulation. Platelets, also known as thrombocytes, are blood cells. They form in your bone marrow, a sponge-like tissue in your bones. Platelets play a major role in blood clotting. Normally, when one of your blood vessels is injured, you start to bleed.
The pre-hypertension blood pressure value is a measurement between:

Prehypertension is defined as a systolic pressure from 120–139 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg) or a diastolic pressure from 80–89 mm Hg. Because blood pressure changes often, your health care provider will check it on several different days before deciding whether your blood pressure is too high.
Where (a) is a neutrophil, identify the other four WBCs?

The correct name of  b, c, d and e are monocyte, basophil, lymphocyte and eosinophil.

White blood cells, also known as leukocytes, are immune cells that circulate in the blood and lymphatic system. There are 5 main types:

  1. Neutrophils – main action against bacterial and fungal infections.
  2. Monocytes – main action against bacterial infections.
  3. Eosinophils – main action against parasitic infections.
  4. Basophils – responsible for responses to allergens.
  5. Lymphocytes – main action against viral infections.
Foetus is Rh-ve and mother is Rh+ve
Foetus is Rh+ve and mother is Rh-ve
Foetus is Rh-ve and father is Rh+ve

Rh incompatibility occurs when the mother's blood type is Rh negative and her fetus' blood type is Rh positive. Antibodies from an Rh-ve mother may enter the bloodstream of her unborn Rh+ve infant, damaging the red blood cells (RBCs).
One of the factors required for the maturation of erythrocytes is:

One of the factors required for the maturation of erythrocytes is B12. Because Vitamin B12 works in conjunction with folate in the formation and maturation of red blood cells.

Maturation from erythroid-committed precursors is called terminal erythropoiesis and occurs in the BM within erythroblastic islands, which consist of a central macrophage surrounded by erythroblasts, and ends in the blood stream where reticulocytes complete their maturation within 1–2 days.
The correct order for an increasing number of corpuscles in our blood is:

The correct order for an increasing number of corpuscles in our blood is: WBCs < Platelets < Erythrocytes

WBCs are relatively lesser in number which average 6000-8000 mm–3 of blood. A healthy adult man has, on average, 5 million to 5.5 million RBCs (Erythrocytes) mm–3 of blood. Blood normally contains 1,500,00-3,500,00 platelets mm–3.
Among mammals, the nucleus is absent in:

The absence of a nucleus is an adaptation of the mature red blood cell and platelets.

Mature red blood cells (RBCs) do not possess a nucleus along with other cell organelles such as mitochondria, Golgi apparatus and endoplasmic reticulum in order to accommodate a greater amount of hemoglobin in the cells. However, immature red blood cells contain a nucleus.

Mammalian platelets do not contain a nucleus. Interestingly, non-mammalian vertebrates have nucleated thrombocytes that have limited responses, to thrombin but not to ADP, serotonin or epinephrine.

Blood plasma proteins:

i. decrease in their level causes excessive absorption of water from tissues into the blood.

ii. they maintain osmotic pressure.
Statement i) is correct and ii) is wrong.
Statement i) is wrong and ii) is correct.

Statement i) is wrong and ii) is correct.

Plasma proteins, such as albumin and globulin, that help maintain the colloidal osmotic pressure at about 25 mmHg. Electrolytes like sodium, potassium, bicarbonate, chloride, and calcium help maintain blood pH. Immunoglobulins help fight infection and various other small amounts of enzymes, hormones, and vitamins.
Manoj has AB blood group, so he will have the following antibodies in his blood plasma:

Manoj will have no antibodies are present in his blood plasma.

AB blood group does not have any antibodies in plasma. That's why AB blood group is a universal recipient.

Human blood of AB group does not contain antibodies to erythrocyte antigens of other blood groups. This determines natural resistance of people to many infectious diseases whose agents have antigens on the surface of their cells that are similar to antigens of one or another group of blood.

Lymph transport absorbs fats from the digestive tract: Lymph includes fluids from your intestines that contain fats and proteins and transports it back to your bloodstream. Protects your body against foreign invaders: The lymphatic system is part of the immune system.

In our blood:

i. Granulocytes which constitutes maximum percentage of total leucocytes are neutrophils.

ii. Elevated number of neutrophils in blood indicates an acute infection such as appendicitis.
Statement i) is correct and ii) is wrong
Statement i) is wrong and ii) is correct

In human blood, granulocytes and agranulocytes types of leucocytes are present. Neutrophils constitute the maximum percentage of total WBCs. Sharp increase in number of neutrophils in blood indicates an acute infection such as appendicitis.

  • Granulocytes are the type of white blood cells that are present in the cytoplasm in the form of granules. They have four lobes and are also known as polymorphonuclear leukocytes.
  • Having a high percentage of neutrophils in your blood is called neutrophilia. This is a sign that your body has an infection. Neutrophilia can point to a number of underlying conditions and factors, including: infection, most likely bacterial. noninfectious inflammation.
  • These are the type of white blood cells without the granules. They have only one lobe and are known as mononuclear leukocytes due to the presence of just one nucleus.
The following pie chart shows four components of blood plasma represented from first to fourth Qtr and the correct sequence will be:
Water, proteins, inorganic salts and other materials
Water, proteins, dissolved gases and other materials
Proteins, water, inorganic salts and other materials

90-92 percent of plasma is water and proteins contribute 6-8 percent of it. Plasma also contains small amounts of minerals and other materials such as glucose, amino acids, lipids, etc., are also present in the plasma.

Plasma is the aqueous part of blood containing proteins and salt in which red and white blood cells and platelets are suspended. It constitutes approximately 55 percent of total blood volume. Important elements in plasma include albumin, coagulation factors, fibrinolytic proteins, immunoglobulin and other proteins.
When a blood clot starts contracting, a pale yellow fluid starts oozing out. Its name and composition are:

Plasma without the clotting factors is called serum. The clotting factors include fibrinogen and blood corpuscles.

Blood clotting normally occurs when there is damage to a blood vessel. Platelets immediately begin to adhere to the cut edges of the vessel and release chemicals to attract even more platelets. A platelet plug is formed, and the external bleeding stops.
Ramesh has Rh antigen and Anti-A as well as Anti-B antibodies in his blood. During blood transfusion, he can receive blood from:

Since he has both antibodies A and B and has Rh antigen and so has O+ blood group. So, he can receive blood from O positive blood group.

O positive red blood cells are not universally compatible to all types, but they are compatible to any red blood cells that are positive (A+, B+, O+, AB+). Over 80% of the population has a positive blood type and can receive O+ blood.
Which of the following represent examples of extracellular fluids?

Tissue fluid( lymph) and blood plasma represents the extracellular fluids. Lymph flows in lymphatic vessels and plasma in arteries and veins along with RBC, WBC and platelets.

The extracellular fluid, in turn, is composed of blood plasma, interstitial fluid, lymph and transcellular fluid (e.g. cerebrospinal fluid, synovial fluid, aqueous humour, serous fluid, gut fluid, etc.). The interstitial fluid and the blood plasma are the major components of the extracellular fluid.
The type of glands in which the entire glandular cell when filled with secretary products is discharged as a part of the secretion:

The type of glands in which the entire glandular cell when filled with secretary products is discharged as a part of the secretion is Holocrine.

Glandular epithelium cells are cuboidal in shape with multiple layers. A basement membrane is always present, which separates the epithelial tissue from the other tissues. The cells are uni-nucleate with a single large nucleus. Secretion is the main function of glandular epithelium.

The normal columnar epithelial cells specialize in the synthesis of chemicals such as enzymes, hormones, milk, mucus, sweat, wax, and saliva.

Glandular epithelium present in the intestinal lining helps in the absorption of nutrients.
Select the incorrect statement from the following:
Muscles play an active role in all the movements of the body.
Blood is the main circulating fluid that helps in the transport of various substances.
Compound epithelium provides protection against chemical and mechanical stress.
Adipose tissue serves as a support framework for epithelium.
The first three statements are true. The fourth statement is wrong. It is the areolar tissue that serves as a support framework for epithelium. Adipose tissue helps in storing fats.
The myelin sheath around the axon is produced by which type of cells?

The myelin sheath around the axon is produced by Schwann cells.

Myelin sheath is formed by oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system and by Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system. These cells wrap layer upon layer of their own plasma membrane in a tight spiral around axon. 

The insulating layer checks the leakage of charge and lesser stoppage points (nodes of Ranvier) leading to acceleration of the conduction of impulse and conservation of the metabolic energy.
Which of the following is a loose connective tissue?

Areolar tissue is a type of connective tissue, that takes part in the structural framework of the body.  It consists of a meshwork of collagen, elastic fibers, and reticular fibers with many connective tissue cells in between the meshwork of fibers. 

Fibroblasts, plasma cells, adipocytes, mast cells, and macrophages are the major cells of the areolar tissue. 

Adipose tissue helps in the storage of fat and protects the internal organs from injury. 

Both of them belong to the class of loose connective tissue.

On the other hand, blood is a type of fluid connective tissue.
Matrix of bone contains the space called _______.

Matrix of bone contains the space called Lacunae.

The small space in the matrix, containing an osteocyte in bone or chondrocyte in cartilage is called as Lacunae. The Lacunae are situated between the lamellae and consist of a number of oblong spaces. Each lacuna is occupied during life by a branched cell, termed an osteocyte, bone-cell or bone-corpuscle.

Strongest ligament of human body is Iliofemoral ligament.

Ligaments are the flexible connective tissue which mainly helps in the attachment of two bones. The iliofemoral ligament is a ligament of the hip joint, which extends from the ilium to the femur in front of the joint. It is also referred to as the Y-ligament. It has the highest tensile strength. This ligament is not only stronger than the two other ligaments of the hip joint, the ischiofemoral and the pubofemoral, but it is also the strongest ligament in the human body.

Ligaments- binds muscles to bone is mismatched.

Tendons are the tissues that join bones to muscles, while ligaments join bones to bones. Ligaments are basically bands of fibrous, flexible connective tissues. They also help to keep organs in their position.
Fibroblasts, macrophages and mast cells are present in __________.

Fibroblasts, macrophages and mast cells are present in Areolar tissue.

Cartilage is made up of specialized cells called chondrocytes. These chondrocytes produce large amounts of extracellular matrix composed of collagen fibers, proteoglycan, and elastin fibers.

Adipose tissue is loose connective tissue composed of fat cells known as adipocytes. Adipocytes contain lipid droplets of stored triglycerides.

The different kinds of cells present in areolar connective tissue are macrophages, mast cells, adipocytes, fibroblasts and plasma cells.

Glandular epithelium covers the endocrine and exocrine glands of the body. The main function is secretion.

Select the correct option:

Nervous tissue is made up of neurons and neuroglial cells. Which of the following statements about these two cells is/are false?

(i) Neuroglia makes up more than one-half of the volume of neural tissue in our body.

(ii) Neuroglia protects and supports neurons.

(iii) When a neuron is suitably stimulated, an electrical disturbance is generated which swiftly travels along its cytosol.

(iv) The arrival of the disturbance at the neuron's endings triggers stimulation or inhibition of adjacent neurons or other cells.

only (iii) statement about neurons and neuroglial cells is false.

Neuroglias are cells in the central nervous system and the peripheral nervous system. 

Along with neurons, they comprise the two types of cells in nervous tissue, and are integral to the functioning of the CNS and PNS. 

Neuroglias play the role of supportive cells to neurons, which are responsible for all nervous system functions.

When a neuron is suitably stimulated, an electrical disturbance is generated which swiftly travels along its plasma membrane. 

Arrival of the electrical impulse or stimulus at the nerve endings or output zone triggers events that may cause stimulation or inhibition of adjacent neurons and other cells.
Which tissue acts as first line of protection for body from any physical or chemical damage?
Epithelial Tissue acts as first line of protection for body from any physical or chemical damage. The outermost layer of the skin, the epidermis is an example of this tissue.
Which of the following classes of animal has/have a two-chambered heart?

Pisces have a two-chambered heart that has one auricle and one ventricle. 

Fish have a single circuit for blood flow and a two-chambered heart that has only a single atrium and a single ventricle.

  • Amphibians have a three-chambered heart that has two atria and one ventricle rather than the two-chambered heart of fish.
  • Reptiles, except crocodile, have three chambered heart.

Blood from the ventricle travels to the lungs and skin where it is oxygenated and also to the body. 

In the ventricle, deoxygenated and oxygenated blood are mixed before being pumped out of the heart.
Which among the following is NOT the characteristic feature of Smooth Muscle Fibres?

'These fibres are cylindrical in shape' is not the characteristic feature of Smooth Muscle Fibres.

Smooth muscle is an involuntary non-striated muscle found in the walls of hollow organs, such as the intestines, uterus and stomach.

  • These fibres are spindle-shaped and are pointed at both ends.
  • They bear a single nucleus which is central.
  • These are involuntary in nature and are also found in the tracts of the urinary, respiratory and reproductive systems.
  • These muscles also play an important role in the ducts of exocrine glands.
The storage of fats in animals occurs in which tissue?

The storage of fats in animals occurs in Adipocyte tissue.

Adipocytes, also known as lipocytes and fat cells, are the cells that primarily compose adipose tissue, specialized in storing energy as fat. Lying three layers deep under the skin, the adipose tissue is composed of a loose collection of specialized cells, called adipocytes, embedded in a mesh of collagen fibers.
Two bones can be connected to each other by another type of connective tissue called the ___________.

Two bones can be connected to each other by another type of connective tissue called the Ligament.

  • Ligament is the connective tissue which connects bone to bone.
  • Tendon connects muscle to bone and fasciae connects muscle to muscle.
  • Cartilage Smoothen bone surface at joints.
The tissue that is found below the skin and stores fat is:

The tissue that is found below the skin and stores fat is Adipose tissue.

Adipose Tissue is a specialized type of connective tissue. These tissues have oval-shaped cells called adipocytes which are present below the skin surface WHite adipose tissue - present in and stores lipids or fats. The fat collected is in the form of a fat globule.
Which of the following are microscopic motile asexual reproductive structures?

Zoospores are microscopic, motile and asexual spores. They have flagella for locomotion. Many protists, bacteria, algae and fungi reproduce asexually through the formation of zoospores.

In most zoosporic fungi the highly motile zoospore is an asexual propagule well adapted for short range dispersal in water (Sparrow 1960). Its function is to deliver the protoplasm quickly to an appropriate digestible substrate.

Ulothrix being an haploid organism, shows zygotic meiosis. Zygote is the only diploid structure which undergoes meiosis to form four haploid quadriflagellate zoospores. Each zoospore develops into a new Ulothrix thallus.
Rotation of body during metamorphosis is at 90 degree in:

Rotation of body during metamorphosis is at 90 degree in herdmania.

  • Herdmania is a genus of ascidian tunicates in the family Pyuridae.
  • Herdmania is a sedentary filter feeding tunicate found in marine habitats. The animal often occurs in gregorious form.
During the process of evolution, development of trichogyne of algae could be traced as:

During the process of evolution, development of trichogyne of algae could be traced as style of angiosperm.

A hairlike terminal process forming the receptive part of the female reproductive structure in certain fungi and algae. A hairlike terminal process forming the receptive part of the female reproductive structure in certain fungi and algae.
Reproduction is the process of generating offsprings. Various unicellular organisms reproduce by:

Nicellular organisms reproduce by asexual means. This asexual mode of reproduction involves single parent to produce their offspring. Different types of asexual modes of reproduction include binary fission, multiple fission, fragmentation, budding etc.
Which of the following is correct for sexual reproduction?
Fusion of one male and one female gamete
Fusion of one male and two polar nuclei

Sexual reproduction is the process in which two parents are involved which produce two types of gamete i.e., male and female. The gametes fuse to form the zygote during fertilization. This is a compulsory event which allows the continuation of the species.
Which of the following statements is/are incorrect about fungal reproduction?
Spores germinate in the presence of moisture.

"Sporangium contains numerous hyphae." is incorrect about fungal reproduction.

Most fungi reproduce by forming spores that can survive extreme conditions such as cold and lack of water. Both sexual meiotic and asexual mitotic spores may be produced, depending on the species and conditions. Most fungi life cycles consist of both a diploid and a haploid stage.
In bryophyllum, new plants arise from buds present on the margin of:

In bryophyllum, new plants arise from buds present on the margin of leaf.

Vegetation propagation in Bryophyllum takes place through leaves of the plant which has notches at its margins. Buds arises from the notches of the leaves and later when they drop on the soil, a new plant develops.

Match the following:

P. Rhizopus 1. Egg
Q. Anther 2. Pollen grain
R. Ovule 3. Spore

The correct match is: P - 3, Q - 2, R - 1

  • Rhizopus is the species of a fungus. They reproduce asexually by the formation of the spores. The body of the fungus is composed of hyphae which develop the sporangium. The sporangium is a swollen structure at the tip of the filaments bearing the spores.
  • In angiosperms, pollen is produced by the anthers of the stamens in flowers. In gymnosperms, it is formed in the microsporophylls of the microstrobili (male pollen cones). Pollen consists of one or more vegetative cells and a reproductive cell. A pollen grain itself is not the male gamete.
  • In animals, egg cells are also known as ova (singular ovum, from the Latin word ovum meaning 'egg'). The term ovule in animals is used for the young ovum of an animal.

Match the following:

P. Spirogyra 1. Vegetative propagation
Q. Rose 2. Fragmentation
R. Planaria 3. Sexual reproduction
S. Human 4. Regeneration

The correct match is: P - 2, Q - 1, R - 4, S - 3

  • Fragmentation is a type of asexual reproduction in Spirogyra, in which an organism simply breaks into individual pieces at maturity.
  • The propagation of roses can be performed by different ways : - By plant division and layering (for hardwood species).
  • Regeneration in planarians depends on the presence of stem cells called neoblasts. These cells are distributed throughout the body and, when part of the worm has been amputated, they are activated to reform the tissues that have been removed (Wagner et al., 2011).
  • Humans reproduce sexually by the uniting of the female and male sex cells. Although the reproductive systems of the male and female are different, they are structured to function together to achieve internal fertilization.
The filament of spirogyra divides into many pieces.
In amoeba, splitting of cells can take place in any plane.
Fission in Leishmania can occur in any plane.

"Fission in Leishmania can occur in any plane." is false statement.

In Leishmania, binary fission occurs in a definite orientation: Nuclear division is followed by the appearance of a constriction in the cell membrane. The membrane grows transversely inwards from the middle of the dividing cell. Cytoplasm separates into two equal parts having one nucleus each.
Which of the following organisms can reproduce new organisms by regeneration?

Planaria can reproduce new organisms by regeneration.

Planaria have the ability to give rise to new individuals from their body parts. This process is called regeneration. If the body of Planaria is somehow cut or broken up into many pieces, each piece grows into a complete organism.

Match the following:

a. Regeneration1. It is the process of getting back a full organism from its body part. 
b. Fragmentation2. It is the process in which new plants are obtained from the parts of old plants without the help of any reproductive organs. 
c. Vegetative propagation3. It is the process of breaking up of the body of a simple multicellular organism into two or more pieces on maturing, each of which subsequently grows to form a complete new organism.

The correct match is a - 1, b - 3, c - 2.

a. Regeneration: 1. It is the process of getting back a full organism from its body part.

b. Fragmentation: 3. It is the process of breaking up of the body of a simple multicellular organism into two or more pieces on maturing, each of which subsequently grows to form a completely new organism.

c. Vegetative propagation: 2. It is the process in which new plants are obtained from the parts of old plants without the help of any reproductive organs.
Which of the following is a unicellular animal having short thread-like structures called cilia over its surface?

Paramecium is a unicellular animal having short thread-like structures called cilia over its surface.

Paramecium, genus of microscopic, single-celled, and free-living protozoans. Most species can be cultivated easily in the laboratory, making them ideal model organisms, well suited for biological study. Paramecium vary in length from about 0.05 to 0.32 mm (0.002 to 0.013 inch). Their basic shape is an elongated oval with rounded or pointed ends, such as in P. caudatum. The term paramecium is also used to refer to individual organisms in a Paramecium species. Paramecium is the only genus in the family Parameciidae, which resides within the phylum Ciliophora.
Vegetative reproduction is done by using tubers in:

Vegetative reproduction is done by using tubers in potato.

In potato, the underground stem stores starch and becomes a fleshy tuber. The eyes of the tuber represent nodes and adventitious buds are present in their axil. The buds may germinate to produce new plantlets.
Reproduction is an essential life process, which help in:

Reproduction is an essential life process, which help in continuity of race.

All living organisms have the feature or character of reproduction. This is an important life process that not only helps in survival but also helps in the continuity of that race and group immortality, as by reproduction. Reproduction also helps in increasing the population of the species.
The period of pregnancy is known as:

The period of pregnancy is known as "Gestation period".

The gestation period is how long a woman is pregnant. Most babies are born between 38 and 42 weeks of gestation. Babies born before 37 weeks are considered premature. Babies born after 42 weeks are called postmature.
Some scientist consider virus as living entities because they can:

Some scientist consider virus as living entities because they can reproduce inside the host.

The only point favouring the virus as living entities is that they have the ability to reproduce (multiply) within the host by using host's machinery. The only point favouring the viruses as living entities is that they have the ability to reproduce (multiply) though in the host using host's machinery.

Ostrich is a large sized bird. It is not able to fly long distance. The egg of ostrich is considered largest cell which is about one meter in diameter.

Ostriches are large flightless birds of the genus Struthio in the order Struthioniformes, part of the infra-class Palaeognathae, a diverse group of flightless birds also known as ratites that includes the emus, rheas, and kiwis. There are two living species of ostrich: the common ostrich and the Somali ostrich.
The period from birth to death of an organism represents:

The period from birth to death of an organism represents life span.

The period from birth of an individual to its natural death is called life span. Different organisms have different life span starting from one day to hundreds of years.

Which of the following are correct?

(i) Sponges : Cellular level of organisation

(ii) Cnidaria : Tissue level of organisation

(iii) Platyhelminthes : Organ level of organisation

(iv) Annelids, Arthropods, Molluscs, Echinoderms and Chordates : Organ system level of organisation.

All are correct.

Animals show four different grades of organization:

(i) Protoplasmic grade found in protozoans.

(ii) Cellular grade is the characteristic of sponges and mesozoans because in a sponge, cells exhibit division of labour for performing specialized functions.

(iii) Tissue grade is of two types : Cell-tissue grade is seen in coelenterates as there are cells not only specialised for different functions but also certain similar cells gather together to form tissue as well. Tissue - organ grade appears in flatworms (Platyhelminthes) with arrangement of tissues to form organs.

(iv) In organ system level of organisation, organs are joined in a system to perform basic functions. It is found in higher invertebrates and all vertebrates.
Functional systems for specific physiological functions are not seen in ______.
Functional systems for specific physiological functions are not seen in coelenterates because of the absence of organ system level of body organisation. They have tissue system organization.
When the body of the animal can be divided into identical halves in only one plane then it is termed as:

When the body of the animal can be divided into identical halves in only one plane then it is termed as Bilateral symmetry.

If the body of an animal cannot be divided into identical halves, then the animal is called asymmetric. Example - Sponges

If the body of the animal can be divided into identical halves in only one plane, then the animal is called bilaterally symmetrical. Example - Flatworms and roundworms

If the body of the animal can be divided into identical halves along many planes, i.e. multiple radii, then the animal is called radially symmetrical. Example- Coelenterates and Cnidarians

If the body of the animal can be divided into identical halves along only two planes, i.e., only two radii then the animal is said to be biradially symmetrical. Example - Sea anemone
Which of the following statement can be related to mesoglea and mesoderm?
Mesoglea is an undifferentiated layer present between the ectoderm and endoderm.
Mesoderm is formed through a process of gastrulation.

All of the above relates to mesoglea and mesoderm.

A) Mesoglea is the gelatinous material between the outer layer (ectoderm) and inner cellular layer (endoderm) of jellyfish and other coelenterates and it is undifferentiated. 

B) The mesoderm forms the middle layer of the early trilaminar embryo germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm). It is absent in diploblastic animals.

C) Mesoderm is formed through a process of gastrulation.
Which of the following animal phyla does not possess a coelom?

Platyhelminthes animal phyla does not possess a coelom.

Flatworms are acoelomates that are characterized by having three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) and lacking respiratory and circulatory systems. Acoelomates are invertebrates that do not have a coelom, or body cavity. With about 25,000 known species, flatworms are the largest phylum of acoelomates. Platyhelminths are thought to be the first invertebrates to have a third germ layer, the mesoderm.
An important characteristic that Hemichordates share with Chordates is _______.

An important characteristic that Hemichordates share with Chordates is Pharynx with gill slits.

Animal belongs to phylum Chordata is characterized by the presence of the notochord, dorsal hollow nerve cord and pharyngeal gill slits. Hemichordata is the phylum of animals that shows certain similar characters of the Chordata such as the presence of pharyngeal gill slits.
Which one of the following group of animals is bilaterally symmetrical and triploblastic?

Aschelminthes group of animals is bilaterally symmetrical and triploblastic.

Animal are classified on the basis of symmetry of body plan and germ layers if the body plan is made up of three germ layers called as triploblastic and if it made up of two germ layers called as diploblastic. Aschelminthes are bilaterally symmetrical and triploblastic.
Which of the following characters is that of Ctenophora?

Bioluminisence character is that of Ctenophora.

The character that matched with Ctenophora is Bioluminescence. Ctenophora is a phylum under the kingdom Animalia. They are commonly known as sea walnuts or comb jellies. They are exclusively marine, radially symmetrical, diploblastic organisms with tissue level of organisation. The body bears eight eterna\rows of ciliated comb plates which help in locomotion.
In which class of Coelenterate, the polyp and medusa both are found in one animal?

In hydrozoa class of Coelenterate, the polyp and medusa both are found in one animal.

Hydrozoa Cnidarians exhibit two basic body forms called polyp and medusa. 

The former is a sessile and cylindrical form like Hydra, Adamsia, etc. whereas, the latter is umbrella-shaped and free-swimming like Aurelia or jellyfish. These Cnidarians, which exist in both forms exhibit alternation of generation (Metagenesis), i.e., polyps produce medusae asexually and medusae form the polyps sexually (e.g., Obelia).
Which of the following phyla includes diploblastic, aquatic animals with tissue grade of organization?

Phylum Coelenterata (cnidaria) includes tentacle bearing, aquatic, acoelomate, diploblastic, radially symmetrical animals. The phylum Cnidaria is characterized by following characters:

(1) Members are mostly marine.

(2) Usually radially symmetrical in the adult stage.

(3) possess tissue level of body organization. 

As the given characters represent the phylum Coelenterata (Cnidaria).
Which of the following mostly shows sexual dimorphism?

Ascaris and Oryctolagus mostly shows sexual dimorphism.

Ascaris is a member of the phylum Aschelminthes. It shows sexual dimorphism. The male and the female can be identified from their external features. Males have a posteriorly curved tail with a pineal spicule whereas, the female has a long and straight tail. Females also have gonophore.

Oryctolagus is the European Rabbit. It is a member of mammals belonging to the phylum Chordata. It shows sexual dimorphism. The males have testes whereas the females have ovaries.
In Poriferans, the spongocoel is lined with flagellated cells called:

In Poriferans, the spongocoel is lined with flagellated cells called choanocytes.

Spongocoel is a large central cavity in the sponges. Water enters through the numerous ostium in the cavity and exit by a central pore known as osculum. Choanocytes are the flagellated cells which line the spongocoel. It helps to set up water current and helps in intake of food.
Which of the following features is not present in the phylum Arthropoda?

Parapodia features is not present in the phylum Arthropoda.

The exoskeleton of arthropods is chitinous, with metameric segmentation and jointed appendages. The Parapodia, on the other hand, is mostly employed for locomotion and respiration. In the case of Arthropods, both procedures are performed by their appendages. As a result, Arthropods lack parapodia.
Which of the following characteristics is not shared by birds and mammals?

Viviparity characteristics is not shared by birds and mammals.

Both mammals and birds can regulate body temperature and have warm-blooded nature. They have lungs and hence use them for breathing. Both the groups have ossified endoskeletons (formation of bones by adding osteoblasts - osteogenesis, results in an ossified endoskeleton.)

But birds lay eggs and show oviparity whereas mammals give birth to live young and show viviparity (except Monotremes or egg-laying mammals).
Water vascular system is the characteristic of which group among the following:

Water vascular system is the characteristic of Echinodermata.

Echinoderms have a water-driven tube system that the members of this phylum use for their locomotion. This system is also known as the water vascular system. It also helps in food capturing.
A jawless fish, which lays eggs in freshwater and whose ammocoetes larvae after metamorphosis return to the ocean is:

A jawless fish, which lays eggs in freshwater and whose ammocoetes larvae after metamorphosis return to the ocean is petromyzon.

Petromyzon are marine but migrate for spawning to fresh water. After spawning, within a few days, they die. Their ammocoete larvae, after metamorphosis, return to the ocean.
________ is an animal which lives in both aquatic and terrestrial habitat in the course of its life.

Frog is an animal which lives in both aquatic and terrestrial habitat in the course of its life.

Frogs lay their eggs in water. The eggs hatch into tadpoles, which look very different from frogs. The tadpoles live exclusively in the water and breathe through gills instead of lungs like an adult frog.

The process of changing from a tadpole into an adult frog is called metamorphosis.The lungs grow and the frogs are able to breathe in air too. During this time, the frogs live in terrestrial habitat.
Which of the following reptile is with four chambers in heart?

The crocodiles are the only reptiles that have a 4-chambered heart. It is somewhat like birds, a unidirectional looping system of airflow within the lungs, but like other reptiles they are ectotherms. There are two auricles and two ventricle where the oxygenated and deoxygenated blood remains separated.
Which among the following organism has mammary glands for the production of milk to nourish their young ones?

Bats has mammary glands for the production of milk to nourish their young ones.

Bats belong to class Mammalia, as have mammary glands to produce milk to nourish their young one. Owls, parrot and turtles do not have mammary glands and they do not belong to class Mammalia.

To which classes do the following animals belong?

A-Petromyzon, B-Scoliodon, C-Pristis
Petromyzon (Lamprey) is an example of Class Cyclostomata. Scoliodon (Dogfish) and Pristis (Sawfish) are examples of Class Chondrichthyes.

In human pancreas secretes pancreatic juice. Match the pairs of enzyme and its function present in it.

EnzymeFunction
(1) Amylase(a) Digestion of fat
(2) Trypsin(b) Digestion of protein
(3) Lipase(c) Digestion of starch

EnzymeFunction
(1) Amylase(c) Digestion of starch
(2) Trypsin(b) Digestion of protein
(3) Lipase(a) Digestion of fat

Salivary amylase is the enzyme produced by salivary glands that initiate the digestion of starch in the mouth. Further pancreatic amylase digests starch in the small intestine.

Trypsinogen is the proenzyme produced in the pancreas. Trypsinogen is converted to trypsin in the small intestine that digests protein.

Lipase enzyme produced by the pancreas that hydrolysis fats in the small intestine.

Fat is completely digested in the small intestine.

Digestion of some fats can begin in the mouth where lingual lipase breaks down some short chain lipids into diglycerides. However, fats are completely digested in the small intestine. Fat is completely digested in the small intestine because it gets bile from the liver through the gallbladder which is responsible for fat digestion. So, fat is completely digested in the small intestine.
The functional unit for absorption of digested food is:

The functional unit for absorption of digested food is villi.

The lining of the small intestine is provided with many folds. These folds have finger-like projections called villi. These increase the surface area of the small intestine for more absorption of the nutrients from the digested food.

Water is absorbed mainly in large intestine, which turns undigested food into a coherent mass of feces. Colon absorbs water from the undigested food. Due to presence of Haustra the water absorbing surface of colon increases and it efficiently increases absorption of water.
The actual site of gaseous exchange in the human respiratory system is:

The actual site of gaseous exchange in the human respiratory system is alveoli.

The primary function of the respiratory system is to exchange oxygen \(\left( O _{2}\right)\) and carbon dioxide \(\left( CO _{2}\right)\). The external nostrils up to the terminal bronchioles constitute the conducting part whereas the alveoli and their ducts form the respiratory or exchange part of the respiratory system. The conducting part transports the atmospheric air to the alveoli. Exchange part is the site of actual diffusion of \(O _{2}\) and \(CO _{2}\) between blood and atmospheric air. The alveolus is richly supplied with blood capillaries which allow the exchange of gases through it.
In which part of the body blood gets purified (becomes oxygenated)?

In lungs blood gets purified (becomes oxygenated).

Deoxygenated (unpurified) blood comes into the right atrium of the heart through the superior and inferior vena cava which is then passed to the right ventricle and then to the lungs by the pulmonary artery. In the lungs, this blood gets oxygenated (purified) which then goes into the left atrial chamber of the heart from which blood is passed to the aorta and then circulated to the whole body.

Breathing involves expansion and contraction off lungs to adjust the partial pressure of relative gases for exchange. The process of inhalation occurs due to an increase in the lung volume (diaphragm contraction and chest wall expansion) which results in a decrease in lung pressure in comparison to the atmosphere. Thus, air rushes in the airway. The process of exhalation occurs due to an elastic recoil of the lung tissue which causes a decrease in volume, resulting in increased pressure in comparison to the atmosphere. Thus, air rushes out of the airway.
Which of the following is not a function of kidneys?

Secretion of antibiotics is not a function of kidneys.

The kidneys remove excess organic molecules from the blood, which are the waste products of metabolism. They are also essential in controlling homeostatic functions, such as the regulation of electrolytes, maintenance of acid-base balance, and regulation of blood pressure (via maintaining salt and water balance). They serve the body as a natural filter of the blood, and remove water soluble wastes. The kidneys also produce hormones, including calcitriol, erythropoietin, and the enzyme renin.
Which one of the following is not an effect of sympathetic nervous system?
Stimulation for saliva secretion during digestion or eating

Stimulation for saliva secretion during digestion or eating is not an effect of sympathetic nervous system.

The sympathetic nervous system is involved in the stimulation of activities that prepare the body for action, such as increasing the heart rate, increasing the release of sugar from the liver into the blood, and other generally considered as fight-or-flight responses (responses that serve to fight off or retreat from danger). The parasympathetic nervous system activates tranquil functions, such as stimulating the secretion of saliva or digestive enzymes into the stomach.
Which of the following has non-myelinated nerve fiber?

Autonomic nerves has non-myelinated nerve fiber.

Myelin sheath is a fatty acid containing a white creamy layer that forms cover the axons of myelinated fibres. These nerve fibres carry out fast and saltatory conduction of nerve impulse and are found in cranial and spinal nerves. The optic nerve is a cranial nerve. Autonomic nerves are non-myelinated fibres that lack myelin sheath and carry out slow but smooth conduction of nerve impulse.
The correct order of the flow of blood through the heart, entering from vena cava is:
Left atrium \(\rightarrow\) left ventricle \(\rightarrow\) right ventricle \(\rightarrow\) right atrium
Left ventricle \(\rightarrow\) left atrium \(\rightarrow\) right atrium \(\rightarrow\) right ventricle
Right atrium \(\rightarrow\) right ventricle \(\rightarrow\) left atrium \(\rightarrow\) left ventricle
Right ventricle \(\rightarrow\) right atrium \(\rightarrow\) left atrium \(\rightarrow\) left ventricle

Humans have double circulation: one is systemic circulation and other is pulmonary circulation. In systemic circulation, oxygenated blood moves from heart to all parts of the body. In pulmonary circulation, deoxygenated blood is pumped by the heart to get oxygenated in lungs. All the deoxygenated blood from the body comes to the right atrium and it moves to the right ventricle from there and finally to the lungs carried by pulmonary trunk. From lungs, oxygenated blood enters left atrium to go to left ventricle to be carried by aorta to whole body. The correct order of the flow of blood through the heart, entering from vena cava is:

Right atrium \(\rightarrow\) right ventricle \(\rightarrow\) left atrium \(\rightarrow\) left ventricle

Direction: The following questions consist of two statements, one labelled as Assertion and the other Reason. Examine both the statements carefully and mark the correct choice according to the instructions given below.

Assertion: In mammals, a complex respiratory system has developed.

Reason: Mammalian skin is impermeable to gases.
Both Assertion and Reason are correct and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are correct but Reason is not the correct explanation for Assertion
Assertion is correct but Reason is incorrect

The respiratory system is a biological system consisting of specific organs and structures used for gas exchange in animals and mammals. Mammals have developed a  complex respiratory system to get more oxygen to maintain their high metabolic rates. Therefore, mammals have a complex respiratory system. Mammalian skin is impermeable to gases so that water loss through it is minimized.

So, both Assertion and Reason are correct but Reason is not the correct explanation for Assertion.
The _____ checks the entry of food into the respiratory tract.

The epiglottis checks the entry of food into the respiratory tract.

The epiglottis is elastic cartilage covered with a mucous membrane located at the entrance of the larynx and the base of the tongue. The epiglottis is the flap-like structure that acts as the covering above the trachea which prevents the entry of food into the respiratory system during eating. This flap opens during the process of respiration when the air is taken in and given out. It opens to allows the air to move in and out of the tracheal system. If the food by error enters into the tracheal system, the food is expelled out by coughing. It is shaped like a leaf and guards the entrance of the glottis (the opening between the vocal cords). When we swallow food, the epiglottis folds over the glottis to stop liquid and food from entering the trachea. Thus, food goes right to the esophagus so that one would not get choked.
The glomerulus, Bowman's capsule and efferent vessel

The malpighian body is constituted by Glomerulus and Bowman's capsule.

Nephrons are the cells of the kidney which are composed of a renal corpuscle and a renal tubule.  The renal corpuscle is also known Malpighian body. It consists of cup-like double-walled structure known as Bowman’s capsule and the bunch of capillaries present in Bowman’s capsule is known as the glomerulus.
Filtration of the blood takes place at:

Filtration of the blood takes place in the malpighian body.

Each nephron has two parts glomerulus and renal tubule. The glomerulus is a tuft of capillaries formed by afferent arteriole. The renal tubule begins with a double-walled cup-like structure called Bowman's capsule, which encloses the glomerulus. The glomerulus along with Bowman's capsule is called the Malpighian body or renal corpuscle. The tube continues further to form PCT, a loop of Henle and DCT. The first step in urine formation is the filtration of blood which is carried out by the Malpighian body.
Removal of useless substances and substances present in excess
Formation of those substances which have some role in the body
Removal of such substances which have never been part of the body

Excretion is the process by which the body gets rid of waste products and the nitrogenous by-products of metabolism. Through excretion, organisms control osmotic pressure, the balance between inorganic ions and water, and maintain acid-base balance. The process thus promotes homeostasis.
The hormone of hypothalamus is called as:

A releasing hormone or releasing factor is a hormone, whose main purpose is to control the release of other hormones. These are also called as hypophysiotropic or hypothalamic hormones. 

The main releasing hormones secreted by the hypothalamus are: thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH), corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH).
The ability to move from one place to another is called:

Locomotion is when the movement of a part of the body leads to a change in the position and location of the organism. In multicellular animals, these movements include walking, running, jumping, crawling, climbing, swimming, flying, galloping, slithering, and so on. So, the ability to move from one place to another is called locomotion.
Which of the following is not a biological function of the skeleton?

The human skeleton is the internal framework of the body. It is composed of around 270 bones at birth this total decreases to around 206 bones by adulthood after some bones get fused together.  The skeleton serves six major functions: support, movement, protection, production of blood cells, storage of minerals and endocrine regulation. So, Excretion is not a biological function of the skeleton.
The cells of the human body exhibits type of movement are:

The cells of the human body exhibit type of movement are Amoeboid, Ciliary, and Muscular.

Movement is a characteristic feature of living organisms. The different types of movement exhibited by cells of the human body are: 

  • Amoeboid movement: Leucocytes present in the blood show amoeboid movement. 
  • Ciliary movement: Reproductive cells such as sperms and ova show ciliary movement.
  • Muscular movements:  Muscle tissue found inside of the heart, digestive organs, and blood vessels serve to move substances throughout the body.
How do muscles attached to the bones move the body?

The Muscles work by contraction and relaxation this represents that muscles can pull bones, but they can't push them back to the original position. For this reason, muscles are often arranged in pairs that pull bones in opposite directions. So, muscles attached to the bones move the body by pull movement only.
Cerebellum, medulla oblongata and pons are the part of:

The human brain is divided into forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain. The hind-brain in humans consists of three parts cerebellum, pons, and medulla oblongata. It helps in the control and coordination of the right and left part of the body. It is also a regulatory site for several involuntary actions like respiration.

The Purkinje cells are the neurons that are present in the cerebellum, part of the hindbrain. The cell body of these neurons has many dendritic fibres. The parallel fibres in the cerebellum form association and synapses with these cells. The neurons have GABA as the neurotransmitter and are important in the regulation of the motor activities in the individual.

The epiphysis is connected with the brow spot in the embryo.

The epiphysis or the pineal body is an endocrine gland that develops from the roof of the diencephalon. During embryo development, it is connected with the brow spot in the embryo. The brow spot is the region between the two eyes. The cells are considered to be the modified neurological cells. It secretes a hormone called melatonin that regulates the diurnal cycle of the body.
The brain stem is made up of:

The brain stem is made up of the midbrain, pons, medulla oblongata.

The brain stem controls the flow of messages between the brain and the rest of the body, and it also controls basic body functions such as breathing, swallowing, heart rate etc. The brainstem is divided into three sections in humans: the midbrain (mesencephalon) which governs rudimentary vision and hearing, pons Varolii (metencephalon) which links the cerebellum to the cerebrum and the medulla oblongata (myelencephalon) which controls breathing, swallowing, blood pressure, and heart rate.

Direction: The following questions consist of two statements, one labelled as Assertion and the other Reason. Examine both the statements carefully and mark the correct choice according to the instructions given below.

Assertion: Arteries carry blood from various body organs to the heart.

Reason: Veins carry blood from various body organs to the heart.
Both Assertion and Reason are correct and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are correct but Reason is not the correct explanation for Assertion
Assertion is correct but Reason is incorrect
Assertion is incorrect but Reason is correct

Arteries carry oxygenated blood from the heart to different parts of the body, except for the pulmonary artery that carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs. The veins carry deoxygenated blood from different parts of the body to the heart except for the pulmonary vein that carries oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart. 

Therefore, assertion is false, but reason is true.
Angina pectoris is a major symptom of:

Angina pectoris is a major symptom of myocardial infarction.

Angina pectoris is a clinical syndrome resulting from a deficit of oxygen in the living tissue of the heart. It is characterized by the presence of chest pain or discomfort of a constricting or suffocating quality. Angina pectoris is commonly caused by myocardial ischemia and occurs when the cells of the heart muscle need more oxygen.
The conduction of impulse takes from SA node to:

Signals arising in the SA node (located in the right atrium) stimulate the atria to contract and travel to the AV node, which is located in the interatrial septum. After a delay, the stimulus diverges and is conducted through the left and right bundle of His to the respective Purkinje fibres for each side of the heart, as well as to the endocardium at the apex of the heart, then finally to the ventricular epicardium.
What are the functions of gastric glands present in the wall of the stomach?
Production of pepsin enzyme that digests proteins
Secretion of mucus for protection of inner lining of the stomach
Secretion of HCl, which kills the bacteria and foreign harmful organisms in the food

Gastric glands are present in the wall of the stomach which secrete gastric juice containing the digestive enzyme like pepsin, renin, mucus and HCl. The function of these enzymes are as follows:

  • Production of pepsin enzyme that digests proteins.
  • Secretion of mucus for the protection of the inner lining of the stomach.
  • Secretion of HCl, which kills the bacteria and foreign harmful organisms in the food.
Which one of the following enzymes initiates protein digestion?

Pepsin initiates protein digestion.

Protein digestion first begins in the stomach, where pepsinogen is converted to active form pepsin, by hydrochloric acid. Pepsin breaks proteins down into polypeptides.
Casparian strips are the bands of thickenings present on ____ walls of endodermis.

Casparian strips are the bands of thickenings present on radial and tangential walls of endodermis.

Endodermis is the innermost layer of cortex that consists of tightly packed barrel shaped cells. It is called starch sheath in case of dicot stems. Radial and tangential walls of endodermal cells possess thickenings of lignin, suberin and cutin in the form of strips or bands, which are known as Casparian bands or Casparian strips.

Which of these characters does/do not apply to the vascular bundle of monocot stem?

I. Conjoint

II. Endarch protoxylem 

III. Open 

IV. Phloem parenchyma is absent

Vascular bundles of monocot stem are conjoint, collateral (xylem, phloem both present together on the same radius) but closed i.e. they lack cambium hence secondary growth is absent. Phloem consists of sieve tubes, companion cells and a few phloem fibres. Phloem parenchyma is absent.

The fusiform initials are elongated cells, which results in the production of cells that form the vertical system of the secondary phloem and xylem, tracheary elements, fibers, sieve cells, and the associated companion cells. The ray initials are isodiametric cells that are equal in all dimensions, which are likely to produce the vascular rays, and comprise the horizontal system of secondary tissues, which helps in the translocation and storage of food and water.

These cell aids in the divisions of the fusiform and ray initials are primarily tangential, as the new cells are regularly replaced and arranged in well-defined radial rows, which results in the characteristic pattern of the secondary vascular tissues.

The fusiform initials result in the formation of tracheary elements such as tracheid’s, vessels, fibers, sieve tubes. Xylem consists of three major types of cells, the tracheary elements, xylem parenchyma cells, and xylem fiber cells. One of the major cell types in wood-forming xylem is the tracheary elements. They help in conducting water and are responsible for distributing raw sap throughout the plant body. These cells are dead as they mature. The specialized vascular cells form hollow tubes with thickened lignified walls of the secondary cell wall that provide the major structural element in wood.
Wound healing in plants is initiated by:

Wound healing in plants is initiated by secondary meristem.

A secondary meristem is a form of meristematic tissue in plants that is responsible for secondary growth, such as girth or thickness expansion. It is in opposition to the primary meristem, which is engaged in primary growth, such as height or length growth. As a result, unlike the primary meristem, a secondary meristem promotes lateral development rather than vertical growth. It is further distinguished from the primary meristem by the fact that it is formed from permanent tissue. The meristem that develops secondarily from the permanent tissue is known as a secondary meristem. The activity of secondary meristems aids in wound healing in plants.

A.Open, collateral, endarch vascular bundles – dicot stem.

B.closed, collateral, endarch vascular bundles – monocot stem

C.open, collateral, exarch – Not found in any part of the plant body.

D.Closed, collateral, exarch – Not found in any part of the plant body.

Trichomes are the multicellular hair like structure present mostly on stem and leaves originate from the epidermal layer.

The function of trichomes:-

  • They are glandular.
  • Protects the plant from sunlight and outer injuries.
  • Prevent plant from water loss.
  • helps plant in defense against insects.

The meristem can be classified into three types on the basis of function they perform:-

1) Protoderm is the outermost layer of the growing region that forms epidermal tissues in plants.

2) Procambium is composed of narrow, elongated meristematic cells that form the vascular tissues in plants.

3) Ground meristem is composed of thick-walled and large cells that form the ground tissues.

Procambium is a meristematic tissue which forms the primary tissues in the vascular system.

These are continuously dividing cells which responsible for producing the vascular tissues in plants to form the primary xylem and primary phloem in mature stems and root.
Which of the following statement is not a difference between monocots and dicots?
Dicot seeds have two cotyledons and monocot seeds have only one cotyledon.
Dicots show tap root system and monocots show fibrous root system.
In dicots, the flowers are unisexual and in monocots flowers are bisexual.
Dicot leaves show reticulate venation and monocot leaves show parallel venation.

MonocotDicot
Seeds with a single cotyledon.Seeds with two cotyledons.
Pollen with single furrow or pore.Pollen with three furrows or pores.
Flower parts in multiples of three.Flower parts in multiples of four or five.
Major leaf veins parallel.Major leaf veins reticulated.

Roots are adventitious.Roots develop from radicle.

Cambium of the root is the example of:

The primary meristems are derived from the embryonic cells.

Primary meristem gives rise to the primary plant body. The cells produced by the primary meristem become permanent later in the life of the plant producing permanent tissues.

The vascular (fascicular) cambium and the cork cambium are examples of lateral meristematic tissue. - These lateral tissues are secondary in origin as they are formed from the permanent tissues. When the cells of the permanent tissues under the influence of hormones and other physiological factors start dedifferentiating into actively dividing meristematic cells, lateral meristems are formed. The cambium is a strip of meristematic tissue undergoing active division when activated. The intrafascicular cambium is present in between the xylem tissue and phloem tissue of the vascular bundle of dicots.
