Which tissue cell wall is made of cellulose and pectin?

Collenchyma tissue cell wall is made of cellulose and pectin.

The collenchyma is the permanent tissue found in dicot plants which provide mechanical support to the plant. It consists of cells which are much thickened at the corners due to a deposition of cellulose, hemicellulose, and pectin.

The walls of parenchyma are thin and only made up of cellulose whereas the walls of sclerenchyma are thickened and composed of cellulose.
The organization of the shoot apex into tunica and corpus is determined largely on the basis of _______________.

The organization of the shoot apex into tunica and corpus is determined largely on the basis of rate of cell division.

Schmidt has postulated tunica- corpus theory on the basis of studies of shoot apices of angiosperm. This theory is concerned with planes of cell division in the apex. In contrast to apical cell theory, the tunica-corpus theory is applicable only to shoot apex and not to root. There are three types of meristematic tissues like apical (at the tips), intercalary (in the middle) and third as lateral (at the sides).

Schmidt distinguished two tissue zones in the shoot apex and termed as tunica and corpus.
Which of the following is a dead mechanical tissue?
Sclerenchyma is the dead mechanical tissue with poor water content. The cell walls are heavily thickened by lignin. It is an important permanent tissue mainly meant for the mechanical functions.

Periblem gives rise to cortex.

Periblem is a primary meristem that gives rise to the cortex and is located between plerome and dermatogen. It is also called as nascent cortex.
Which of the following statements describes monocotyledons?

The monocotyledonous plants have the adventitious or the fibrous type of root system that do not grow much deeper but spread in the region widely to provide support the plant.

Parallel venation is where the secondary veins run parallel to each other and are connected laterally by the minute and straight veinlets. This type of venation is mostly seen in monocots. They show the presence of a single cotyledon.
Which among the following statements is/are correct regarding dicot leaf?
Vascular bundle is surrounded by parenchymatous bundle sheath

Dicot leaves are dorsiventral. The bulliform cells are absent. The vascular bundle is surrounded by parenchymatous bundle sheath. Mesophyll is differentiated into palisade and spongy parenchyma. Hence, all the statements are correct regarding dicot leaf.
The tissue present in all organs of plant is
Generally all the organs of plant are made up of parenchyma cells.
Which meristem contributes to the formation of the primary plant body?
Both apical meristems and intercalary meristems are primary meristems because they appear early in life of a plant and contribute to the formation of the primary plant body.
Scleroids belongs to sclerenchyma complex permanent tissue presentin hard parts of plants. They are generally hard and founds in rough fruits and stem.
The parenchymatous cells which lie between the xylem and the phloem are called
Conjunctive tissue is a narrow strip of tissue ( parenchyma or sclerenchyma) that lies between xylem and phloem bundles of root.
A speciallised parenchymatous cells, which are closely associated with sieve tube elements is

The companion cells are specialised parenchymatous cells, which are closely associated with sieve tube elements. The sieve tube elements and companion cells are connected by pit fields present between their common longitudinal walls.
Which of the following is not a point source of water pollution?

The non-point sources of water pollution do not have a specific location for the discharge of water pollutants into the water bodies, e.g. run-off from crop fields, logging areas, oil spills through cargo ships, etc.

Which of the following statements regarding eutrophication are correct?

(i) Eutrophication is the natural ageing of a lake by nutrient enrichment of its water.

(ii) Pollutants from human activities like effluents from the industries and homes can radically accelerate the aging process of a lake. This phenomenon is called as cultural or accelerated eutrophication.

(iii) The plant nutrients responsible for eutrophication are nitrates and phosphates.

(iv) These phosphates and nitrates accelerate the growth of algae, which utilize oxygen and may deoxygenate the water to kill the fish and other aquatic animals.

Eutrophication is when a body of water becomes overly enriched with minerals and nutrients that induce excessive growth of plants and algae. This process may result in oxygen depletion of the water body. One example is the "bloom" or great increase of phytoplankton in a water body as a response to increased levels of nutrients. Eutrophication is almost always induced by the discharge of nitrate or phosphate-containing detergents, fertilizers, or sewage into an aquatic system. Cultural eutrophication is the process that speeds up natural eutrophication because of human activity. Due to clearing of land and building of towns and cities, land runoff is accelerated and more nutrients such as phosphates and nitrate are supplied to lakes and rivers, and then to coastal estuaries and bays. Extra nutrients are also supplied by treatment plants, golf courses, and agricultural practices through the use of fertilizers. Human activities, including the ones previously listed, can be responsible for an increase in nutrients, therefore, cultural eutrophication is more pronounced in non-polar ecosystems which have higher levels of human activity.

So the correct option is '(i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)'.
Eutrophication is the process in which dissolved oxygen in water is reduced due to excessive growth of algae. This is the result of:
Extra loading of nutrients in water body

Eutrophication is nutrient enrichment of water bodies by fertilizer-rich runoff from fields and sewage water. Nutrients stimulate excessive algal growth called algal bloom. Submerged plants die due to shading and result in increased organic loading. Subsequently the algae also die and aerobic decomposers become active. They rapidly consume the dissolved oxygen of water and as a result all the aquatic life in water body dies.
Chipko Movement occurred in which of following region?

The chipko movement began in the year of 1973 in the Tehri Garhwal region. It was  a form of organized resistance against destruction of forests. The local village women prevented the felling of trees by hugging them highly. The word 'Chipko' means to 'stick around' or to 'hug'.
Which one of the following is not an example of "natural air pollution"?

Nuclear test is not an example of "natural air pollution".

The major difference between natural and man-made air pollution is that continuous or temporary natural events cause natural air pollution, but human activities are responsible for man-made pollution. We can't prevent natural air pollution from sources like volcanoes, but we can reduce man-made pollutants and their consequences: respiratory diseases, acid rain and global warming.

Natural Sources of Air Pollution:

  • Natural air pollutants include radon, fog and mist, ozone, ash, soot, salt spray, spores released by plants, windblown dust and volcanic and combustion gases.
  • Radon is a radioactive gas that seeps from the ground in some areas, and fog and mist are both dense water vapor at ground level that obscures vision.
  • Ozone, a chemical formed naturally by the action of sunlight on oxygen, is a pollutant at ground level but beneficial in the upper atmosphere. A molecule made of three oxygen atoms, ozone shields the Earth from harmful ultraviolet rays from the sun, but it damages plants and causes breathing problems in the lower atmosphere.
  • Volcanic eruptions and forest, swamp and grass fires launch soot and ash into the atmosphere, which reduces sunlight and lowers temperatures. Eruptions and fires also produce carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide and other polluting gases.
  • The large number of nuclear weapons tests carried out in the atmosphere and underground during 1945–2013 (the last nuclear test was performed by North Korea) was responsible for the current environmental contamination with radioactive waste which resulted in ecologically and socially destroyed sites, due to high levels of radioactivity.
  • The 2000 Report of the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation to the General Assembly states that:
  • “The main man-made contribution to the exposure of the world's population [to radiation] has come from the testing of nuclear weapons in the atmosphere, from 1945 to 1980. Each nuclear test resulted in unrestrained release into the environment of substantial quantities of radioactive materials, which were widely dispersed in  the atmosphere and deposited everywhere on the Earth’s surface.”
Which UV rays is not absorbed by the ozone layer?

The stratospheric ozone layer absorbs ultraviolet (UV) radiation, preventing dangerous UV rays from hitting the Earth's surface and harming living organisms.

  • The UV rays that reach the earth has ultraviolet A, ultraviolet B and ultraviolet C (UVA, UVB and UVC) rays.
  • UV A (wavelength 400-315nm) is not absorbed by the ozone and penetrate deep into the skin causing DNA changes and skin cancer.
  • UV B (wavelength 315-280 nm) is mostly absorbed by the ozone layer and is the main cause of sunburn and cataract.
  • UV C (wavelength 280-100 nm) is completely absorbed by the ozone layer.

Thus, UV A rays are not absorbed by the ozone layer.
Which of the following are NOT the consequences of Deforestation?

An increase in groundwater level is not a consequence of deforestation.

Deforestation:

It is a very broad term, which consists of cutting of trees including repeated lopping, felling, and removal of forest litter, browsing, grazing, and trampling of seedlings. It can also be defined as the removal or damage of vegetation in a forest to the extent that it no longer supports its natural flora and fauna.

Deforestation not only affects the climate by increasing the atmospheric level of carbon dioxide but also affects the environment by inhibiting water recycling, triggering severe flooding, aquifer depletion, soil degradation, and the extinction of plant and animal species.

Deforestation leads to an increase in soil erosion and a decrease in rainfall.  

Causes of Deforestation: The most common reason for deforestation is the cutting of wood for fuel, lumber, and paper. Another important cause relates to the clearing of forest land for agriculture, including conversion to cropland and pasture. The main causes of deforestation are:

  • Agriculture
  • Shifting cultivation
  • Demand for firewood
  • Wood for industry and commercial use
  • Urbanization and developmental projects
  • Overgrazing of forests
Which of the following places was accredited to be the most polluted spot on Earth in 1960?
Lake Karachay in Central Russia was named by the Worldwatch Institute as the most polluted spot on Earth in 1960. It served as a disposal site for the Soviet Union.
Ozone layer to become ozone hole, the concentration of ozone should be:

Ozone layer to become ozone hole, the concentration of ozone should be < 220 Dobson Unit.

​Dobson units:

  • The thickness of the ozone in a column of air from the ground to the top of the atmosphere is measured in terms of Dobson units (DU).
  • One Dobson Unit is the amount of ozone that would be present if it formed a layer 0.01mm thick at average sea-level pressure and temperature.
  • Over the Earth’s surface, the ozone layer’s average thickness is about 300 Dobson Units or a layer that is 3 millimeters thick.
  • In Antarctica where the ozone hole phenomenon is predominantly observed, the total column ozone level of less than 220 Dobson Units due to catalyzed ozone loss from chlorine and bromine compounds.
  • For these reasons, NASA uses 220 Dobson Units as the boundary of the region representing ozone loss.

Ozone:

  • It is found in the upper part of the atmosphere called the stratosphere, and it acts as a shield absorbing ultraviolet radiation from the sun. 
  • Ozone gas is continuously formed by the action of UV rays on molecular oxygen and also degraded into molecular oxygen
  • Ozone depletion is the gradual thinning of Earth's ozone layer in by the release of chemical compounds containing chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) which move upward and reach the stratosphere and degrade ozone releasing molecular oxygen.
  • Although ozone depletion is occurring widely in the stratosphere, the depletion is particularly marked over the Antarctic region where it has resulted in the formation of a large area of the thinned ozone layer, commonly called as the ozone hole.
Which of the following is called the secondary air pollutant?

Ozone is called the secondary air pollutant.

Primary pollutants:

  • These are directly emitted from the sources in the atmosphere in a harmful form.
  • They can be natural (volcanic eruptions or fires, for example) or of anthropogenic origin (carbon monoxide from vehicles).

Secondary Pollutants:

  • These are derived from primary pollutants due to chemical or photochemical reactions in the atmosphere they become hazardous after reaction in the air. 
  • The best known of the secondary pollutants is certain gases that are synthesized by photochemical reactions in the lower atmosphere.
  • The primary emitted chemicals in these reactions are hydrocarbons and gaseous oxides of nitrogen such as nitric oxide and nitrogen dioxide. 
  • Its origin lies in the interactions between the primary emissions in the atmosphere.
Ozone depletion potential (ODP) is the measure of ozone depletion capability of a refrigerant compared to that of:

Ozone depletion potential (ODP) is the measure of ozone depletion capability of a refrigerant compared to that of R11.

Ozone depletion potential (ODP):

The ozone depletion potential (ODP) of a chemical compound is the relative amount of degradation to the ozone layer it can cause, with trichlorofluoromethane (CFC-11) being fixed at an ODP of 1.0.

ODP can be estimated from the molecular structure of a given substance.

Chlorofluorocarbons have ODPs roughly equal to:

  • Brominated substances have usually higher ODPs in range 5–15, because of more aggressive bromine reaction with ozone.
  • Hydrochlorofluorocarbons have ODPs mostly in range 0.005 - 0.2 due to the presence of the hydrogen which causes them to react readily in the troposphere, therefore reducing their chance to reach the stratosphere where the ozone layer is present.
  • Hydrofluorocarbons (HFC) has no chlorine content, so their ODP is essentially zero.

Ozone-depleting substances include:

  • Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)
  • Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs)
  • Hydrobromoflurocarbons (HBFCs)
  • Halons (any of a number of unreactive gaseous compounds of carbon with bromine and other halogens, used in fire extinguishers, etc).
  • Methyl bromide
  • Carbon tetrachloride
  • Methyl chloroform

HFC, Ammonia, and Carbon dioxide do not cause depletion of Ozone.

  • So they have zero ODP.
Which of the following air pollution control device is suitable for removing the finest dust from the air?

An electrostatic precipitator (ESP) is a device that removes fine particles, like dust and smoke from an outlet gas by the use of the force of an induced electrostatic charge, minimally impeding the flow of gases through the unit.
Which of the following statements best describes "Carbon Footprint"?
Carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere as a result of the activities of a particular individual, organization or community.
Greenhouse gases emitted by industries contributing to global warming.
Carbon emissions released by the burning of jet fuel.
Increase in the carbon content of the atmosphere due to the felling of trees.

'Carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere as a result of the activities of a particular individual, organization or community' statement best describes "Carbon Footprint".

Carbon Footprint:

​A carbon footprint is the total amount of Greenhouse Gases – GHGs (especially carbon dioxide and methane) released into the atmosphere by different human activities.

Carbon footprints can be associated with an individual, an organization, a product or an event, among others.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), a carbon footprint is a measure of the impact people’s activities have on the amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) produced through the burning of fossil fuels and is expressed as a weight of CO2 emissions produced in tonnes.

The carbon footprint is seen as a subset of the ecological footprint, where carbon footprint deals with resource usage but focuses strictly on the greenhouse gases released due to the burning of fossil fuels, while the latter compares the total resources people consume with the land and water area that is needed to replace those resources. 

The release of Six Greenhouse gases as recognized by the Kyoto Protocol will be counted in the carbon footprint. The Six GHGs are:

  • Carbon dioxide (CO2)
  • Methane (CH4)
  • Nitrous Oxide (N2O)
  • Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs)
  • Perfluorocarbon (PFCs)
  • Sulfur hexafluoride (SF6)
Which of the following metals is not used as a catalyst in catalytic converts fitted in automobiles?

A catalytic converter is an exhaust control device used to reduce the degree of toxicity of pollutant gases emitted from a vehicle. These work on the principal of redox (reduction and oxidation) reactions. 

The commonly used catalysts are platinum, iridium, and palladium. Rhodium is used as a reduction catalyst, palladium is used as an oxidation catalyst, and platinum is used both for reduction and oxidation.
Oxides of nitrogen and fluorides are responsible for:

Chlorosis is yellowing of leaves caused due to the destruction of chlorophyll. Deficiency of Mg, Fe, Zn or nitrogen or excess of Cl causes the chlorosis.

Necrosis is the symptom of the death of plant tissues or organs that results from pathogen infection. This symptom can occur in any plant tissues, such as the leaves, petioles, stems, branches, roots, flowers, fruits or tubers. Necrosis may appear in small areas or cover a large area of the plant tissues. Oxides of nitrogen and fluorides are responsible for chlorosis and necrosis.
Which of the following is sweet in taste but is not a sugar?

Sweet tasting carbohydrates are called sugars, e.g., glucose and fructose. Starch is a storage polymer of glucose and is tasteless till it is broken down into monomer glucose molecule. Lactose is milk sugar. Proteins are polymers of amino acids which are tasteless except for some like aspartic acid. Saccharine is an artificial sweetener. Saccharin is more sweet than common table sugar or sucrose but has a bitter after taste.
A carbohydrate which can not be hydrolyzed to simpler compound is:

A carbohydrate which can not be hydrolyzed to simpler compound is monosaccharide. They have general formula \(\left(\mathrm{CH}_{2} \mathrm{O}\right)_{n}\).

Carbohydrates are classified based on hydrolysis:

(i) Monosaccharides

(ii) Oligosaccharides

(iii) Disaccharides

(iv) Trisaccharides

(v) Polysaccharides
Glucose, galactose, mannose come in the category of:
The mono saccharides which result from carbohydrate digestion consist primarily of glucose, fructose, galactose, mannose, xylose and arabinose.
Which of the following is simplest form of sugar and are usually colorless, water-soluble, crystalline solids?

Monosaccharides are the most basic units of carbohydrates. They are the simplest form of sugar and are usually colourless, water -soluble, crystalline solids. Examples of monosaccharides includes glucose, fructose galatose.
Hydrolysis of which of the following sugars gives 2 to 10 mono saccharides?

Hydrolysis of oligosaccharides gives 2 to 10 mono saccharides.

A carbohydrate that cannot be hydrolysed further to give simpler unit of polyhydroxy aldehyde or ketone is called a monosaccharide. Some common examples are glucose, fructose, ribose, etc.

Carbohydrates that yield two to ten monosaccharide units, on hydrolysis, are called oligosaccharides. They are further classified as disaccharides, trisaccharide, tetrasaccharide, etc., depending upon the number of monosaccharides, they provide on hydrolysis. 

Amongst these the most common are disaccharides. The two monosaccharide units obtained on hydrolysis of a disaccharide may be same or different.
______ sugars are further classified in Di, Tri, Tetra. depending on the number of hydrolytic products formed.

Oligosaccharides sugars are further classified in Di, Tri, Tetra. depending on the number of hydrolytic products formed.

Oligosaccharides represent carbohydrates that contain between 3 and 10 single sugar residues and are not relatively abundant in the diet when compared to other more common carbohydrates like those in the disaccharide category. Common oligosaccharides include raffinose, stachyose, and verbascose.
Sucrose is a common table sugar. It belongs to:

Sucrose is a common table sugar. It belongs to oligosaccharides.

Oligosaccharides represent carbohydrates that contain between 3 and 10 single sugar residues and are not relatively abundant in the diet when compared to other more common carbohydrates like those in the disaccharide category. Common oligosaccharides include raffinose, stachyose, and verbascose.
Fructose is known as fruit sugar and is found in many foods. It is an example of:

Fructose is known as fruit sugar and is found in many foods. It is an example of monosaccharides.

Monosaccharides are the simplest carbohydrates; they conform to the general chemical formula (CH2O)x and are termed simple sugars. The most commonly occurring monosaccharides contain three to six carbon atoms in an unbranched single-bonded chain. Monosaccharides are signified by the suffix ose.
The noncrystalline, insoluble in water and tasteless sugars are:

The noncrystalline, insoluble in water and tasteless sugars are polysaccharides.

Polysaccharides are a class of carbohydrates generated by repeated units of monosaccharide (such as glucose, fructose, and galactose) or disaccharides (such as sucrose and lactose), that are linked together by glycosidic bonds.
The sugars like xylose and ribose are colorless, water-soluble and crystalline solids. They are categorised as:

The sugars like xylose and ribose are colorless, water-soluble and crystalline solids. They are categorised as monosaccharides.

Monosaccharides, also called simple sugars, are the simplest forms of sugar and the most basic units from which all carbohydrates are built. They are usually colorless, water-soluble, and crystalline solids. Contrary to their name, only some monosaccharides have a sweet taste.
The building blocks of di-saccharides (sucrose) and poly-saccharides are:

Monosaccharides are the building blocks of disaccharides (such as sucrose and lactose) and polysaccharides (such as cellulose and starch). 

The table sugar used in everyday vernacular is itself a disaccharide sucrose comprising one molecule of each of the two monosaccharides D-glucose and D-fructose.

The sugar insoluble in water is polysaccharides.

Polysaccharides display a wide range of solubility; some are water insoluble, e.g., cellulose, some are only hot water soluble, e.g., starch and some are readily dissolved in cold water, such as pullulan and gum arabic.

The tasteless sugars are polysaccharides.

Polysaccharides are not as sweet because they do not readily bind to the sweet receptors on our tongue, as the other smaller molecules do.
Which of the following is a non-crystalline sugar?

Sugar + glucose syrup is a non-crystalline sugar.

Non-crystalline sugar is usually hard and brittle and has a higher sugar concentration than crystalline sugar. Typically, non-crystalline sugar is made by allowing the sugar syrup to cool over several days. Rock candy, lollipops and glass candy are some examples of non-crystalline sugar.

Enzymes are regarded as the biocatalysts.

Enzymes are proteins made from amino acids. It is made up of hundreds and thousands of amino acids stringed together in a very specific and unique order. Any chemical reaction inside a cell or any work that goes on inside a cell is the handiwork of enzymes inside the cell.
A disaccharide consists of two mono saccharides joined by _____ bonds.

A disaccharide consists of two mono saccharides joined by glycoside bonds.

For example:

(1) Sucrose is a disaccharide containing two monosaccharids glucose and fructose  joined by glycoside bonds.

(2) Maltose is a disaccharide containing two monosaccharids glucose and glucose joined by glycoside bonds.

(3) Lactose is a disaccharide containing two monosaccharids glucose and galactose  joined by glycoside bonds.
A dehydration synthesis reaction is also known as:

Dehydration is the term which stands for removal of water. Dehydration is the synthesis reaction where polymerization occurs in which the monomers are bound together which

releases water as the end product or precipitate.

Option (A): A condensation reaction: Dehydration synthesis is a reaction where two small molecules are

joined chemically. Dehydration and condensation both the terms stand for ‘losing water’. So, dehydration synthesis reaction is known as a condensation reaction.

Option (B): A hydrolysis reaction: Hydrolysis reaction is termed as breaking bonds and releasing energy.

Option (C): an isometric reaction: It is the type of skeletal muscle contraction in which the length of the

muscles remain constant but pressure increases.

Option (D): Energy releasing reaction: chemical reactions which release energy during the formation of the bond is called energy-releasing reaction. Energy releasing reaction is also known as Exothermic Reaction.
The condensation reaction is concerned with the synthesis of _______ with the removal of water molecule.

The condensation reaction is concerned with the synthesis of disaccharides with the removal of water molecule.

A disaccharide also called a double sugar or biose is the sugar formed when two monosaccharides are joined by glycosidic linkage. Like monosaccharides, disaccharides are simple sugars soluble in water. Three common examples are sucrose, lactose, and maltose.

We know that carbohydrates are the sugar molecules. Monosaccharides are the simplest carbohydrates. These monosaccharides join together to form disaccharides, oligosaccharides and polysaccharides. These monosaccharides are joined together through glycosidic linkage.

Monosaccharides are the simplest units of carbohydrates, so they cannot be further hydrolysed to be broken down into simpler units. Disaccharides break down into monosaccharides on hydrolysis.

The sugar present in some cereals like sugar beet, cottonseed is known as Raffinose. It is a trisaccharide. This means that three monosaccharides joined together to form a single unit of Raffinose.

Raffinose consists of glucose, galactose and fructose. Therefore, when we hydrolyse Raffinose, it will produce glucose, galactose and fructose.

We can write the hydrolysis reaction of Raffinose and break down of Raffinose is shown as follows:

Raffinose \(\rightarrow\) Glucose \(+\) Galactose \(+\) Fructose

Biose is the other name for disaccharide.

A disaccharide is the sugar formed when two monosaccharides are joined by glycosidic linkage. Like monosaccharides, disaccharides are simple sugars soluble in water. Three common examples are sucrose, lactose, and maltose.
Cellobiose and maltose are classified as the reducing ________.

Cellobiose and maltose are classified as the reducing disaccharides.

A disaccharide also called a double sugar or biose is the sugar formed when two monosaccharides are joined by glycosidic linkage. Like monosaccharides, disaccharides are simple sugars soluble in water. Three common examples are sucrose, lactose, and maltose.
Sucrose and trehalose are categorised as the non-reducing _______.

Sucrose and trehalose are categorised as the non-reducing di-saccharides.

Non-reducing disaccharides like sucrose and trehalose have glycosidic bonds between their anomeric carbons and thus cannot convert to an open-chain form with an aldehyde group; they are stuck in the cyclic form. Complete solution: Let us begin by knowing about sucrose the answer will ultimately come out.
The two mono saccharides undergoes dehydration reaction to form:

The two mono saccharides undergoes dehydration reaction to form disaccharides.

A disaccharide also called a double sugar or biose is the sugar formed when two monosaccharides are joined by glycosidic linkage. Like monosaccharides, disaccharides are simple sugars soluble in water. Three common examples are sucrose, lactose, and maltose.

Nijerose and kojibiose are disaccharides.

Nigerose also known as sakebiose, is an unfermentable sugar obtained by partial hydrolysis of nigeran, a polysaccharide found in black mold, but is also readily extracted from the dextrans found in rice molds and many other fermenting microorganisms, such as L. mesenteroides.

Kojibiose is a disaccharide. It is a product of the caramelization of glucose. It is also present in honey. Kojibiose has a mild sweet taste, but low calorie count. In combination with its prebiotic properties, kojibiose could function as a sugar substitute.
Lactose is milk sugar. It is a:
Lactose or milk sugar is a disaccharide which consists of a glucose molecule and a galactose molecule. Lactose is only found in milk from mammals.
The binomial name of French marigold is:

The binomial name of French marigold is Tagetes patula.

Tagetes patula, the French marigold, is a species of flowering plant in the family Asteraceae, native to Mexico and Guatemala with several naturalized populations in many other countries. It is widely cultivated as an easily grown bedding plant, with thousands of different cultivars in brilliant shades of yellow and orange.
The book 'Historia Generalis Plantarum' was written by:

The book ‘Historia Generalis Plantarum’ was a book that contained information about 18,500 plant species. This book was written by the English naturalist John Ray. He published the important works on botany, zoology and natural theology. The classification of plants in Historia Plantarum was an important step towards modern taxonomy. Also, he was the first to attempt a biological definition of the concept of species.
Which of the following statements is correct about blue-green algae?

Blue-Green algae are photosynthetic autotrophic bacteria.

Blue-green algae (cyanobacteria) are a group of prokaryotic, autotrophic microorganisms that contain the photosynthetic pigments (chlorophyll and phycocyanin).

Blue-green algae are actually types of bacteria known as Cyanobacteria. They normally look green and sometimes may turn bluish when scums are dying. Taste and odour problems commonly occur with large concentrations of blue-green algae and some species are capable of producing toxins.
All the florets are disc florets in:

All the florets are disc florets in vernonia. The name of an exceedingly large and wide spread family of flowering plants.

Vernonia is a genus of about 350 species of forbs and shrubs in the family Asteraceae. Some species are known as ironweed.

Stigeoclonium exhibits a heterotrichous habit, characterized by the production of both erect filamentous structures and creeping, prostrate forms. This algae commonly inhabits freshwater environments, displaying adaptability in growth forms to various ecological niches.
Which one of the following algae is reported to produce an antibiotic?
Chlamydomonas provides antimicrobial benefit while Chlorella used for cancerous patient treatment and Ectocarpus used for molecular study only Nostoc is scientifically produces anti-biotic.

In bryophytes sporophytes depend upon gametophytes.

In bryophytes the long-lived and conspicuous generation is the gametophyte, while in vascular plants it is the sporophyte. Structures resembling stems, roots, and leaves are found on the gametophore of bryophytes, while these structures are found on the sporophytes in the vascular plants.
To which of the following categories does the protein-rich spirulina belong?

Spirulina belongs to kingdom monera. It is a spirally coiled free floating filamentous blue green alga or cyanobacterium of upto 0.5 mm length. It can grow both autotrophically and heterotrophically. This cyanobacterium is rich in protein. It also contains minerals, vitamins and essential fatty acids. Because of its beneficial nature, Spirulina is used as food additive in the form of powder, pill or tablet. It is also used as manure. It is helpful in reclamation of usar soils.
'Watermelon snow' is caused due to which of the following?

'Watermelon snow' is caused due to Chlamydomonas nivalis.

Watermelon snow, also called snow algae, pink snow, red snow, or blood snow, is a phenomenon caused by Chlamydomonas nivalis, a species of green algae containing a secondary red carotenoid pigment (astaxanthin) in addition to chlorophyll.
Bryophytes resemble algae in which of the following aspects?
Filamentous body, presence of vascular tissues and autotrophic nutrition
Differentiation of plant body into root, stem and leaves and autotrophic nutrition
Thallus like plant body, presence of root and autotrophic nutrition
Thallus-like plant body, lack of vascular tissues and autotrophic nutrition

Both in algae and bryophytes, plant body is thalloid, vascular bundles are absent. The chloroplast pigments in the vegetative cells of bryophytes are identical with those of green algae. They both can synthesize their own food, so mode of nutrition is autotrophic.
The algal plant body, considered to be advanced over the unicellular condition, is
Non-motile colony, mixed with the motile colony

A. The distinct characteristic of Volvox is to show individuality. Each cell contributes for the good of the colony more or less acting as a multicellular organism. Hence, Volvox is the most developed in the series of genera that form spherical colonies. The vegetative cells of volvox comprise of a flagella facing outward and the cells are motile. They swim in a coordinated way towards light.

B. The option is incorrect because it is not the name of any species of algae but a characteristic feature of a few protozoans.

C. Ulothrix is fresh water and marine, green filamentous algae but it is definitely not the most avanced and motile unicellular organisms.

D.This option is not a name of an algal plant body. It is only a significant characteristic of a few protozoans.

Hence, the correct option is (A).

Okra or lady finger is a perennial plant that grows upto 2m tall. This plant is characterized by broad leaves 5-7 palmately lobed. The flowers have five white to yellow petals with a red or purple sot at its base of the petals. The fruit is a pentagonal capsule containing numerous seeds. These characteristics place it in the family of Malvaceae.
How can a member of the Brassicaceae family be distinguished from that of the Malvaceae family?
They possess bicarpellary ovary in which the carpels are placed transversely and the ovules are borne on parietal placenta.
They possess bicarpellary ovary in which the carpels are placed anterio–posteriorly and develop a replum.
They possess bicarpellary ovary which is multilocular and bears ovules on parietal placenta.
They possess pentacarpellary ovary in which the bilocular ovules are borne on axile placenta.

They possess bicarpellary ovary in which the carpels are placed transversely and the ovules are borne on parietal placenta.

Brassicaceae or Cruciferae is a medium-sized and economically important family of flowering plants commonly known as the mustards, the crucifers, or the cabbage family. Most are herbaceous plants, while some are shrubs. The leaves are simple (although are sometimes deeply incised), lack stipules, and appear alternately on stems or in rosettes. The inflorescences are terminal and lack bracts.
A research scholar once collected a certain alga and found that its cells contained chlorophyll a, chlorophyll d and phycoerythrin. The alga must belong to the class:

Members of Rhodophyceae (red algae) contains Chlorophyll-a, d, r-phycoerythrin, r-phycocyanin, α and β-carotene Pigments.  Members of Chlorophyceae (green algae) contain chlorophy ll-a, b and p-carotene pigments. Members of Bacillariophyceae (diatoms) contain chlorophyll-a, c β-carotene, α-carotene pigments.  Members of Cyanophyceae (cyanobacteria, blue-green algae) contain chlorophyll-a, c-phytocyanin, c-phycoer) then and β-carotene pigments.
Which of the following organisms are called 'amphibians' of the plant kingdom?

Bryophytes are called amphibians of the plant kingdom because these plants need both water and soil for their survival.

Bryophytes is the informal group name for mosses, liverworts and hornworts. They are non-vascular plants, which means they have no roots or vascular tissue, but instead absorb water and nutrients from the air through their surface (e.g., their leaves).
In Phaeophyceae, the food stored in the form of:

In Phaeophyceae, laminarin is the stored food and major pigments are chlorophyll a and b. 

Phaeophyceae (brown algae) The Phaeophyceae (Heterokontophyta) comprise multicellular brown algae with a wide range of morphologies and sizes (van den Hoek et al., 1995). This class contains 14 orders, 265 genera and 1500–2000 species.

Kelps are marine algae of class phaeophyceae or brown algae. The body of kelp may reach upto 100 meter long. They vary in colour from olive green to various shades of brown depending upon xanthophyll pigments , fucoxanthin present in them.
An algae having ribbon shaped chloroplast is:

An algae having ribbon shaped chloroplast is Spirogyra.

The shape of a chloroplast varies from species to species. It may be cup-shaped (e.g., Chlamydomonas), (e.g., Vaucheria), Girdle (e.g., Ulothrix), Stellate or Star-shaped (e.g., Zygnema), Reticulate or net-like (e.g., Cladophora, Oedogonium), Spiral or ribbon or scalariform (e.g., Spirogyra), ovoid or disc or spheroid in higher plants.

The common forms of Brown algae or Phaeophyceae are Ectocarpus, Dictyota, Laminaria, Sargassum and Fucus.

The Phaeophyceae or brown algae are a large group of marine multicellular algae. They play an important role in marine environments. Both, Laminaria and Fucus are the genera of Phaeophyceae.

The plant body of phaeophyceae is usually attached to the substratum by a holdfast whereas the angiosperms attach to the substratum with the help of roots.

Phaeophyceae: a class comprising the brown algae and being coextensive with the division Phaeophyta.
The half of the total carbon dioxide fixation on earth is carried out by algae through:

Nearly 50% of total carbon dioxide fixation is carried out by algae through photosynthesis. Photosynthesis by algae releases oxygen in the immediate aquatic environment. It is essential for the respiration of aquatic life.
In Ulothrix or Spirogyra, reduction division (meiosis) occurs at the time of:

In Ulothrix/Spirogyra reduction division (meiosis) occurs at the time of zygospore germination. Plant body of Ulothrix and Spirogyra, is gametophytic (haploid), they produce zoogametes (n) which fuses to form zygosporic (2n) diploid, which is a resting spore. Onset of favourable condition zygospore undergoes reductional division, or meiosis to produce zoo- meiospores.
The cell wall of green algae is made up of:

Green algae usually have a rigid cell wall made of an inner layer of cellulose and an outer layer of pectose.

Cell wall of green algae is thin, transparent and firm and consists of outer pectic and inner cellulosic layers. It is smooth but in most of species it gets thickened at the anterior end to form an apical papilla.
Which classes of algae possess chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, carotenoids and xanthophylls?

Phaeophyceae possess chlorophyll a, c, carotenoids and xanthophylls. They vary in colour from olive green to various shades of brown depending upon the amount of the xanthophyll pigment, fucoxanthin present in them.

  • Phaeophyceae have a root-like structure called a holdfast, which anchors them to their substrate. The structure of holdfast varies in different species. They do not take part in nutrient or water uptake like roots in plants. They prevent algae from being flown away by the water current.
  • There is a small stalk present, which is more like a stem. It is called a stipe. Fucus shows three distinct layers in the stipe region, namely pith (central region), cortex and outer epidermis. Stipe may be rigid or elastic. The centre of the stipe is hollow and helps in keeping the algae buoyant.
The process of fusion between one large and non-motile female gamete with smaller, motile male gamete is termed as:

Fusion between one large, non-motile female gamete and a smaller, motile male gamete is termed as Oogamy. e.g., Volvox, Fucus.

Sperm, is often designated as oogamy. In oogamous reproduction, the union of sperm and egg is called fertilization. Isogamy, heterogamy, and oogamy are often considered to represent an increasingly specialized evolutionary series.
Rhodophyta are commonly called red algae because of the predominance of pigment:

Red algae are red because of the presence of the pigment phycoerythrin; this pigment reflects red light and absorbs blue light.

The photosynthetic pigments found in green plants are chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, xanthophyll and carotene. These pigments are found in the chloroplast of cells. Xanthophyll a yellow colored pigment is carotene is orange colored pigment.

Agar is obtained from gelidium.

Gelidium is a genus of thalloid red algae comprising 134 species. Its members are known by a number of common names. Gelidium was first described by Lamouroux in 1813 and is regarded to be one the genus with the most species.

Largest unicellular organism is acetabularia.

Acetabularia is a genus of green algae in the family Polyphysaceae, Typically found in subtropical waters, Acetabularia is a single-celled organism, but gigantic in size and complex in form, making it an excellent model organism for studying cell biology.

Pond scum is spirogyra.

Spirogyra, (genus Spirogyra), any member of a genus of some 400 species of free-floating green algae (division Chlorophyta) found in freshwater environments around the world. Named for their beautiful spiral chloroplasts, spirogyras are filamentous algae that consist of thin unbranched chains of cylindrical cells.

An algae with ribbon shaped chloroplast is spirogyra.

Spirogyra, (genus Spirogyra), any member of a genus of some 400 species of free-floating green algae (division Chlorophyta) found in freshwater environments around the world. Named for their beautiful spiral chloroplasts, spirogyras are filamentous algae that consist of thin unbranched chains of cylindrical cells.
Which of the following is not an RNA virus?

Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) is a double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) virus with a 152-kb linear genome. Replication of HSV-1 DNA takes place in the host nucleus. 

Reovirus is a nonenveloped double-stranded RNA virus. This virus was initially not known to be related to any specific disease, and so was named Respiratory Enteric Orphan virus.

The genome of the hepatitis delta virus (HDV) is the smallest known to infect man. Encoding just one protein, hepatitis delta antigen (HDAg), HDV relies heavily on host functions and on structural features of the viral RNA.

The rotavirus genome consists of 11 segments of double-stranded (ds) RNA and is contained in the viral core along with the minor structural proteins, VP1 and VP3 (10).
Chronic inflammation of the eye occurs in the case of:

Chronic inflammation of the eye occurs in the case of trachoma.

Trachoma is chronic conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and is characterized by progressive exacerbations and remissions. It is the leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide. Initial symptoms are conjunctival hyperemia, eyelid edema, photophobia, and lacrimation.

Polio, or poliomyelitis, is a disabling and life-threatening disease caused by the poliovirus. The virus spreads from person to person and can infect a person's spinal cord, causing paralysis (can't move parts of the body).

The human enteroviruses are ubiquitous viruses that are transmitted from person to person via direct contact with viruses shed from the gastrointestinal or upper respiratory tract. Poliovirus, the prototypical enterovirus, can cause a subclinical or mild illness, aseptic meningitis, or paralytic poliomyelitis.
Which of these viral diseases in humans is caused by a DNA virus?

Smallpox is a double-stranded, 135- to 375-kilobase (kb) DNA virus that replicates in the cytoplasm of the host cell and forms B-type inclusion bodies (Guarnieri bodies). This is in contrast to herpes viruses, which replicate in the nucleus. The orthopoxviruses are among the largest and most complex of all viruses.
Which one of the following is an anaerobic gram-negative cocci?

Veillonella is an anaerobic gram-negative cocci.

Among gram-negative anaerobic cocci, Veillonella species are common and considered mainly harmless, or even beneficial, colonizers of the mouth from the early years of life onward,31 whereas Acidaminococcus and Megasphaera spp. reside in the human intestine and genitourinary tract, respectively.
In the human immune system, interferon is a part of:
Interferons are a type of cytokine barrier. Interferons are the proteins secreted by the virus-infected cells, which protect noninfected cells from further viral infection.

Lymphatic filariasis is caused by infection with parasites classified as nematodes (roundworms) of the family Filariodidea. There are 3 types of these thread-like filarial worms: Wuchereria bancrofti, which is responsible for 90% of the cases. Brugia malayi, which causes most of the remainder of the cases.

HIV attacks a specific type of immune system cell in the body. It's known as the CD4 helper cell or T cell. When HIV destroys this cell, it becomes harder for the body to fight off other infections. When HIV is left untreated, even a minor infection such as a cold can be much more severe.

Cancer refers to any of a large number of diseases characterized by the development of abnormal cells that divide uncontrollably and have the ability to infiltrate and destroy normal human tissues. Cancer usually has the ability to spread throughout the body. Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the world.

Sarcomas are cancers caused by transformed cells derived from mesenchymal (connective tissue or mesoderm tissue). Therefore, malignant tumors codified of cancellous bone, cartilage, fat, muscle, blood vessels, or hematopoietic tissue are considered sarcomas. Sarcomas are the opposite of malignant tumors that originate from epithelial cells called carcinoma.

Types of sarcoma:

Adult fibrosarcoma: usually affects healthy tissues in the legs, arms, or trunk. This is usually a basic habit of individuals between the ages of 20 and 60, but it can also occur in individuals of all ages, even babies.

Alveolar soft part sarcoma: is a rare cancer that mainly affects young people. These tumors are most common in the legs.

Clear cell sarcoma: is a rare cancer that usually starts in the tendons of the arms or legs. Under the microscope, it has certain characteristics of malignant melanoma, which starts from skin cells that produce pigment. It is not yet known how cancers with these characteristics start in areas other than the skin.

Sarcomas are rare in adults, accounting for about 1% of all adult cancer diagnoses. They are relatively common in children. Between 1,500 and 1,700 children in the United States are identified with bone or soft tissue sarcoma each year.
Which of the following is the most fatal non-infectious disease?

Cancer is the most fatal non-infectious disease. In 2017, 9.6 million people are estimated to have died from various forms of cancer. While AIDS is the most fatal infectious disease affecting nearly 36.9 million people worldwide. Diabetes and Obesity are also non-infectious diseases but not the most fatal.
Which of the following is a Congenital Disease?

Sickle-cell anemia is a congenital disease. Congenital diseases are contracted before birth due to chromosomal abnormalities or gene mutations or defects in development. Goitre and Kwashiorkor are caused due to deficiency of an essential element while Rheumatoid Arthritis is an autoimmune disease.
Which of the following is a tick-borne viral disease?

Kyasanur Forest Disease is one of tick-borne associated diseases of flaviviruses caused by infected tick bite of Haemaphysalis spingera. It was first discovered in 1957 in India in Kyasanar forest of Shimoga district, state of Karnataka.
The major mechanism of HER-2/neu oncogene activation in breast cancer is:

The major mechanism of her-2/neu oncogene activation in breast cancer is gene amplification.

HER2 is a membrane tyrosine kinase and oncogene that is overexpressed and gene amplified in about 20% of breast cancers. When activated it provides the cell with potent proliferative and anti-apoptosis signals and it is the major driver of tumor development and progression for this subset of breast cancer.

The fungus with bioluminescent characteristics is Omphalotus olearius.

Omphalotus olearius, commonly known as the jack-o'-lantern mushroom, is a poisonous orange gilled mushroom that to an untrained eye appears similar to some chanterelles. It is notable for its bioluminescent properties. It is found in woodland areas in Europe, where it grows on decaying stumps, on buried roots, or at the base of hardwood trees. It has also been reported from the Western Cape Province, South Africa. A similar, but phylogenetically distinct species found in eastern North America is Omphalotus illudens.
Which of the following viruses causes the green monkey disease?

Marburg virus causes the green monkey disease.

Marburg virus disease (MVD) commonly known as green monkey disease is a rare but severe hemorrhagic fever that affects both people and non-human primates. MVD is caused by the Marburg virus, a genetically unique zoonotic (or, animal-borne) RNA virus of the filovirus family. MVD is caused by the Marburg virus, a genetically unique zoonotic virus that can infect both human and non-human primates. This RNA virus belongs to the filovirus family that causes rare but severe hemorrhagic fever. Other members of this family include the Ebola virus.

A pathogen or infectious agent is a biological agent that causes disease or illness to its host. This term is most often used for agents that disrupt the normal physiology of animals or plants. Pathogens can be a bacterium, viruses, or other microorganisms that can cause disease.

Plasmodium completes their life cycle in two hosts, female anopheles and human beings. The motile zygote of plasmodium occurs in the gut of female anopheles, which gets transferred to a human being during a mosquito bite.
The pathogenic bacterium that causes typhoid fever in a human being is:
Typhoid fever in a human being is caused by Salmonella typhi. The pathogen enters to the small intestine through food and contaminated water and migrates to other organs through blood.
Alzheimer's disease in humans is associated with the deficiency of:

Alzheimer's disease is a neurological disorder in which the death of brain cells causes memory loss and cognitive decline. It is caused in humans due to the deficiency of acetylcholine. One of the proteins involved is called amyloid, deposits of which form plaques around brain cells. The other protein is called tau, deposits of which form tangles within brain cells.
Hemozoin is released into the blood during the infection of Plasmodium vivax every:

Plasmodium vivax protozoa cause malaria in human beings having high fever and chill effects at the regular interval of time. Hemozoin is released into the bloodstream by plasmodium which causes a high fever at the interval of 48 hours.

Match Column I with Column II and then choose the correct option.

Column I Column II
a. Caput epididymis 1. It lies on the lateral side of the testis and stores the sperms temporarily.
b. Corpus epididymis 2. It is the lower wider part that lies on the posterior side of the testis and stores spermatozoa.
c. Cauda epididymis 3. It is the upper wider part, which receives the vasa efferentia.

The correct answer is a - 3, b - 1, c - 2.

Caput epididymis: It is the upper wider part, which receives the vasa efferentia. The caput, or head, is where sperm enter the epididymis from the testes. At this stage, sperm are not motile. They are also very dilute. 

Corpus epididymis: It lies on the lateral side of the testis and stores the sperms temporarily. The corpus, or body, is where sperm begin to gain motility.

Cauda epididymis: It is the lower wider part that lies on the posterior side of the testis and stores spermatozoa. The cauda epididymis is the primary storage site for mature sperm and is continuous with a highly muscular duct called the ductus deferens, also known as the vas deferens.

Assertion: Human females are fertile on a cyclic basis.

Reason: The hormones estrogen, progesterone, FSH and LH regulate the cyclic activity.
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.

Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.

The menstrual cycle is a series of natural changes in hormone production and the structures of the uterus and ovaries of the female reproductive system that make pregnancy possible.

The ovarian cycle controls the production and release of eggs and the cyclic release of estrogen and progesterone.

Naturally occurring hormones drive the cycles; the cyclical rise and fall of the follicle stimulating hormone prompts the production and growth of oocytes (immature egg cells). The hormone estrogen stimulates the uterus lining (endometrium) to thicken to accommodate an embryo should fertilization occur.
Which of the following connects the scrotal sac to the abdominal cavity?

Inguinal canal connects the scrotal sac to the abdominal cavity.

The inguinal canal is a passage in the lower anterior abdominal wall located just above the inguinal ligament. It starts from the internal inguinal orifice, extends medially and inferiorly through the abdominal wall layers and ends in the external inguinal orifice. This canal is about four to six centimeters in length.
Which of the following secretes a mucus like substance that lubricates the vagina for frictionless movement of penis?

Cowper's glands secretes a mucus like substance that lubricates the vagina for frictionless movement of penis.

Cowper's glands are pea sized glands present inferior to the prostate gland in the male reproductive system. They produce thick clear mucus prior to ejaculation that drains into the spongy urethra.

Match Column I with Column II and then choose the correct option.

Column IColumn II
a. Mons pubis1. It is a set of two large thick folds of skin which forms the boundary of the vulva.
b. Clitoris2. It is a solid structure containing erectile tissues and is made up of two erectile bodies.
c. Labia Majora3. It is the anteriormost portion which is fatty and is covered with pubic hairs.

The correct answer is a - 3, b - 2, c - 1.

Mons pubis: The mons pubis is the coarse hair-bearing prominent area of skin and fatty tissue overlaying the symphysis pubis and other pubic bones that is bounded superiorly by the pubic hairline and inferiorly by the clitoris.

Clitoris: It is a solid structure containing erectile tissues and is made up of two erectile bodies. 

Labia Majora: It is a set of two large thick folds of skin which forms the boundary of the vulva. The labia majora are a prominent pair of cutaneous skin folds that will form the lateral longitudinal borders of the vulval clefts.

In which of the following phase(s) of formation of spermatids, the sperm mother cells lining the seminiferous tubules of the testes proliferate by repeated mitotic divisions and increase their number?

a. Multiplication phase

b. Growth phase

c. Maturation phase

Multiplication phase: This phase is also known as proliferation and renewal of spermatogonia. During this phase the diploid spermatogonia which are situated at the periphery of the seminiferous tubule, multiply mitotically to form spermatocytes and also to give rise to new spermatogonia.
Which of the following parts of a human spermatozoon is very short and contains one proximal centriole and one distal centriole?

A male sperm contains a head, neck, a middle piece, and the tail. The sperm head contains an elongated haploid nucleus whereas the neck contains a proximal centriole i.e. reduced centrosome which remains intact during the spermatogenesis. The middle piece contains numerous mitochondria which produce energy for the movement of pain and facilitate sperm motility.
Oogenesis occurs under the influence of hormones secreted by the endocrine glands. Which of the following hormones is secreted by the hypothalamus?

Gonadotropin hormone-releasing hormone (GnRH) is the key regulator of the reproductive axis. Its pulsatile secretion determines the pattern of secretion of the gonadotropins Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), which then regulate both the endocrine function and gamete maturation in the gonads.

Assertion : The middle piece in the sperm is called its powerhouse.

Reason : It contains mitochondria that provides energy (ATP) for swimming.
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation for A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation for A.
A is true but R is false.

Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation for A.

The middle piece of human sperm contains the mitochondria coiled around the axial filament called, mitochondrial spiral. They provide energy for the movement of the sperm. So it is called as the 'power house of the sperm'.
In which of the following processes do specific blastomeres migrate from the surface of the blastula to their pre-determined positions and form three germinal layers?

Gastrulation is the process during embryonic development that changes the embryo from a blastula with a single layer of cells to a gastrula containing multiple layers of cells. Gastrulation typically involves the blastula folding in upon itself or dividing, which creates two layers of cells. Organisms that do not form a third layer are known as diploblastic organisms.

Which of the following statements is/are false?

a. Only one sperm fertilizes the egg, while the others degenerate and are engulfed by leucocytes. 

b. A sperm can survive in the female body for a maximum of 5 days and can fertilize the ovum within 24 hours only. 

c. Fertilization occurs if either ovum or sperm is transported to the ampullary-isthmic junction.

The motile sperms swim rapidly, pass through the cervix, enter into the uterus and finally reach the junction of the isthmus and ampulla (ampullary-isthmic junction) of the fallopian tube. The ovum released by the ovary is also transported to the ampullary-isthmic junction where fertilization lakes place. Fertilization can only occur if the ovum and sperms are transported simultaneously to the ampullaryisthmic junction. This is the reason why not all copulations lead to fertilization and pregnancy.
The fusion of the sperm and the ovum to form a diploid zygote is called fertilization. Which of the following is not a significance of fertilization?
It stimulates the secondary oocyte to undergo maturation.
It restores the cell size and the nucleo-cytoplasmic ratio characteristic of the species.

Fertilization is not associated with the cell size and the nucleo-cytoplasmic ratio characteristic of the species.

Cleavage is basically the process of division of a single-celled zygote into a multicellular blastocyst that further undergoes implantation and development to form a fetus. Restoration of the cell size and the nucleocytoplasmic ratio characteristic of the species is done by the process of cleavage.

Which of the following extra-embryonic membranes develop from the inner cell mass later on, after the formation of embryonic parts?

a. Allantois

b. Yolk sac

c. Chorion

d. Amnion

Allantois and Yolk sac are the extra-embryonic membranes that develop from the inner cell mass later on, after the formation of embryonic parts.

Allantois is an extra-embryonic membrane of reptiles, birds, and mammals arising as a pouch, or sac, from the hindgut. In mammals other than marsupials the allantois is intimately associated with the chorion, contributing blood vessels to that structure as it forms—in conjunction with the endometrium, or mucosal lining, of the uterus—the placenta.

A yolk sac is a structure that develops inside uterus during early pregnancy. It provides an embryo with nourishment . It helps circulate gases between mother and the embryo. The yolk sac also produces cells that turn into important structures, such as the umbilical cord, blood cells and reproductive organs.

Match the following:

a. Decidua basalis 1. It is between the embryo and the lumen of the uterus.
b. Decidua capsularis 2. It is between the embryo and uterine serosa.
c. Decidua parietalis 3. It is the remaining part of the deciduas.

The correct answer is a - 2, b - 1, c - 3.

Decidua basalis: The maternal component of the placenta is known as the decidua basalis. It is between the embryo and uterine serosa.

Decidua capsularis: The decidua capsularis is the portion underlying the chorion laeve and fuses with it to become the outermost component of the peripheral membranes. As the amniotic cavity expands to fill the uterus, the decidua capsularis becomes thinner until the chorioamnion is in direct contact with the decidua parietalis.

Decidua parietalis: The mucous membrane lining the main cavity of the pregnant uterus elsewhere than at the site of attachment of the chorionic vesicle. It is the remaining part of the deciduas.
The remaining cells of the embryonic disc, after the formation of mesoderm, form ectoderm. Which of the following is not formed by the ectoderm?
Outer layer of tympanic membrane and internal ears.

Connective tissues are not formed by the ectoderm.

The ectoderm is one of the three primary germ layers formed in early embryonic development. It is the outermost layer, and is superficial to the mesoderm (the middle layer) and endoderm (the innermost layer).

The ectoderm differentiates to form epithelial and neural tissues (spinal cord, peripheral nerves and brain). This includes the skin, linings of the mouth, anus, nostrils, sweat glands, hair and nails, and tooth enamel. Other types of epithelium are derived from the endoderm.

Match the following:

a. Amnion 1. It is composed of ectoderm from inside and mesoderm from outside.
b. Chorion 2. It is composed of endoderm from inside and mesoderm from outside.
c. Allantois 3. It is composed of ectoderm from outside and mesoderm from inside.

The correct answer is a - 1, b - 3, c - 2.

Amnion: The amnion is a membrane that closely covers the human and various other embryos when first formed. It is composed of ectoderm from inside and mesoderm from outside. 

Chorion: The chorion is the outermost fetal membrane around the embryo in mammals, birds and reptiles. It is composed of ectoderm from outside and mesoderm from inside.

Allantois: The allantois arises as an endodermally lined ventral outpocketing of the hindgut. It is composed of endoderm from inside and mesoderm from outside.

Which of the following statements is/are false?

a. The primary yolk sac consists of mesoderm inside and endoderm outside.

b. Chorion protects the embryo and forms placenta for metabolic exchange between the foetus and the mother. 

c. Allantois is a sac like structure which arises from the gut of the embryo near the yolk sac.

The yolk sac is the part of the tube outside the embryo.

The yolk sac is formed from hypoblast endoderm and extraembryonic mesoderm. The hypoblast separates from the inner surface of the embryonic disc in early blastocyst stage, forming an endodermal tube within the trophoblast tube. The hypoblast tube is invested with splanchnic mesoderm after its formation and splitting.
Which of the following is formed by the endoderm?

Inner layer of tympanic membrane is formed by the endoderm.

The inner mucosal layer of the tympanic membrane is derived from the endoderm of the first pharyngeal pouch and covered with simple cuboidal epithelium that is continuous with the lining of the tympanic cavity.

Match the following:

a. Foetal placenta 1. The type of placenta that is shared by the uterine wall of the mother.
b. Maternal placenta 2. The type of placenta in which the maternal blood and chorion are in direct contact. 
c. Haemochorial placenta 3. The type of placenta that is contributed by the foetus.

The correct answer is a - 3, b - 1, c - 2.

Foetal placenta: It is the type of placenta that is contributed by the foetus.

Maternal placenta:  It is the type of placenta that is shared by the uterine wall of the mother.

Haemochorial placenta: The haemochorial placenta is the type of placenta in which maternal blood is in direct contact with the chorionic villi which are covered by maternal blood and exchange of gases and nutrients from mother's blood and foetus takes place as observed in humans.

Parturition is the process of expelling the fully formed young one from the mother's uterus. It is controlled by which of the following hormones?

a. Relaxin

b. Prolactin

c. Oxytocin

d. HCG

Parturition is controlled by relaxin and oxytocin.

Oxytocin: It helps in the uterine contractions during parturition and the release of milk during breastfeeding.

Relaxin: Relaxin is a hormone produced by the ovary and the placenta with important effects in the female reproductive system and during pregnancy. In preparation for childbirth, it relaxes the ligaments in the pelvis and softens and widens the cervix.
Which of the following is a primary sex organ of female?
Ovary is the primary sex organ of female reproductive system in human beings. Egg is released from one of the ovary each month. It also releases hormones.
Seminal plasma in human males is rich in:
Seminal plasma along with sperms forms the semen. The seminal plasma provides nourishment to sperms and is rich in fructose and calcium ions.
External genitalia of human female is called:

The external genitalia of human female is called vulva. 

Vulva includes mons pubis, labia majora, labia minora, hymen and clitoris.

The head of epididymis is called caput epididymis.

Epididymis is a long narrow coiled tube attached to the surface of the testis in mammals and reptiles. It acts as temporary storage organ of spermatozoa received from seminiferous tubules.
The primary sex organ of human male is:

Testis is the primary sex organ in human male.

The testes are 2 small organs that are found inside the scrotum. The testes are responsible for making sperm and are also involved in producing a hormone called testosterone.
The layers of flat broad tendons are known as:

The layers of flat broad tendons are known as aponeuroses.

An aponeurosis is a type or a variant of the deep fascia, in the form of a sheet of pearly-white fibrous tissue that attaches sheet-like muscles needing a wide area of attachment. Their primary function is to join muscles and the body parts they act upon, whether bone or other muscles.
What type of freely movable joint is present in between atlas and axis?

Pivot joint is present in between atlas and axis.

The pivot joint is a type of synovial joint. Synovial joints allow considerable movement. Fibrous joints do not allow any movement, cartilaginous joints allow only limited movements.
The heads of all the metatarsal bones are connected by _______ ligaments.

The heads of all the metatarsal bones are connected by transverse metatarsal ligaments.

The deep transverse metatarsal ligament (DTML), which is a series of 4 short ligamentous bands that span between the distal ends of adjacent metatarsal bones and intersect with the plantar ligaments of the metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint, is a narrow band that runs across and connects the heads of the metatarsal bones.
The pea-shaped bone in the wrist is:

The pea-shaped bone in the wrist is pisiform. The pisiform is one of eight and smallest carpal bones that forms part of the wrist joint. It is a small pea-shaped bone. it develops in a tendon and is a sesamoid bone The name pisiform is derived from the Latin word pisum which means "pea". It can be felt on the anteromedial side of the wrist.
Organisms which are not differentiated into sexes
Organisms which have tentacles as locomotory organs

The term sessile refers to an organism that is anchored to a substrate and cannot move about freely. For example, a sessile alga that lives on a rock (its substrate). Another example is a barnacle that lives on the bottom of a ship. Mussels and coral polyps are also examples of sessile organisms.
In which organism are contractile fibrils found?

Hydra is a sessile Coelenterate animal that lives in a freshwater habitat. With the help of its pedal disc, it remains fastened to certain objects (substratum) in the water. Hydra perform locomotion, either in search of food or in response to some light or chemical stimulus. The muscle cells in Hydra, are lacking. That is why, locomotive movements in Hydra are largely contributed by the periodic expansion and contraction of two types of contractile cells, namely the epitheliomuscular cells and the nutritive muscular cells.  With the help of these cells, locomotion in Hydra takes place in many types, such as Floating, Looping, Somersaulting, etc.
How do coelenterates move from one place to another?

Coelenterates move from one place to another by using tentracles.

Tentacles have special structures known as the nematocysts which help in capturing and paralyzing prey. Coelenterates simply wave their tentacles and when a prey comes in contact, the nematocysts inject the toxin that paralyses or kills the prey.
How do body cells like macrophages and leukocytes move?

Body cells like macrophages and leukocytes move by pseudopodial movement.

  • Macrophages are polymorphic cell. These are amoeboid cells and phagocytes of connective tissues. They are having most active lysosomes and phagocytic cells and pathogen. Macrophages remove the dead and damaged cell and clean the body for also known as scavenger cells.
  • White blood cells are leukocytes that are colourless and complete cell. These are found in blood and a bigger than RBCs but their numbers are less. They are formed in red bone marrow, spleen, thymus and lymph nodes from myelocytes.
  • They show amoeboid movement and these are destroyed outside blood vessels and the process by which they come out is known as diapedesis.
How many bones are there in an adult human body?

Bones provide the structure for our bodies. The adult human skeleton is made up of 206 bones. These include the bones of the skull, spine (vertebrae), ribs, arms and legs. Bones are made of connective tissue reinforced with calcium and specialised bone cells. Most bones also contain bone marrow, where blood cells are made.

Bones work with muscles and joints to hold our body together and support freedom of movement. This is called the musculoskeletal system. The skeleton supports and shapes the body and protects delicate internal organs such as the brain, heart and lungs.

Freely movable joints are defined as those joints which can move about in one or in more than one direction.

Synovial joint is an example of one such joint. The bones of this joint are covered inside a synovial membrane. There is a synovial cavity that remains inside. The cavity is composed of synovial fluid. This fluid is very crucial as it acts as a lubricant. It also gives the bones necessary nutrients and allows movement possible in more than one direction. At times it could have happened that we might fall or there might be a jerk in these joints. Then it also functions as a shock absorber. some different types of synovial joints are:

1.Ball and socket joint: It is present between the head of femur and clavicle.

2.Hinge joint: They are present in toes, fingers and ankle.

3.Gliding joint: It is present in wrists and also in the ankle.

4.Pivot joint: They are present in the atlas and axis.

5.Saddle joint : It is present between metatarsals.

An earthworm moves using circular and longitudinal muscles, as well as bristles called setae. The earthworm can push the setae out of its body to grab the soil around it. To move forward, the worm uses its setae to anchor the front of its body and contracts the longitudinal muscles to shorten its body.
Most muscles in our body are attached to the bones, but some are not. Which of the following muscles is not attached to bones?

Smooth muscles and cardiac muscles are not attached to bone. Recall that these types of muscles are under involuntary control. Smooth muscle is responsible for the contractility of hollow organs, such as blood vessels, the gastrointestinal tract, the bladder, or the uterus.
Identify hinge joint(s) from the given alternatives.

Carpals are hinge joints.

The antebrachiocarpal and middle carpal joints are considered ginglymi, but they are not typical of hinge joints; the carpometacarpal joint is arthrodial. Arthrodial joints also exist between carpal bones in each respective row.

Bones that form pelvic girdle are ilium - ischium - pubis.

In discussing the pelvis, a distinction can be made between the "pelvic spine" and the "pelvic girdle." The pelvic girdle, also known as the os coxae, Latin for “bone of the hip,” consists of the fused bones identified individually as the ilium, ischium, and pubis.
Which of the following is not a bone of forelimb in humans?
Tarsal is not a bone of forelimb in humans. In the human ankle there are seven tarsal bones. The talus (astragalus) articulates above with the bones of the lower leg to form the ankle joint.
Actin filaments are found in all eukaryotic cells but reportedly absent in:

Actin filaments are found in all eukaryotic cells but are reportedly absent in nematode sperms.

The protein actin is abundant in all eukaryotic cells. It was first discovered in skeletal muscle, where actin filaments slide along filaments of another protein called myosin to make the cells contract.

Myology (from latin myos "muscle" and logia, "logy") is the science that studies muscles, their physical structure, type of fibers, specific function, and the connections between different muscle groups.
The correct organisation of skeletal muscle is:
Muscle bundles → muscle cells → muscle fibres → sarcomere

The correct organisation of skeletal muscle is fascicles → muscle fibres → myofilaments → sarcomere

Each organised skeletal muscle in our body is made of a number of muscle bundles or fascicles held together by a common collagenous connective tissue layer called fascia. Each muscle bundle contains a number of muscle fibres. A characteristic feature of the muscle fibre is the presence of a large number of parallelly arranged filaments in the sarcoplasm called myofilaments or myofibrils. The portion of the myofibril between two successive ‘Z’ lines is considered as the functional unit of contraction and is called a sarcomere.

Actin was discovered by Straub (1942). Together with myosin and ATP it constitutes the contractile system. In the absence of salt, actin molecules are stable as monomers (G-actin); in the presence of salt, especially divalent cations, actin polymerizes.

A tendon is a fibrous connective tissue that attaches muscle to bone. Tendons may also attach muscles to structures such as the eyeball. A tendon serves to move the bone or structure.

A tendon is a cord of strong, flexible tissue, similar to a rope. Tendons connect your muscles to your bones. Tendons let us move our limbs. They also help prevent muscle injury by absorbing some of the impact your muscles take when you run, jump or do other movements. Your body contains thousands of tendons.

No respiratory pigment is found in cockroach.

Insects do not use respiratory pigments to transport oxygen, rather they have branching tubes called trachae that suck in air. These carry oxygen straight to the tissues. Insect blood is not important for circulation of respiratory gases. Hence they do not have a respiratory pigment.

Oxygenation of blood occurs in lungs.

Oxygenation of blood occurs in the lungs with the help of the blood pigment known as haemoglobin present in RBCs. It is transported to all parts of the body through blood vessels.

Book-lungs are the respiratory organs of arachnida.

A book lung is a type of respiration organ used for atmospheric gas exchange that is found in arachnids, such as scorpions and spiders. Their name describes their structure. Stacks of alternating air pockets and tissue filled with haemolymph give them an appearance similar to a folded book.
Which of the following structures prevent(s) the food from entering into the wind pipe and lungs during swallowing?

Epiglottis prevent(s) the food from entering into the wind pipe and lungs during swallowing.

The oral cavity leads into a short pharynx, which serves as a common passage for food and air. The oesophagus and the trachea (wind pipe) open into the pharynx. A cartilaginous flap, called as epiglottis, prevents the entry of food into the glottis opening of the wind pipe during swallowing.

During hibernation, Frog respires through skin/integument.

The skin of the frog provides an extensive surface for the exchange of gases. It is thin, richly supplied with blood and kept moist by the mucus and water. The cutaneous respiration is always carried out. During hibernation (winter sleep) and aestivation (summer sleep), it is the only method of respiration in a frog. This is also known as cutaneous respiration.
Tracheal tube divides into right and left bronchi at the level of :
Trachea divides at the level of 5th thoracic vertebra into a right and left primary bronchi.
Vital capacity of our lungs include all of the following except :

Vital capacity of our lungs include all of the following except RV.

Vital capacity includes ERV, TV and IRV or the maximum volume of air a person can breathe out after a forced inspiration.
Skin is the only respiratory organ in :

There are no special respiratory organs in Hirudinaria. In addition to its primary role of a protective covering, the skin also serves a respiratory function. It is provided with a rich supply of haemocoelomic fluid in an extensive system of capillaries and capillary loops, which penetrate into the spaces between the inner ends of the epidermal cells.

The value of TV is about 500 ml for an average adult human male but only some part of it enters lung alveoli and rest of it fills respiratory passage. What should be the distribution ratio for alveolar volume /respiratory passage volume:

Tidal volume (TV) = volume moved in one breath. Normal = 500 ml

About 70% of TV reaches alveoli (350 ml) Only this amount is involved in gas exchange

30% in airways =respiratory passage (anatomical dead space)

So ratio = 350:150= 7:3
The exposure of carbon monoxide to animals
