Exotic refers to newly introduced species from outside or some other ecosystem. Local species are called indigenous species. 
Necrosis is a plant deficiency or disease symptom, which means the death of tissue. 
Atrophic means some external factor, which is responsible for slowing down or stopping growth. 
Trophic movements are the growth movements, like phototrophic means growth movement due to light. Geotropic means growth movement due to gravity. 
"Hyper" means more or excess, so hypertrophic refers to more growth or excess growth.
Which of the following produce energy currency of the cell (ATP) through respiration?

Cellular respiration is a metabolic reaction that takes place in the mitochondria of the cell of an organism to convert the energy stored in food into adenosine triphosphate (ATP). Mitochondria are also called as energy factory or powerhouse of the cell as it produces energy currency of the cell. ATP is the energy currency of the cell as it provides the energy required for various metabolic activities.

Solarization is the destruction of chlorophyll molecules. It is prevented by carotenoids. C3 plants may not have the necessary amount of carotenoids and therefore, due to solarization, their chlorophyll molecules get destroyed.
Is irreplaceable and indispensable for the growth of plants

An essential element is an irreplaceable and indispensable element required by plants for healthy growth. It may be required in a large amount (macronutrient) or in very small amounts (micronutrient). For e.g. K +, Na+ and Cl-.
Which of the following hormones can replace vernalization?

Gibberellins affect several reproductive processes in plants. They stimulate flowering, particularly in long-day plants. In addition, gibberellins substitute for the low temperature that biennials require before they begin flowering (vernalisation). If gibberellins are applied to biennials during their first year of growth, flowering occurs without exposure to a period of low temperature. Gibberellins, like auxin, also affect fruit development. Agriculturalists apply gibberellins to several varieties of grapes to produce larger fruits.
How many molecules of ATP are synthesised, if fructose 1,6 diphosphate undergoes aerobic respiration?

Cellular respiration includes all metabolic pathways where carbohydrates and other metabolites are broken down to build up ATP. Aerobic cellular respiration includes pathways that require oxygen. Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate can not directly enter into glycolysis. It should convert into glucose which yields 2 ATP molecules. Then this glucose enters into glycolysis and citric acid cycle which yields 38 ATP molecules. So, altogether 40 molecules of ATP are synthesised if fructose 1,6 diphosphate undergoes respiratory cycles.
An element playing important role in nitrogen fixation is?

An element playing important role in nitrogen fixation is Molybdenum.

In nitrogen fixation, atmospheric nitrogen is fixed into nitrates.

Nitrogen fixation can be done in many ways but in biological nitrogen fixation some microbes are involved in it such as Rhizobium when shows symbiotic association with roots of the plant where it stimulates nodule formation, there’s a leghemoglobin pigment (pink color) which removes oxygen and creates an anaerobic condition for the enzyme nitrogenase, it helps in nitrogen fixation.

The structure of the nitrogenase enzyme has elements: metal, iron, molybdenum (Mo) which are the important element for the formation of the nitrogenase enzyme.
If a plant develops the deficiency of boron, then it will ________.

If a plant develops the deficiency of boron, then it will not flower.

Boron-deficient trees usually exhibit two key visible symptoms: depression of growing points (root tip, bud, flower, and young leaf) and deformity of organs (root, shoot, leaf, and fruit). Boron deficiency affects vegetative and reproductive growth of plants resulting in inhibition of cell expansion, death of meristem and reduced fertility. Plants contain B both in a water-soluble and insoluble form.
Element which helps in electron transport in the process of photosynthesis is _________.

Element which helps in electron transport in the process of photosynthesis is Mangnese.

During noncyclic electron flow the electron hole in \(\mathrm{P}-680\) is filled by electrons obtained by photolysis of water. As a result, there is an evolution of oxygen and the electron move through Mn-protein bound to PS II. In this transport \(\mathrm{Mn}^{++}\) is oxidised to \(\mathrm{Mn}^{+++}\)and then reduced to \(\mathrm{Mn}^{++}\)in a cyclic manner. The manganese thus transfers electrons from water to photosystem II and thus plays an important role in electron transport in the process of photosynthesis.
Identify the elements whose deficiency causes both necrosis and chlorosis.

The plant requires the elements for the growth and developmental processes. The deficiency of the element causes adverse effects on the growth of the plant. The deficiency of the elements Mg and K results in the necrosis and chlorosis. Necrosis is the death of the living tissue and chlorosis is the decolourisation of the pigment of the leaves.
Which one of the following symptoms is not due to manganese toxicity in plants?
Calcium translocation in shoot apex is inhibited
Deficiency in both Iron and Nitrogen is induced
Appearance of brown spot surrounded by chlorotic veins

'Deficiency in both Iron and Nitrogen is induced' symptom is not due to manganese toxicity in plants.

The prominent symptom of manganese toxicity is the appearance of brown spots surrounded by chlorotic veins. It is important to know that manganese competes with iron and magnesium for uptake and with magnesium for binding with enzymes. Manganese also inhibit calcium translocation in shoot apex. Therefore, excess of manganese may, in fact. induce deficiencies of iron, magnesium and calcium.
Study the given figures carefully showing the development of root nodules and arrange them in a correct sequence.

The root nodules formation in legumes involve following events:

(i) Rhizobia multiply and colonize the surroundings of roots and get attached to epidermal and root hair cells. 

(ii) The root-hairs curl and the bacteria invade the root-hair. 

(iii) An infection thread is produced carrying the bacteria into the cortex of the root, where they initiate the nodule formation in the cortex of the root. Then the bacteria are released from the thread into the cells which leads to the differentiation of specialized nitrogen fixing cells. 

(iv) The nodule thus formed, establishes a direct vascular connection with the host for exchange of nutrients.

Thus, the correct answer is '(i), (iv), (iii), (ii).'
All of the following statements concerning the Actinomycetes filamentous soil bacterium are correct, except that Frankia.
Can induce root nodules on many plant species.
Can fix nitrogen in the free-living state.
Cannot fix specialized vesicles in which the nitrogenase is protected from oxygen by a chemical barrier involving triterpene hopanoids.
Like Rhizobium, it usually infects its host plant through root hair deformation and stimulates cell proliferation in the host's cortex.

Frankia is a genus of filamentous, nitrogen-fixing bacterium and it forms a symbiotic relationship with many plants. It causes root hair deformation in a way that it enters the cortical cells and induces the nodule formations, which look like those induced by Rhizobium in legumes. It produces three cell types: sporangiospores, hyphae, and diazo-vesicles. The diazo-vesicles are responsible for the supplying of sufficient nitrogen to the host plant during symbiosis. Reductive nitrogen fixation takes place in the diazo-vesicles and this process is protected from molecular oxygen by many layers of tightly stacked hopanoid lipids. It converts atmospheric \(\mathrm{N}_{2}\) gas into ammonia.
Rhizobium meliloti, a nitrogen fixer, forms nodules in the root of ________.

Rhizobium meliloti, a nitrogen fixer, forms nodules in the root of Alfalfa.

Alfalfa (Medicago sativa) is an herb that some people consume as a source of calcium, potassium, phosphorous, iron, and vitamins A, C, E, and K. Alfalfa is most commonly grown as food for livestock animals. In humans, it's often eaten as a garnish, and seems to prevent cholesterol absorption in the stomach.
The plant ash is an indication of ____________.

The plant ash is an indication of mineral salts absorbed by plants.

Plant ash is the residue left behind, when plants are heated to high temperature. Fresh weight of plant includes weight of water and protoplasm. Dry weight is the mass of protoplasm alone, when water has escaped as vapours. Further heating gives us plant ash, which is an indication of minerals absorbed by plants.
Conversion of ammonia into nitrite and nitrate is _____________.

Conversion of ammonia into nitrite and nitrate is Nitrification. It is a process in which there is conversion of ammonia into nitrite and nitrates with the help of nitrifying bacteria, for example, Nitrosomonas, Nitrosococcus, Nitrobacter, etc.

The process of converting the ammonia to nitrates involves, mainly two steps, which include the conversion of ammonia to nitrates, and these nitrites further converted to nitrates.

During the first step of conversion of ammonia to nitrite, ammonia is oxidized by ammonia-oxidizing bacteria.

\(\mathrm{NH}_{3}+\mathrm{O}_{2} \rightarrow \mathrm{NO}^{2-}+3 \mathrm{H}++2^{\mathrm{e}-}\)

Next in order to convert nitrite to nitrate, they require nitrite-oxidizing bacteria.

\(\mathrm{NO}_{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightarrow \mathrm{NO}^{3-}+2 \mathrm{H}++2^{\mathrm{e}-}\)

The enzymes required are ammonia monooxygenase and hydroxylamine oxidoreductase. Nitrification is very important because it shows the availability of nitrogen as fertilizer.
Promoting many enzymatic activities that regulate plant processes

Potassium is involved in promoting many enzymatic activities that regulate plant processes.

Potassium is a macronutrient absorbed by the plant in the form of potassium ions (K+). It is required in the abundant quantities in the meristematic tissues, buds, leaves and root tips. It is involved in the activation of many enzymes that help in the regulation of plant processes.
Donnan equilibrium is a good mechanism for __________.

Donnan equilibrium is a good mechanism for Accumulation of ions.

Donnan equilibrium explains passive mineral absorption in plants. According to this concept, the occurrence of a nondiffusible ion in the cell interior will cause the similarly charged external ion to diffuse inwards. The other ion will diffuse inwards till the multiple of free cations and anions in the interior becomes equal to the multiple of free cations and anions in the external medium.
Due to the deficiency of manganese, only the upper leaves develop yellow streaks on them because Mn is a/an ___________.

Due to the deficiency of manganese, only the upper leaves develop yellow streaks on them because Mn is a/an immobile element.

Mn is an immobile nutrient. Therefore, it will not move out of older leaves to the new leaves. Symptoms will appear when the plant can no longer extract sufficient amounts of the nutrient from the soil.
Porphyrins are an important constituent of chlorophyll. The element involved in its formation is:

Porphyrins are an important constituent of chlorophyll. The element involved in its formation is Nitrogen.

The chlorophyll molecule consists of a central magnesium atom surrounded by a nitrogen-containing structure called a porphyrin ring; attached to the ring is a long carbon–hydrogen side chain, known as a phytol chain.
Leghaemoglobin in leguminous plants builds up an environment which is ____________.

Leghaemoglobin in leguminous plants builds up an environment which is anaerobic for nitrogenase activity.

The leghaemoglobin is responsible for creating anaerobic conditions in the root nodules of the legume plant. It acts as oxygen scavenger and protects enzyme nitrogenase from oxygen and helps in proper functioning of the enzyme.

Third ventricle is found in Brain of rabbit.

The ventricles are the features of the mammalian brain. These are the cavities in the brain as well as the spinal cord that is filled with the cerebrospinal fluid. These are lined with the choroid plexus made up of tela choroidea, blood vessels and the ependymal cells. The third ventricle is present in the diencephalon wherein, the epithalamus forms the roof, the two halves of the thalami form the lateral walls and the hypothalamus forms the floor. Rabbit is a mammal, so its brain will have the third ventricle.
Given below is a diagrammatic cross section of a single loop of human cochlea. Which one of the following options correctly represent the names of three different parts?
B- Tectorial membrane, C-Perilyph, D- Secretory cells
C- Endolymph, D- Sensory hair cells, A- Serum
D- Sensory, D- Sensory hair cells, A- serum
B- Sensory hair cells, A- Perilymph, C- Tectorial membrane

B- Sensory hair cells, A- Perilymph, C- Tectorial membrane

Perilymph is an extracellular fluid located within the cochlea (part of the inner ear) in two of its three compartments, the scala tympani and scala vestibuli. The ionic composition of perilymph is comparable to that of plasma and cerebrospinal fluid.Tectorial membrane is a membrane having the consistency of jelly that covers the surface of the organ of Corti. It is located above the spiral limbus and spiral organ of corti and elongates to cochlea. Sensory hair cell is the mechanosensory cell which helps in hearing and vestibular function. The organ of corti in the cochlea has sensory cells which hold the hair cell.
Which part of our central neural system acts as a master clock?

Hypothalamus acts as a master clock in the human body. The master circadian clock that regulates 24-hour cycles throughout our bodies is found in a region called the suprachiasmatic nuclei (SCN) in the hypothalamus of the brain. The SCN is made up of two tiny clusters of several thousand nerve cells that "tell time" based on external cues, such as light and darkness. The SCN regulates sleep, metabolism, and hormone production.
Carries sensations from 2 or more different sense organs
Has a common root but branches into two or more nerves to different organs
Has two or more roots from different parts of the brain

A mixed nerve is one which contains both sensory and motor fibres.

Our nervous system is composed of the peripheral nervous system (PNS) and central nervous system (CNS). CNS includes the brain and spinal cord. PNS includes a network of spinal and cranial nerves that link to the brain and spinal cord. The peripheral nervous system has three types of nerves- sensory, motor and mixed.

Sensory nerves are the afferent nerves which carry the sensory information to the CNS. They can recognize the stimuli whether internal or external.

Motor nerves are located in CNS, that send motor signals from CNS to muscles of the body.

Mixed nerves are made of both the sensory and the motor nerves. They can transmit messages in both directions. Cranial nerves are the mixed nerves containing both sensory and motor nerves.
Lateral rectus muscle of the eye is served by which cranial nerve?

Lateral rectus muscle of the eye is served by Abducens cranial nerve.

The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus eye muscle that turns the eye outward away from the midline. 

The oculomotor nerve serves the superior, inferior, and medial rectus muscles and inferior oblique muscles.

The facial nerve serves taste buds, facial muscles, and the associated glands. 

Spinal accessory nerves are not cranial nerves. These are the part of peripheral nervous system.
Which part of brain is supposed to be damaged if in an accident, a person lose control of water balance, hunger and body temperature?

The hypothalamus is the control centre for many autonomic functions of the peripheral nervous system. Connections with structures of the endocrine and nervous systems enable the hypothalamus to play a vital role in maintaining homeostasis. The hormones produced by this area of the brain govern body temperature, thirst, hunger, sleep, circadian rhythm, moods, sex drive, and the release of other hormones in the body. Hence, if hypothalamus is damaged in an accident, control of water balance, hunger and body temperature will be lost.
Which one of the following pairs of structures distinguishes a nerve cell from other types of cell?

Perikaryon and dendrite pairs of structures distinguishes a nerve cell from other types of cell.

The soma or perikaryon or cyton, is the bulbous end of a neuron, containing the cell nucleus. Dendrites are the branched projections of a neuron, that act to propagate the electrochemical stimulation received from other neural cells to the cell body, or soma, of the neuron from which the dendrites project. Other cells have a nucleus, mitochondria, flagellum, medullary sheath, vacuoles and fibres but not perikaryon or dendrites.
When a neuron is in resting state, i.e., not conducting any impulse, the axonal membrane is:
Comparatively more permeable to \(\mathrm{Na}^{+}\) ions and nearly impermeable to \(\mathrm{K}^{+}\) ions
Comparatively more permeable to \(\mathrm{K}^{+}\) ions and nearly impermeable to \(\mathrm{Na}^{+}\) ions

When a neuron is in resting state, i.e., not conducting any impulse, the axonal membrane is comparatively more permeable to \(\mathrm{K}^{+}\) ions and nearly impermeable to \(\mathrm{Na}^{+}\) ions.

Resting membrane is the condition in which there is no propagation of impulse. As the impulse passes from one part of the neuron to other the conductivity of the ions in the previous part decreases and the ion channels start closing. During this stage, \(\mathrm{K}^{+}\) ion channels are opened as they slow workers and also called as lazy channels. They take more time to close and hence they remain open. \(\mathrm{Na}^+\) channels are closed as the impulse passes off. Due to the presence of opened \(\mathrm{K}^{+}\) channels, the permeability of \(\mathrm{K}^{+}\) is more and as the na+ channels are closed the membrane is impermeable to \(\mathrm{Na}^+\). So the resting membrane of axon have more \(\mathrm{K}^+\) inside and more na+ outside.

Which of the following are true about the brain?

A. The main thinking part of the brain is the hindbrain.

B. Centres of hearing, smell, memory, sight, etc., are located in the forebrain.

C. Involuntary actions like salivation, vomiting, blood pressure are controlled by the medulla in the hindbrain.

D. Cerebellum does not control posture and balance of the body.

Statement C and D are true.

The lower part of brain stem forms the hindbrain which comprises of the medulla oblongata, pons, and cerebellum. Cerebrum serves to receive sensory inputs, to bring about integration before commanding voluntary motor responses, to coordinate the activities of another part of the brain, and to carry out higher thought processes for learning, memory, language and speech. The cerebrum is part of the forebrain. Medulla oblongata consists of reflex centres that control heartbeat, blood vessel diameter, and rhythm of breathing as well as other vital and involuntary functions. Cerebellum serves to coordinate the voluntary movements of skeletal muscles as well as posture, balance, and equilibrium.

Unipolar neurons are found only in the spinal cord.

Unipolar (pseudo-unipolar) neurons are sensory neurons with cell bodies located in spinal and cranial nerve ganglia. Unipolar neurons are sometimes called pseudo-unipolar because embryologically they originate as bipolar neurons and subsequently become unipolar.
Which is not conditioned acquired reflexes of the following options?

Knee - jerk is not conditioned acquired reflexes.

A conditioned acquired reflex is the reflex that is under the control of a stimulus. It is a learned response to the previously neutral stimulus. For examples, riding a bicycle, typing, knitting, etc. An unconditioned acquired reflex is an unlearned response. It occurs naturally and spontaneously in response to an unconditioned stimulus. For example, knee jerk, ankle reflex, jerking of hand back after touching a hot oven.
Nissl granules are found in cyton of nerve cells. These have affinity for basic dyes. The granules are made up of:

Nissl granules are found in cyton of nerve cells. These have affinity for basic dyes. The granules are made up of Ribosomes.

Nissl granule is a large granular body found in neurons. It consists of rough endoplasmic reticulum and clusters of free ribosomes and are a site of protein synthesis. It was named after Franz Nissl, a German psychiatrist, who invented the Nissl staining method.
Which of the following nerves arises from organ of Corti?

The cochlear nerve arises from organ of Corti.

The organ of Corti consists of outer hair cells, inner hair cells, inner pillar cells, outer pillar cells, tunnel of Corti, phalangeal cells (cells of Deiters), cells of Hensen and cells of Claudius. The sensory hairs project from the outer ends of the hair cells into the scala media, while from the inner end of the cells nerve fibres arise, which unite to form the cochlear nerve.
Iodopsin is a light sensitive (photosensitive) pigment and is present in the ______________.

Iodopsin is a light sensitive (photosensitive) pigment and is present in the Cones.

Rods and cones are used to process light, in a human eye. 

Cones have iodopsin and are found mainly in the central area of the retina (fovea), while rods containing rhodopsin are found in the peripheral retina. 

Cones sense colour and need more light than rods to work well. 

Cones are most helpful in normal or bright light. 

There are 3 types of cones - red, green, and blue - to help you see different ranges of colour. Together, these cones sense combinations of light waves, that enable our eyes to see millions of colours. 

Iodopsin is a photosensitive violet pigment that occurs in the cones of the retina and is transformed by light into retinal and opsin protein.

Dieter's cells are found in Organ of corti.

Deiters cells are the cochlear supporting cells in the inner ear. Each outer hair cell is supported by a phalangeal cell of Deiters or supporting cell, which holds the base of the hair cell in a cup-shaped depression. From each Deiters cell, a projection extends upward to the stiff membrane, the reticular lamina, that covers the organ of Corti.

Match the following:

Diseases Causing pathogen
A. Gonorrhoea 1. Treponema pallidum
B. Syphilis 2. Human Papilloma virus
C. Genital warts 3. Neisseria gonorrhoeae

A. Gonorrhoea - Gonorrhoea is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by bacteria called Neisseria gonorrhoeae or gonococcus.

B. Syphilis - Syphilis is a chronic bacterial infection that can be transmitted through sexual contact. Syphilis is caused by a type of bacteria known as Treponema pallidum.

C. Genital warts - Genital warts are a type of sexually transmitted disease (STD). The disease causes warts (small bumps or growth ) to form in and around the genitals and rectum. it is caused by Human Papilloma virus.

The dramatic increase in the population size over a relatively short period is called population explosion. Which of the following are the primary factors for population explosion?

A. Decrease in death rate

B. Development of agriculture

C. Protection from natural risks

D. Increase in longevity

Decrease in death rate and Development of agriculture are the primary factors for population explosion.

Population explosion means a sudden increase in the number of individuals in a particular species. The term is used to refer to the world’s human population. In India, Population explosion has become a severe matter of concern because the increase in population leads to poverty and illiteracy.

Directions: In the following question, two statements are given. One is assertion and the other is reason. Examine the statements carefully and mark the correct answer according to the instructions given below.

Assertion: Use of condom is a safeguard against AIDS and other sexual diseases, besides checking pregnancy.
Reason: Certain contraceptives are inserted under the skin of the upper arm to prevent pregnancy.
Both Assertion and Reason are true and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion.
Assertion is true, but Reason is false.

Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion.

Condoms are a "barrier" method of contraception. They are made of very thin latex (rubber), polyurethane or polyisoprene and are designed to prevent pregnancy by stopping sperm from meeting an egg. They can also protect against STIs if used correctly during vaginal, anal and oral sex.

Implantable contraception (often called the birth control implant) is a small, flexible plastic tube that doctors put under the skin of the upper arm. The tube releases hormones that can help protect against pregnancy for up to 3 years.
Which of the following 'Disease - Causing pathogen' pairs is incorrectly matched?

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is caused by either staphylococcus or streptococcus bacteria.

These bacteria normally live on the skin and in the nose or mouth without causing harm, but if they get deeper into the body they can release toxins that damage tissue and stop organs working.
Which one of the following types of IUDs makes the uterus unsuitable for implantation and the cervix hostile to the sperms?

Progestasert makes the uterus unsuitable for implantation and the cervix hostile to the sperms.

The Progestasert system combines the advantageous features of IUDs and oral minidose progestogen preparations. An internal device continuously delivers progesterone for 1 year to the uterine lumen and endometrium.
Oral contraceptive pills check ovulation and are a combination of:

Oral contraceptive pills check ovulation and are a combination of estrogen and progestogen.

Oral contraceptive pills are tablets that contain estrogen and progesterone, which are taken by mouth to prevent pregnancy, and the mechanism which prevents pregnancy is by preventing ovulation by suppressing the release of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone.
Which of the following is a reversible contraceptive which emits progestogen, that thickens the cervical mucus, making it impenetrable to sperm?

Mirena IUD is a reversible contraceptive which emits progestogen, that thickens the cervical mucus, making it impenetrable to sperm.

Mirena is a hormonal intrauterine device (IUD) that can provide long-term birth control (contraception). The device is a T-shaped plastic frame that's inserted into the uterus, where it releases a type of the hormone progestin.

Which of the following hormones are necessary for ovulation?

A. FSH

B. HCG

C. LH

D. CRH

FSH and LH hormones are necessary for ovulation.

In women, LH helps control the menstrual cycle. It also triggers the release of an egg from the ovary. This is known as ovulation. LH levels quickly rise just before ovulation. LH in synergy with follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates follicular growth and ovulation. In women, FSH helps control the menstrual cycle and stimulates the growth of eggs in the ovaries. FSH levels in women change throughout the menstrual cycle, with the highest levels happening just before an egg is released by the ovary. This is known as ovulation.

Directions: In the following question, two statements are given. One is assertion and the other is reason. Examine the statements carefully and mark the correct answer according to the instructions given below.

Assertion: Copper -T is an IUD and is an effective contraceptive in human females.

Reason: Copper - T prevents passage of sperm from vagina upwards into the Fallopian tube.
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.

A is true but R is false.

A copper IUD is a small device with a fine copper wire wrapped around a plastic frame. It's placed inside the uterus to prevent pregnancy. A fine nylon thread is attached to the IUD - the thread comes out through the cervix into the top end of the vagina.

Infertility refers to the biological inability of an individual to contribute to conception, or to a female who cannot carry a pregnancy to full term. Which of the following is/are the reason(s) for infertility?

Aspermia, Lack of ovulation and Oligospermia all are reasons for infertility.

Aspermia -  It is the complete lack of semen with ejaculation, due to either an inability to transport semen (anejaculation) or to ejaculate in an antegrade direction, which is associated with infertility.

Lack of ovulation - Anovulation happens when an egg (ovum) doesn't release from your ovary during menstrual cycle. An egg is needed to have a pregnancy. Since multiple hormones are involved in ovulation, there are many causes of anovulation. Chronic anovulation is a common cause of infertility.

Oligospermia - It means to have a low sperm count.

Match the following:

A. ZIFT 1. In this, ovum collected from a donor is transferred into the Fallopian tube. 
B. GIFT 2. In this, zygote with up to 8 blastomeres is transferred into the Fallopian tube.
C. IUT 3. In this, embryos with more than 8 blastomeres are transferred into the uterus.

A. ZIFT -  In this, zygote with up to 8 blastomeres is transferred into the Fallopian tube - Zygote intra fallopian transfer (ZIFT) is an infertility treatment used when a blockage in the fallopian tubes prevents the normal binding of sperm to the egg. Egg cells are removed from a woman's ovaries, and in vitro fertilised. The resulting zygote is placed into the fallopian tube by the use of laparoscopy.

B. GIFT -  In this, ovum collected from a donor is transferred into the Fallopian tube - GIFT stands for Gamete Intra-Fallopian Transfer. It is a technique in which the male and female germ cells required to begin formation of a human embryo are injected into a woman's fallopian tubes of the female for fertilization.

C. IUT - In this, embryos with more than 8 blastomeres are transferred into the uterus - If embryo contains more than 8 blastomeres and it is transferred into uterus than it is called intra uterine transfer (IUT).
Which of the following techniques is used for females who cannot produce a viable ovum but can provide a suitable environment for fertilisation and further development.?

GIFT technique is used for females who cannot produce a viable ovum but can provide a suitable environment for fertilisation and further development.

GIFT - GIFT stands for Gamete Intra-Fallopian Transfer.  In this, ovum collected from a donor is transferred into the Fallopian tube. It is a technique in which the male and female germ cells required to begin formation of a human embryo are injected into a woman's fallopian tubes of the female for fertilization.
Amniocentesis is a technique of drawing amniotic fluid and testing it. Which of the following is not a property of amniocentesis?
It is used for detecting congenital diseases.
It is used to find metabolic disorders.
This technique can be used to detect the sex of the developing baby.

Postnatal diagnostic technique is not a property of amniocentesis.

Amniocentesis is a prenatal procedure that doctor may recommend to have during pregnancy. The test checks for fetal abnormalities (birth defects) such as Down syndrome, cystic fibrosis or spina bifida. In most cases, the results are normal. Amniocentesis is performed between 16 and 20 weeks into the pregnancy.
Which of the following is an ultra sensitive technique of direct detection of infection through amplification of minute amount of nucleic acid from the genome of the concerned pathogen?

PCR is an ultra sensitive technique of direct detection of infection through amplification of minute amount of nucleic acid from the genome of the concerned pathogen.

PCR - polymerase chain reaction - A laboratory method used to make many copies of a specific piece of DNA from a sample that contains very tiny amounts of that DNA. Polymerase chain reaction allows these pieces of DNA to be amplified so they can be detected. Polymerase chain reaction may be used to look for certain changes in a gene or chromosome, which may help find and diagnose a genetic condition or a disease, such as cancer. It may also be used to look at pieces of the DNA of certain bacteria, viruses, or other microorganisms to help diagnose an infection.
Which of the following diseases causes itching sensation of the genitals, leucorrhoea and even abortion in women?

Trichomoniasis causes the itching sensation of the genitals, leucorrhoea and even abortion in women.

Trichomoniasis is a common sexually transmitted infection caused by a parasite. In women, trichomoniasis can cause a foul-smelling vaginal discharge, genital itching and painful urination. Men who have trichomoniasis typically have no symptoms.
Which one is not a sexually transmitted disease?

Hepatitis-B is not a sexually transmitted disease.

Hepatitis B is a serious liver infection caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV). For some people, hepatitis B infection becomes chronic, meaning it lasts more than six months. Having chronic hepatitis B increases risk of developing liver failure, liver cancer or cirrhosis — a condition that permanently scars of the liver.
In ET technique embryo is transferred into:

In ET (embryo transfer) technique, in vitro fertilized embryo is transferred into fallopian tube or uterus for further development.

This is a method by which embryos are loaded into the inner sheath of a soft-tipped catheter and threaded through the remaining outer sheath of another catheter that has already passed through the endocervix.
Introduction of sex education in schools should be encouraged to:
To provide right information to the young
To avoid interaction between boys and girls

Sex education in schools should be encouraged to provide right information to young and to discourage children from believing in myths and misconceptions about sex related aspects.

Sex education should be compulsory in every school. Comprehensive sex education is important for young people to prepare themselves for any bodily changes and maintain their healthy and hygienic well being.
Disease or infections which are transmitted through sexual intercourse are collectively called:

Venereal Diseases (VD) also referred to as Sexually transmitted infections (STI) and sexually transmitted diseases (STD) are infections that are commonly spread by sex, especially vaginal intercourse, anal sex or oral sex. Most STIs initially do not cause symptoms.
Action plans and programmes to attain total reproductive health called family planning were initiated in India in:

The first action plan to attain total reproductive health called family planning was initiated in 1951 in India after independence.

India was amongst the first countries in the world to initiate action plans and programs at a national level to attain total reproductive health as a social goal. These programs called family planning were initiated in 1951 and were periodically assessed over the past decades.
Which of the following sentences is false regarding asexual reproduction?
The whole cell acts as a reproductive unit in protists and monerans.
Budding is a form of asexual reproduction seen only in unicellular organisms.
Vegetative reproduction is a type of asexual reproduction.

The statement "Budding is a form of asexual reproduction seen only in unicellular organisms." is false regarding asexual reproduction.

Budding is a type of asexual reproduction, which is most commonly associated in both multicellular and unicellular organisms. Bacteria, yeast, corals, flatworms, Jellyfish and sea anemones are some animal species which reproduce through budding.
Which of the following spores are released through ostiole, a small opening at the apex?

Pycnidia are released through the ostiole, a small opening at the apex.

Pycnidium: a flask-shaped fruiting body bearing conidiophores and conidia on the interior and occurring in various imperfect fungi and ascomycetes.
Zoospores, which are characteristic of oomycota (fungus like eukaryotic organism), are:

Zoospores, which are characteristic of oomycota (fungus like eukaryotic organism), are heterokont.

Heterokonts are a group of protists (formally referred to as Heterokonta, Heterokontae or Heterokontophyta). The group is a major line of eukaryotes. Most are algae, ranging from the giant multicellular kelp to the unicellular diatoms, which are a primary component of plankton.
Slips for vegetative reproduction are found in:

Slips for vegetative reproduction are found in "Tapioca". Tapioca plant (Cassava) can be vegetatively propagated by stem cuttings.

A part which is cut from the plant roots in vegetation propagation is called slips. Slips is used to develop the the new plant in fruit or vegetable . Slips develop the tuberous plant roots for vegetative propagation. For example - sweet potato.
Centrioles are absent in the sperm of:

Centrioles are absent in the sperm of Mice.

A mouse ejaculation contains about 9.5 million sperm—each about 124 micrometres long—and that of an elephant (56 micrometres) over 200 billion sperm, they said. For species where females mate with multiple males, sperm are in sharper competition with one another to fertilise the egg.
Metacystic trophozoites are formed during the life cycle of:

Metacystic trophozoites are formed during the life cycle of Entamoeba.

Life cycle of Entamoeba histolytica. 1 Cysts with 4 nuclei (i.e., metacysts) are ingested orally with contaminated food or drinking water ( A–C). 2–4 After excysting in the small intestine, both the cytoplasm and nuclei divide to form 8 small amoebulae (i.e., metacystic trophozoites).
Hormogonia is a method of vegetative reproduction seen in:

Hormogonia is a method of vegetative reproduction seen in  blue-green algae. Hormogonia are motile filaments produced by many filamentous cyanobacteria that function in dispersal, phototaxis and the establishment of nitrogen-fixing symbioses.
Seasonal breeding in some animals is controlled by:

Seasonal breeding in some animals is controlled by hypothalamus.

Seasonal breeding is under the control of central circadian regulatory system located in the SCN. It controls through neuroendocrine mechanism involving the hypothalamus, pituitary and pineal gland.
During the anestrus phase of estrus cycle:

During the anestrus phase of the Anestrus cycle, the cycle rests.

Anestrus refers to the phase when the sexual cycle rests. This is typically a seasonal event and controlled by light exposure through the pineal gland that releases melatonin. Melatonin may repress stimulation of reproduction in long-day breeders and stimulate reproduction in short-day breeders. Melatonin is thought to act by regulating the hypothalamic pulse activity of the gonadotropin-releasing hormone.
There are 3 barriers between mother's blood and foetal blood
There are 2 barriers between mother's blood and foetal blood
There are 6 barriers between mother's blood and foetal blood
There is no barrier between mother's blood and foetal blood

In the placenta of guinea pigs,  there are 2 barriers between the mother's blood and fetal blood.

The placenta is considered the key barrier between the mother and fetus, regulating delivery of essential nutrients, removing waste as well as protecting the fetus from potentially noxious substances.
In multi-nucleate protozoa like Opalina, during asexual reproduction:
Only nucleus divides but the cytoplasm does not
Only cytoplasm divides but the nuclei do not

In multi-nucleate protozoa like Opalina, during asexual reproduction only cytoplasm divides but the nuclei do not.

Plasmotomy: It is the division of the multinucleate protist into two or more multinucleate offspring by the division of cytoplasm without nuclear division. It occurs in Opalina.
The common mode of asexual reproduction seen in Ephelora (protozoan), Sycon (sponge), Planaria (flatworm), Eusyllis (annelid) and Botryllus (tunicate) is:

The common mode of asexual reproduction seen in Ephelora (protozoan), Sycon (sponge), Planaria (flatworm), Eusyllis (annelid) and Botryllus (tunicate) is budding.

Asexual reproduction in free-living species usually involves nuclear division and the division of the cell into two identical daughter cells of equal size by binary fission. In parasitic protozoans and some free-living species, multiple fission, resulting in the production of many offspring that may not resemble the parent cell, is normal. During the cycle of growth and division, the protozoan undergoes a series of identifiable phases: a division phase, a growth phase during which the cell increases substantially in size, a phase of DNA synthesis, and a phase of preparation for division, which extends from the end of DNA synthesis until the initiation of division. The division of the cytoplasm (cytokinesis) is preceded by the division of the nucleus or nuclei.

Choose the correct sentences from the following with respect to external fertilisation:

a. Water acts as an essential medium for external fertilisation.

b. Male and female gametes are released at the same time.

c. External fertilisation is successful with few gametes.

d. Externally fertilised eggs have better chances of survival.

With respect to external fertilization below sentence is correct:

a. Water acts as an essential medium for external fertilization.

b. Male and female gametes are released at the same time.

External fertilization is a mode of reproduction in which a male organism's sperm fertilizes a female organism's egg outside of the female's body. It is contrasted with internal fertilization, in which sperm are introduced via insemination and then combine with an egg inside the body of a female organism.
Which of the following sentences is false?
Organism's habitat is one of the factors on which the type of reproduction depends.
Dioceous organisms are only seen in animals.
Clones are never obtained in sexual reproduction.

Dioceous organisms are only seen in animals." is false.

Dioecious organisms are seen in both plants and animals. Papaya, date palm and most of the animals are dioecious.
During cleavage of a fertilised egg, the blastomeres become arranged in spiral manner around the animal-vegetal axis in:

During cleavage of a fertilised egg, the blastomeres become arranged in spiral manner around the animal-vegetal axis in annelids.

In Spiralia, which include annelids, mollusks, and flatworms, "spiral cleavage" produces a highly stereotypic, spiral-like arrangement of blastomeres and swimming trochophore-type larvae with rotational (spiral) symmetry.
The transporters that mediate the movement of proteins, ribosomal unit and DNA inside and outside the nucleus are referred to as:

The transporters that mediate the movement of proteins, ribosomal unit and DNA inside and outside the nucleus are referred to as karyopherins.

Karyopherins, also known as importins or exportins, are a superfamily of nuclear transport receptors that facilitate the translocation of proteins, RNAs, and ribonuclear particles across the NPC in a Ran GTP hydrolase-dependent process.
Which of the following cells represent a source for isolating pure plasma membranes for biochemical analysis?
Mammalian red blood cells do not contain nuclei or internal membranes, so they represent a source from which pure plasma membranes can be easily isolated for biochemical analysis.

The inner layer of the plasma membrane is negatively charged due to predominance of

a. Phosphatidylserine

b. Phosphatidylinositol

c. Phosphatidylcholine

d. Sphingomyelin

Phosphatidylserine, a phospholipid with a negatively charged head-group, is an important constituent of eukaryotic cellular membranes.

PS is an activator of the protein kinase C, and PS exposure to the cell surface plays a key role in platelet aggregation as well as in elimination of apoptotic cells [51]. Due to its net negative charge, PS yields abundant [M-H]− ions in negative ion mode while [M+H]+ or [M+Na]+ ions are formed in positive mode.
Spitzenkörper is a component of the endomembrane system of:

Spitzenkörper is a component of the endomembrane system of fungi.

The Spitzenkörper functions in the export of materials packaged in vesicles, but the process of membrane (vesicle) import, or endocytosis, may be equally important in fungal growth.
Woronin body in some cells of fungus is derived from ____________.

Woronin body in some cells of fungus is derived from peroxisomes.

Woronin bodies are membrane-bound organelles of filamentous ascomycetes that mediate hyphal compartmentalization by plugging septal pores upon hyphal damage. Their major component is the peroxisomal protein Hex1, which has also been implicated in additional cellular processes in fungi.
Highly folded plasma membrane which gathers light in bacteria like green sulfur bacteria is referred to as _____________.

Highly folded plasma membrane which gathers light in bacteria like green sulfur bacteria is referred to as chlorosome.

A chlorosome is a photosynthetic antenna complex found in green sulfur bacteria (GSB) and some green filamentous anoxygenic phototrophs (FAP)
Endomembrane system of the eukaryotes has originated from the:
Inner membrane invaginations of the plasma membrane
Outer membrane vesicles of the endosymbiotic mitochondria

Endomembrane system of the eukaryotes has originated from the outer membrane vesicles of the endosymbiotic mitochondria.

the eukaryotic endomembrane system originated from bacterial OMVs released by the mitochondrial ancestor within the cytosol of its archaeal host at eukaryote origin. Confined within the host's cytosol, OMVs accumulated naturally, fusing either with each other or with the host's plasma membrane.
Obsolete organelles of a cell are recycled in a process called autophagy by:

Obsolete organelles of a cell are recycled in a process called autophagy by lysosomes.

Besides providing the means for degradation, lysosomes are also involved in autophagy regulation and can become substrates of autophagy when damaged. During autophagy, they exhibit notable changes, including increased acidification, enhanced enzymatic activity, and perinuclear localization.
Which of the following events takes place at transitional endoplasmic reticulum?

Formation of vesicles takes place at transitional endoplasmic reticulum.

The ER has a central role in lipid and protein biosynthesis. Its membrane is the site of production of all the transmembrane proteins and lipids for most of the cell's organelles, including the ER itself, the Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, endosomes, secretory vesicles, and the plasma membrane.
Which of the following RNAs is contained in the 40S subunit of eukaryotic ribosome?

In a eukaryotic cell, the ribosome is 80 S with a smaller subunit of 40 S and a larger subunit of 60 S type.

The 40 S subunit has an18 SR RA with 1900 nucleotides and 33 proteins. So, the correct answer is '18 S'.
Which of the intermediate filament proteins is/are structural component(s) of the sarcomeres in muscle cells?

Desmin is a muscle-specific protein and a key subunit of the intermediate filament in cardiac, skeletal and smooth muscles.

A sarcomere is the basic contractile unit of muscle fiber. Each sarcomere is composed of two main protein filaments—actin and myosin—which are the active structures responsible for muscular contraction.
Which of the following cytoskeletal proteins serve(s) as a localised attachment site for other proteins, and prevents the diffusion of certain molecules from one cell compartment to another?

These can assemble to filaments and rings. Therefore, septins can be considered part of the cytoskeleton. The function of septins in cells include serving as a localized attachment site for other proteins, and preventing the diffusion of certain molecules from one cell compartment to another.
Which organelle is involved in the formation of cilia and flagella in animals?

Human cells move by the use of cilia and flagella, organelles which are attached to the basal body (another organelle). Cilia and flagella are tiny, hair-like structures that occupy the surface of the human cell.

Basal bodies are characteristic of the eukaryotic cells which contain a nucleus that travels in its cell by means of flagella or cilia. Cilia and flagella attach to the cell at a protein-based organelle called basal body/granule (modified centriole), which serves both to create and connect the cilia and flagella to the cell.
In which of the following membranes can maximum concentration of cardiolipin be found?

In mammalian cells, but also in plant cells, cardiolipin (CL) is found almost exclusively in the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it is essential for the optimal function of numerous enzymes that are involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism.
In which of the following cells were Golgi bodies first discovered?

In nerve cells were Golgi bodies first discovered.

Owing to its large size and distinctive structure, the Golgi apparatus was one of the first organelles to be discovered and observed in detail. It was discovered in 1898 by Italian physician Camillo Golgi during an investigation of the nervous system.

Match List I (Zoological names) with List II (Common names) and select the correct answer using the codes given below:

List I List II
I. Sitophilus oryzae A. Rice weevil
II. Trogoderma granarium B. Khapra beetle
III. Tribolium castaneum C. Flour beetle
IV. Plodia interpunctella  D. Indian meal moth
<font size="2" face="Arial">I – B, II – C, III – D, IV – A</font>
<font size="2" face="Arial">I – B, II – C, III – A, IV – D</font>
<font size="2" face="Arial">I – A, II – B, III – D, IV – C</font>
<font size="2" face="Arial">I – A, II – B, III – C, IV – D</font>

Callosobruchus chinensis is a common species of beetle found in the bean weevil subfamily and is known to be a pest to many stored legumes. Although it is commonly known as the 'adzuki bean' weevil it is in fact not a true weevil, belonging instead to the leaf beetle family Chrysomelidae. Other common names include the pulse beetle, Chinese bruchid and cowpea bruchid.

The rice weevil (Sitophilus oryzae) is a serious stored product pest, which attacks several crops, including wheat, rice and maize.

The khapra beetle (Trogoderma granarium), also called as cabinet beetle, which originated in South Asia is one of the worlds most destructive pests of grain products and seeds.

The almond moth or tropical warehouse moth (Cadra cautella) is a small stored-product pest. It belongs to the snout moths (family Pyralidae), more specifically to the tribe Phycitini of the huge snout moth subfamily Phycitinae. This species is often confused with the related Indian mealmoth (Plodia interpunctella).
In plant breeding programmes, the entire collection (of plants/seeds) having all the diverse alleles for all genes in a given crop is called :

Germplasm is the living genetic resources that fulfill the purpose of animal and plant breeding, preservation and other research use. Germplasm contains all the diverse alleles for all genes in a given organism.

So, the correct answer is 'Germplasm collection'
An Italian variety of bee introduced in the Indian apiculture is______.

Apis mellifera is an Italian bee variety. It is a very popular bee amongst bee keepers.

The local varieties of bees used for commercial honey production are Apis cerana indica, commonly known as the Indian bee, A. dorsata, the rock bee and A. florae, the little bee.

the correct answer is 'Apis mellifera'
Which of the following is not a micronutrient?

Macro Nutrients are Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Potassium, Magnesium, Carbon, and Hydrogen.

Micro Nutrients are Iron, Manganese, Boron, Molybdenum, Copper, Zinc, Chlorine, Sodium and Silicon.

Potassium

Macro nutrient

  • For formation of sugar, carbohydrates, protein synthesis and division of cell in roots.
  • Maintains cation anion balance.

Zinc

Micro nutrient

  • Essential for Carbohydrate metabolisms, internodal elongation and protein synthesis.

Sulphur

Micro nutrient

  • It is a structural component of amino acids, enzymes and vitamins.
  • It gives flavour to vegetables.

Boron

Micro nutrient

  • Essential for Cell wall synthesis and cell division.
  • For flowering, fruiting, cell division and the movement of hormones.
Which of the following options is/are the advantage(s) of crop rotation?
Helps in the production of crop yield
Leguminous plants grown during crop rotation fix atmospheric nitrogen and enrich soil with nitrogen compounds

Crop rotation is the process of successive growing of crop in the same field. This helps in increasing the fertility of the soil. Helps in a good production of the crop. It decreases the population of pests. It also reduces soil erosion.
Which of the following is the highest milk-yielding variety of cows?
Holstein is a breed of cattle known today as the world's highest production dairy animal. It is black and white due to artificial selection by breeders.
Which of the following plant species would you select for the production of bioethanol?

The production of bioethanol from plants depends on their glucose content. There are various crop plants like maize that have good glucose content but these are already used as a food crop. Therefore, the best alternative is to choose plants that can be used as a biofuel source without disturbing food production. So, the Jatropha plant is used for this purpose. The seeds of this plant are rich in fatty acid methyl esters and these produce a high amount of energy.

A. The oil obtained from Jatropha seeds can be processed to yield the biofuel.

B. One species of Brassica, called B. napus has shown bioethanol properties, but it is not used extensively.

C. Zea mays  is used for bioethanol production in the places where its cultivation is very high, for example, the US. In other places, it is preferably used as a food crop.

Best method to increase crop yield is:

Crop production can be increased by adopting a number of methods like using seeds of improved varieties, using modern method of agriculture, using fertilizers and pesticides. An improved seed variety is most important for better yield.
The superiority of the hybrid over either parent in one or more traits is:

Heterosis, hybrid vigor, or outbreeding enhancement, is the improved or increased function of any biological quality in a hybrid offspring. The adjective derived from heterosis is heterotic

Hybrid obtained from two different plants have one or more traits superior than either of parents.
Production of HGH gene in E. coli
Cloning is the method of increasing the number of individual having similar genetic organization. It is not a means of reproduction or production of the organism.
Taichung Native-1”, a rice variety was introduced in India from________.
Taichung Native-1 is a rice variety introduced in India from Taiwan. This variety of rice is medium sized having long inflorescence. The maturity period is also shorter than usual varieties of rice.
Picking up plants with superior phenotype for further propagation is_______.

Mass selection is a simplest , common and oldest method of crop improvement, in which large number of plants of similar superior phenotype are selected and their seeds are harvested and mixed together to constitute the new variety.
Sonalika and Kalyan Sona are high yielding varieties of_______________.
Sonalika and Kalyan Sona is wheat varieties were introduced in India in 1963. These are high yielding drug-resistant varieties.
The correct sequence of the developmental process in a plant cell is_________.

The correct sequence of the developmental process in a plant cell is Cell division, elongation, differentiation, maturation.

The developmental process in a plant cell starts from cell division, the divided cell growth and show differentiation which gets matured.
Parbhani Kranti, a variety of bhindi (lady finger) is resistant to__________.

Parbhani Kranti, a variety of bhindi (lady finger) is resistant to Yellow mosaic virus.

Prabhani Kranti (example of mutation breeding) is a variety of bhindi which is made resistant to yellow mosaic, virus.

In this Abelmoschus esculentus was transferred from a wild species to produce this new variety.
How can we make our crops disease resistant?
by crossing them with their wild relatives

Our crops could be made disease resistant by crossing them with wild varieties, which has disease resistance gene. This helps in yielding a new breed, which is highly disease resistant as well as carries the features of the existing variety. 

So, the correct answer is 'By crossing them with their wild relatives'
Co-419 and Co-527 are improved varieties of__________.

Co-419 and Co-527 are improved varieties of Sugarcane.

There are number of varieties of sugarcane available based on the suitability of different states of the country. For example, in Maharashtra CoC-671 and Co-86032  and in the drier parts of Tamil Nadu Co-86032 are found to be the best varieties for high productivity and sugar recovery.

Common varieties in Rajasthan include: Co-997, Co-527, Co-6617, CoH-92201, Co-419, Co-527, CoS-91230 etc.
Wild varieties of plants are essential as__________.
The can be used to make domestic varieties.
They provide resistance of diseases by crossing with domestic crops.

Wild varieties of plants are essential as they provide resistance of diseases by crossing with domestic crops.

Wild varieties of plants are essential as they provide resistance of diseases by crossing with domestic crops.

Conservation of wild relatives are essential components of natural and agricultural ecosystems and hence are indispensable for maintaining ecosystem health. Their conservation and sustainable use is very important for improving agricultural production, increasing food security, and maintaining a healthy environment.

The natural populations of many wild varieties are increasingly at risk. They are threatened by habitat loss through the destruction and degradation of natural environment or their conversion to other uses. Deforestation is leading to the loss of many populations of important wild relatives of fruit, nut, and industrial crops. Populations of wild relatives of cereal crops that occur in arid or semi-arid lands are being severely reduced by over grazing and resulting desertification.
_________ is growing of two or more crops simultaneously on the same piece of land in a definite pattern.

Intercropping  is growing of two or more crops simultaneously on the same piece of land in a definite pattern.

Inter-cropping is growing two or more crops simultaneously on the same field in a definite pattern. A few rows of one crop alternate with a few rows of a second crop. For example, soybean + maize, or finger millet (bajra) + cowpea (lobia). 

The crops are selected such that their nutrient requirements are different. This ensures maximum utilization of the nutrients supplied and also prevents pests and diseases from spreading to all the plants belonging to one crop in a field. This way, both crops can give better returns.

'Sonora' and 'Lerma Rojo' are varieties of Wheat.

After assessing the possibility of increasing the wh eat production in India, Wheat scientists introduced five dwarf wheat varieties- Lerma Rojo 64-A, Sonora 63, Sonora 64, Mayo 64 and S 227 along-with around 200 other breeding lines of dwarf wheat. 

These varieties were extensively tested in all the Wheat growing states of the country and it was concluded that the varieties such as 'Lerma Rojo 64-A', 'Sonora 64' and 'PV 18' developed in Mexico and carrying the genes for dwarfism having a high potential for yield in our country too.

Which of the following statements are correct?

(A) The oxidation of pyruvic acid molecules formed in glycolysis occurs inside the mitochondria.

(B) Acetyl COA is a 3-carbon compound.

(C) Under anaerobic conditions, the pyruvic acid formed during glycolysis is reduced to either ethyl alcohol or lactic acid.

(D) Acetyl COA molecules enter into cyclic reactions during Calvin's cycle.

Pyruvate is produced by glycolysis in the cytoplasm, but pyruvate oxidation takes place in the mitochondrial matrix (in eukaryotes). So, before the chemical reactions can begin, pyruvate must enter the mitochondrion, crossing its inner membrane and arriving at the matrix. Therefore option (A) is correct.

Pyruvate—three carbons—is converted to acetyl CoA, a two-carbon molecule attached to coenzyme A. A molecule of coenzyme A is a necessary reactant for this reaction, which releases a molecule of carbon dioxide and reduces a NAD+ to NADH. Therefore option (B) is incorrect.

Pyruvic acid supplies energy to living cells through the citric acid cycle (also known as the Krebs cycle ) when oxygen is present (aerobic respiration); it ferments to produce lactic acid when oxygen is lacking ( fermentation ). Pyruvate is the output of the anaerobic metabolism of glucose known as glycolysis. Therefore option (c) is correct.

The Calvin cycle has three stages. In stage 1, the enzyme RuBisCO incorporates carbon dioxide into an organic molecule. In stage 2, the organic molecule is reduced. In stage 3, RuBP, the molecule that starts the cycle, is regenerated so that the cycle can continue. Therefore option (D) is incorrect.
Which of the following reactions are catalysed by the enzyme phosphofructokinase?
Fructose - 1, 6 - bisphophateFructose - 6 - phosphate
Glucose - 6 - phosphateFructose - 6 - phosphate
G - 3 - P Dihydroxy acetone phosphate
Fructose - 6 - phosphate + ATPFructose - 1, 6 - bisphosphate

Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK1) catalyzes the irreversible conversion of fructose-6-phosphate (F6P) and ATP into fructose-1,6-bisphosphate (F1,6BP) and ADP.

Phosphofructokinase composed of PFKM subunits is involved in the sequence of events that breaks down glycogen to provide energy to muscle cells. Specifically, the enzyme converts a molecule called fructose-6-phosphate to a molecule called fructose 1,6-bisphosphate.
If the CO2 content of atmosphere is as high as 300 parts per million, then _________.
plants would grow for sometime and then die

If the CO2 content of atmosphere is as high as 300 parts per million, thenthe plants would thrive well.

The photosynthetic rate is influenced by many external (light, temperature, carbon dioxide, water, oxygen) and internal (chlorophyll content, protoplasmic condition, accumulation of end products) factors. The concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is 0.03 percent (300 parts per million). Plants can thrive well in this condition.
if respiratory substrate is an organic acid

RQ (Respiratory Quotient) is infinite in anaerobic respiration.

The RQ of anaerobic respiration is infinite. This is because, in anaerobic respiration, the total volume of oxygen consumed is zero as this process occurs in the absence of oxygen and only carbon dioxide is produced. Therefore : RQ = CO2/O2 = 2/0 = infinity.
