Which one of these is a non reducing disaccharide?
Sucrose is a non-reducing sugar because the monosaccharides’ anomeric carbon is involved in glycoside or acetal formation. So it does not have a free -CHO group.
Which one of these is the most highly mineralised tissue of human body?
Tooth enamel is the hardest and most highly mineralized tissue in the body. It is 96% mineral and composed of hydroxyapatite crystals that are 1000 times larger than those found in bone.
What is the utility of iodine number?
It measures the carbon content present in a carbohydrate.
It detects lifetime of a radioactive compound.
It measures the average degree of unsaturation of an unsaturated fatty acid.
It can detect the number of hydroxy groups in a fatty acid.

Iodine numbers are often used to determine the amount of unsaturation in fats, oils and waxes. In fatty acids, unsaturation occurs mainly as double bonds which are very reactive towards halogens, the iodine in this case. Thus, the higher the iodine value, the more unsaturations are present in the fat.
Which molecule is called the adapter molecule?

tRNA is called the adapter molecule.

tRNA is charged by attaching an amino acid at one end. It then binds the ribosome-mRNA complex at the position defined by a codon that codes for an amino acid. So, the tRNA molecule acts as an adaptor because it converts mRNA into proteins by the process of translation.
What is the significance of Heller's Test?
It detects the presence of carbohydrates in urine.
It helps to detect the presence of protein in a patient's urine.
The test is used to detect the presence of blood in urine.
It detects the presence of bacteria in stool.

Heller's test is a chemical test that shows that strong acids cause the denaturation of precipitated proteins. Concentrated nitric acid is added to a protein solution from the side of the test tube to form two layers. A white ring appears between the two layers if the test is positive.

Fatty acids are not dissolvable in water.

Fatty acids made up of ten or more carbon atoms are nearly insoluble in water, and because of their lower density, float on the surface when mixed with water.
In case of biomolecules, which particular force or bond cannot be disrupted by denaturating agents?

In case of biomolecules, covalent peptide bond cannot be disrupted by denaturating agents.

Covalent peptide bond: A covalent bond joining the α-amino group of one amino acid to the carboxyl group of another with the loss of a water molecule.
Which of the following is a sulphur aggregate containing amino acid?

Cysteine is a sulphur aggregate containing amino acid.

Cysteine is a non-essential amino acid important for making protein, and for other metabolic functions. It's found in beta-keratin. This is the main protein in nails, skin, and hair. Cysteine is important for making collagen. It affects skin elasticity and texture.
Which of the following is not essential amino acid?

Essential amino acids cannot be made by the body so you must get them from your diet.

The 9 essential amino acids are: histidine, isoleucine, leucine, lysine, methionine, phenylalanine, threonine, tryptophan, and valine.
Prostaglandins are lipid autacoids derived from arachidonic acid. They both sustain homeostatic functions and mediate pathogenic mechanisms, including the inflammatory response.

Seliwanoff's test is a biochemical test which is used to identify the presence of ketose and aldose. This test is based on the principle that, on heating or on treatment with a concentrated acid, ketoses dehydrate more rapidly than aldoses.
Xanthoproteic Test is utilised to distinguish which specific biomolecule(s)?

Xanthoproteic Test is utilised to distinguish aromatic amino acids.

Xanthoproteic test is used to detect amino acids containing an aromatic nucleus (tyrosine, tryptophan and phenylalanine) in a protein solution which gives yellow color nitro derivatives on heating with conc. HNO3.
Which is the most widely recognised fuel utilised by a human brain?

Glucose is the most widely recognised fuel utilised by a human brain.

Brain functions such as thinking, memory, and learning are closely linked to glucose levels and how efficiently the brain uses this fuel source. If there isn't enough glucose in the brain, for example, neurotransmitters, the brain's chemical messengers, are not produced and communication between neurons breaks down.

Besides green algae, pyrenoids are also present in:

Besides green algae, pyrenoids are also present in Hornworts.

  • Psilotum -  Psilotum is a genus of fern-like vascular plants. It is one of two genera in the family Psilotaceae commonly known as whisk ferns, the other being Tmesipteris
  • Marsilea -Marsilea is a genus of approximately 65 species of aquatic ferns of the family Marsileaceae. The name honours Italian naturalist Luigi Ferdinando Marsili (1656–1730).
  • Selaginella - Selaginella is a pteridophyte. It is also called spikemoss or club moss. It is the largest and the only living genus of the family Selaginellaceae.
  • Lycopsida - a subdivision of Tracheophyta coextensive with the class Lycopodineae comprising vascular plants (as the club mosses and related forms) with small leaves, sessile and adaxial sporangia, and no leaf gaps in the primary vascular cylinder — compare psilopsida , pteropsida , sphenopsida.
Roots with symbiotic association with nitrogen-fixing bacteria are present in:

Roots with symbiotic association with nitrogen-fixing bacteria are present in cycas.

Cycas is a genus of plants belonging to a very ancient lineage, the Cycadophyta, which are not closely related to palms, ferns, trees or any other modern group of plants.
Which of the following sentences is false about Cycas?

The false sentence about cycas is: seeds are borne in seed cones.

  • Cycas is a genus of plants belonging to a very ancient lineage, the Cycadophyta, which are not closely related to palms, ferns, trees or any other modern group of plants.
  • Cycas, genus of 115 species of palmlike cycads in the family Cycadaceae native to tropical and subtropical areas of the Old World. The leaves of sago palm (Cycas revoluta) are widely used as ceremonial “palms” and in floriculture. The pithy stems of this and other species are a source of sago, a food starch.
Three of the following statement regarding cell organelles are correct while one is wrong. Which one is wrong?
Lysosomes are double membraned vesicles budded off from Golgi apparatus and contain digestive enzymes.
Endoplasmic reticulum consists of a network of membranous tubules and helps in transport, synthesis and secretion.
Leucoplasts are bound by two membranes, lack pigment but contain their own DNA and protein synthesizing machinery.
Spherosomes are single membrane bound and are associated with synthesis and storage of lipids.

Lysosomes are small vesicles containing hydrolyzing enzymes and surrounded by a single membrane of up to 100 nanometers in thickness. It is formed by the Golgi body.

Whereas endoplasmic reticulum is a membranous network in the cytoplasm that involved in the formation and transportation of proteins, lipids, steroids etc., leucoplast is the colourless double-membrane bounded plastid which possesses their own DNA and protein synthesising machinery. 

Spherosomes are the small spherical organelle found in the cytoplasm of the plant cells. It is a single membrane-bounded structure which involved in the formation and storage of lipids in plant cells.
Capsule is a polysaccharide layer that lies outside the cell envelope of bacteria. Which organism contains polypeptide of D-glutamic acid in its capsule?

Bacillus anthracis contains polypeptide of D-glutamic acid in its capsule.

Bacillus anthracis is a gram-positive and rod-shaped bacterium that causes anthrax, a deadly disease to livestock and, occasionally, to humans. It is the only permanent pathogen within the genus Bacillus. Its infection is a type of zoonosis, as it is transmitted from animals to humans.

An S-layer (surface layer) is a part of the cell envelope commonly found in archaea, as well as among bacteria. In which of the following bacteria does it bind to pseudomurein or to methanochondroitin?

An S-layer (surface layer) is a part of the cell envelope commonly found in archaea, as well as among bacteria. In Gram positive archaea it bind to pseudomurein or to methanochondroitin.

Gram-positive bacteria are bacteria with thick cell walls. In a Gram stain test, these organisms yield a positive result. The test, which involves a chemical dye, stains the bacterium's cell wall purple. Gram-negative bacteria, on the other hand, don't hold the dye.
What is the similarity between yeast cell Cryptococcus neoformans and Gram-negative bacteria?

Presence of capsule is the similarity between yeast cell Cryptococcus neoformans and Gram-negative bacteria.

Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungus that lives in the environment throughout the world. People can become infected with Cryptococcus neoformans after breathing in the microscopic fungus, although most people who are exposed to the fungus never get sick from it.

Gram-negative bacteria are bacteria that do not retain the crystal violet stain used in the Gram staining method of bacterial differentiation. They are characterized by their cell envelopes, which are composed of a thin peptidoglycan cell wall sandwiched between an inner cytoplasmic cell membrane and a bacterial outer membrane.
In plants, besides nitrogen metabolism, peroxisomes also participate in:

In plants, besides nitrogen metabolism, peroxisomes also participate in photorespiration.

Photorespiration is a process which involves loss of fixed carbon as CO2 in plants in the presence of light. It is initiated in chloroplasts. This process does not produce ATP or NADPH and is a wasteful process. Photorespiration occurs usually when there is the high concentration of oxygen.
Which of the following organisms consist of Braun's lipoprotein (Lpp) in its cell wall?

Yersinia pestis consist of Braun's lipoprotein (Lpp) in its cell wall.

Yersinia pestis is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus bacterium without spores that is related to both Yersinia pseudotuberculosis and Yersinia enterocolitica. It is a facultative anaerobic organism that can infect humans via the Oriental rat flea.
Some pili called type IV generate motile forces. Which kind of motility is generated by type IV pili in Myxococcus xanthus?

Gliding motility is generated by type IV pili in Myxococcus xanthus.

Gliding motility is the ability of certain rod-shaped bacteria to translocate on surfaces without the aid of external appendages such as flagella, cilia, or pili.

Melanosomes are organelles found in animal cell that stores the pigment melanin which is responsible for color and photoprotection in animal cells and tissues. Which motor protein is responsible for carrying melanin to the periphery during behaviourial signalling?

Melanosomes are organelles found in animal cell that stores the pigment melanin that is responsible for color and photoprotection in animal cells and tissues. Kinesin protein is responsible for carrying melanin to the periphery during behaviourial signalling.

Kinesins are found in all eukaryotic organisms and are essential to all eukaryotic cells, involved in diverse cellular functions such as microtubule dynamics and morphogenesis, chromosome segregation, spindle formation and elongation and transport of organelles.
Which of the following mediates the attachment of Staphylococcus aureus to the mucosal cells?

Teichoic acid mediates the attachment of Staphylococcus aureus to the mucosal cells.

The main function of teichoic acids is to provide flexibility to the cell-wall by attracting cations such as calcium and potassium. Teichoic acids can be substituted with D-alanine ester residues, or D-glucosamine, giving the molecule zwitterionic properties.

Mucous cells are large cells shaped like a truncated pyramid. The apex of the cell has a larger lumenal surface than serous cells, but intercellular canaliculi usually are not present between mucous cells. They are joined to their neighbors by junctional complexes and gap junctions.

Staphylococcus aureus has long been recognized as one of the most important bacteria that cause disease in humans. It is the leading cause of skin and soft tissue infections such as abscesses (boils), furuncles, and cellulitis. Although most staph infections are not serious, Staphylococcus.
Eyespot proteins are present in the eyespot apparatus of some unicellular prokaryotes that allow phototaxis to take place. In Chlamydomonas which protein mediates phototaxis?

Eyespot proteins are present in the eyespot apparatus of some unicellular prokaryotes that allow phototaxis to take place. In Chlamydomonas archaeal-type rhodopsins protein mediates phototaxis.

A specialized structure within the cell, the eyespot, aids in the detection of light direction and is key to improving the efficiency of phototactic behavior. The Chlamydomonas reinhardtii eyespot is the most well-studied photoreceptive structure guiding cellular movement.
Endospores are metabolically dormant forms produced inside the bacterial cell. Which of the following organisms produces elliptical centrally located spores?

Endospores are metabolically dormant forms produced inside the bacterial cell. Bacillus cereus organisms produces elliptical centrally located spores.

Bacillus cereus is a Gram-positive, rod-shaped, facultatively anaerobic, motile, beta-hemolytic, spore-forming bacterium commonly found in soil, food and marine sponges. The specific name, cereus, meaning "waxy" in Latin, refers to the appearance of colonies grown on blood agar.
Prosthecae are cellular appendages found basically in freshwater bacteria. How many prosthecae does Caulobacter possess?

Prosthecae are cellular appendages found basically in freshwater bacteria. Caulobacter possess 1 prosthecae.

Prosthecae are semi-rigid extensions of the cell wall and cytoplasmic membrane and have a diameter that is always less than that of the cell. They are characteristic of a number of aerobic bacteria from fresh water and marine environments.

Match the following:

Side ASide B
1. Thermoactinomycesa. Exospores
2. Methylosinusb. Cysts
3. Actinomycetesc. Endospores
4. Azotobacterd. Sporangiospores

Correct match:

Side ASide B
1. Thermoactinomycesc. Endospores
2. Methylosinusa. Exospores
3. Actinomycetesd. Sporangiospores
4. Azotobacterb. Cysts
As such bacterial cells lack internal membranes. An exception to this rule is:

As such bacterial cells lack internal membranes. An exception to this rule is nitrosomonas.

Nitrosomonas is a genus of Gram-negative bacteria, belonging to the Betaproteobacteria. It is one of the five genera of ammonia-oxidizing bacteria and, as an obligate chemolithoautotroph, uses ammonia as an energy source and carbon dioxide as a carbon source in presence of oxygen.
Parenthesomes are barrel shaped structures having an endoplasmic covering. In which of the following eukaryotic cells, is it found?

Parenthesomes are barrel shaped structures having an endoplasmic covering. It is found in Basidomycete fungi.

Basidomycetes are a fungal group belonging to the Eukarya domain, that includes all life forms composed by nucleated cells. Basidomycetes are classified under the Fungi kingdom as belonging to the phylum - mycota.
As per 'Panspermia', life reached Earth in the form of:

The cosmozoic theory is also called the theory of panspermia. According to this theory, life has reached this planet Earth from other heavenly bodies such as meteorites, in the form of highly resistant spores of some organisms. This idea was proposed by Richter in 1865 and supported by Arrhenius (1908) and other contemporary scientists.

Catastrophism describes the differences in fossil forms encountered in successive stratigraphic levels as being the product of repeated cataclysmic occurrences and repeated new creations.

Biogenesis is any process by which lifeforms produce other life forms.

Naturalistic theory or modern theory of the origin of life states that life originated from a collection of chemicals through a progressive series of chemical reactions in which atoms combined into molecules, molecules into simple organic molecules and simple organic molecules into complex, and complex into aggregates which ultimately got organized into the living matter.
Pasteur's experiments and similar ones that followed convinced most people that spontaneous generation of life did not happen because:
Pasteur used very fine mesh screens to cover his flasks.
Pasteur did not boil his flasks for a long time.
Pasteur's swan-necked flasks ruled out the objection that spoiled air could have contaminated his experiments.

Pasteur's experiments demonstrated that when nutrient broths were placed in flasks with swan-necked curves, preventing microorganisms from entering while allowing air exchange, no microbial growth occurred despite prolonged exposure to air. This disproved the notion of spontaneous generation by showing that microorganisms were not spontaneously generated in the broth, but rather came from pre-existing microorganisms in the air. Thus, Pasteur's meticulous experimental design and use of swan-necked flasks provided compelling evidence against spontaneous generation.
From his experiments, S.L. Miller produced amino acids by mixing the following in a closed flask:

Oparin and Haldane proposed a hypothesis. According to this hypothesis, the first form of life came from pre-existing non-organic molecules.

S.L. Miller supported their proposal. He created Earth's reducing atmosphere during the early days of development. He created electric discharge in a closed flask containing methane, hydrogen, ammonia, and water vapour at \(800^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). This resulted in the formation of amino acids.

The first mammals are believed to have appeared during the Mesozoic Era, specifically in the Triassic period, which lasted from approximately 252 million years ago. These early mammals evolved from synapsids, a group of reptiles, and gradually diversified over time. The Triassic period marked a significant transition in Earth's history, witnessing the emergence of various new forms of life, including the ancestors of modern mammals.
Which of the following cannot be explained by Lamarckism?
Degeneration of visual apparatus in cave dwellers

Dull progeny of Nobel laureate cannot be explained by Lamarckism.

Lamarckism proposes that acquired traits during an organism's lifetime can be passed on to its offspring. However, intellectual capabilities, such as intelligence or dullness, are not considered acquired traits in Lamarckian theory and cannot be inherited. The absence of limbs in snakes, long necks of giraffes, and degeneration of visual apparatus in cave dwellers could be explained by Lamarckism through the concept of use and disuse of organs leading to evolutionary changes over generations.
Hardy-Weinberg principle states that allele frequencies get change when evolutionary forces act on a population. Which of the following is not an evolutionary force?

Random mating is not considered an evolutionary force because it does not directly alter allele frequencies within a population. Instead, it is one of the assumptions of the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, which states that mating occurs randomly with respect to genotype frequencies. Mutations , gene flow, and genetic drift are all evolutionary forces that can lead to changes in allele frequencies within populations over time.
Which one of the following options gives one correct example each of convergent evolution and divergent evolution?
Eyes of octopus and mammals, Bones of forelimbs of vertebrates
Thorns of Bougainvillea and tendrils of Cucurbita, Wings of butterfly and birds
Bones of forelimbs of vertebrates, Wings of butterfly and birds
Thorns of Bougainvillea and tendrils of Cucurbita, Eyes of octopus and mammals

Development of similar adaptive functional structures in unrelated groups of organisms is called convergent evolution. It shows analogy. Examples are wings of butterfly and birds, eye of octopus and mammals, flippers of penguins and dolphins, etc. On the other hand, divergent evolution involves the modification of organs to perform different functions as an adaptation to different environments. For example forelimbs of vertebrates (whales, bat, cheetah, human). Though these perform different functions, they have similar anatomical structure.

So, the correct answer is 'Eyes of octopus and mammals, Bones of forelimbs of vertebrates'.
After industrialisation in 1920, there were more dark colored moths in England because
soot from industries changed the colour of white moths
white colored moths immigrated to other areas due to pollution
white colored moths died due to toxic pollutants from industries

The evolution of the peppered moth is an evolutionary instance of directional colour change in the moth population as a consequence of air pollution during the Industrial Revolution. The frequency of dark-coloured moths increased at that time, an example of industrial melanism. Later, when pollution was reduced, the light-coloured form again predominated. Industrial melanism in the peppered moth was an early test of Charles Darwin's natural selection in action, and remains as a classic example.
Change in frequency of alleles in a population results in evolution as proposed by :

According to Hardy-Weinberg principle, disturbance in genetic equilibrium or change of frequency of alleles in a population can be interpreted as accumulation or change in variations that results in evolution. 

Five factors are known to affect Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium,

1. Gene migration or gene flow

2. Genetic drift. 

3. Mutation. 

4. Genetic recombination. 

5. Natural selection.

So, the correct answer is 'Hardy-Weinberg principle'
Which of the following were not among the basic concepts of Lamarckism?

Internal vital forces: Lamarck suggested that organisms possess inherent internal forces or tendencies driving them towards greater complexity and adaptation to their environment.

Use and disuse of organs: Lamarck proposed that the use or disuse of organs by organisms during their lifetime would result in the development or degeneration of those organs, respectively, and these acquired traits could be inherited by offspring.

Inheritance of acquired characters: Lamarck hypothesized that organisms could pass on traits acquired during their lifetime to their offspring, contributing to evolutionary change.

The concept of the struggle for existence, which involves competition among individuals for resources and survival, is more closely associated with Charles Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection, rather than Lamarckism.
Original features of Darwin's finches in Galapagos islands were adapted for:

The small black birds found on Galapagos islands, which later came to be known as Darwin's finches were originally adapted with seed-eating features. From these many other forms evolved with altered beaks depending on the food habit. This enabled them to become insectivorous and vegetarian finches.

So, the correct answer is 'Seed eating'
Which one of the followings is also called Sewall Wright Effect?

Genetic drift is also known as the Sewall Wright effect. It has been observed that genetic drift sometimes may lead to gene variants to disappear completely and thus results in the reduction of genetic variation. It may even lead to an increase in the frequency of the initially rare alleles and to become far more fixed.

Genetic drift can occur only in small, isolated populations during which the gene pool is little enough that chance events can change its makeup substantially. Ronald Fisher is the one who explained survival using Mendelian genetics, also held the view on the genetic drift that genetic drift plays at the foremost a bit part in evolution, and this remained the dominant view for several decades. In the year 1968, population geneticist Motoo Kimura rekindled the talk together with his neutral theory of molecular evolution, which claims that the majority of instances where a genetic change spreads across a population) are caused by genetic drift working on neutral mutations.
The idea of Natural selection as the fundamental process of evolutionary changes was reached:
Independently by Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace in 1900
Independently by Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace in 1859

Both Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace independently reached the idea of natural selection as the fundamental process of evolutionary change. They presented their ideas jointly in 1858, and Darwin published his seminal work "On the Origin of Species" in 1859, outlining the theory of evolution by natural selection.
Which of the following are properties of stabilizing selection?

Stabilizing selection is characterized by the preservation of the intermediate phenotype and the reduction of phenotypic variation in a population. It occurs when the environment remains relatively constant and favors the average phenotype. In such an environment, extreme phenotypes are selected against, leading to the maintenance of the intermediate phenotype. This is because the average phenotype is well-adapted to the prevailing conditions and provides a fitness advantage.
Jurassic period of the Mesozoic era characterized by:
Radiation of reptiles and origin of mammal like reptiles
Gymnosperms are dominant plants and first birds appear

During the Jurassic period of the Mesozoic era, gymnosperms, including conifers and cycads, were the dominant plant group, shaping terrestrial ecosystems. This period saw the emergence of the first birds, evolving from theropod dinosaurs, marking a significant milestone in the evolutionary history of vertebrates. The presence of gymnosperms as dominant plants provided habitat and food sources for diverse terrestrial life forms, including the evolving dinosaurs and the newly emerging birds. Thus, the Jurassic period is characterized by the flourishing of gymnosperms and the appearance of the earliest avian species, contributing to the ecological and evolutionary dynamics of the era.
When two species of different genealogy come to resemble each other as a result of adaptation, the phenomenon is termed:

Convergent evolution is the process whereby organisms not closely related, independently evolve similar traits as a result of having to adapt to similar environments or ecological niches. Convergent evolution creates analogous structures that have similar form or function but were not present in the last common ancestor of those groups. 

Hence two species of different genealogy (a line of descent traced continuously from an ancestor) show resemblance due to similar adaptation. The phenomenon is convergent evolution.
Anatomically the structurally different structures with functional similarity are:

Analogous structures are anatomically different structures in different species that have similar functions but evolved independently in response to similar environmental pressures or ecological niches. These structures do not share a common evolutionary origin but have converged to perform similar functions. Examples of analogous structures include the wings of birds and insects, which both serve the function of flight but have different anatomical structures.
Which one of the following experiments suggests that simplest living organisms could not have originated spontaneously from non-living matter?
Microbes did not appear in stored meat
Larvae could appear in decaying organic matter
Meat was not spoiled, when heated and kept sealed in a vessel

Lazzaro Spallanzani is an Italian scientist, reviewed both Redi's and Needham's data and experimental design and concluded that perhaps Needham's heating of the bottle did not kill everything inside. He constructed his own experiment by placing broth in each of two separate bottles, boiling the broth in both bottles, then sealing one bottle and leaving the other open. Days later, the unsealed bottle was teeming with small living things that he could observe more clearly with the newly invented microscope. The sealed bottle showed no signs of life. This certainly excluded spontaneous generation as a viable theory. Except, it was noted by scientists of the day that Spallanzani had deprived the closed bottle of air and it was thought that air was necessary for spontaneous generation.
An important evidence in favour of organic evolution is the occurrence of:

An important evidence in favour of organic evolution is the occurrence of homologous and vestigial organs. Homologous organs are those organs which are similar in origin but perform different function. Examples include bat's wing, cat's paw, bird's wing. All these have same origin but over the course of evolution perform different function. It favours the divergent evolution. Vestigial organs are those organs which are no longer functional but were functional in the past. It also favour the occurrence of organic evolution. Examples include wisdom teeth, appendix.
The type of natural selection where more individuals acquire a value other than the mean character value is known as:

The theory of natural selection was proposed by Charles Darwin as a mechanism of evolution.

It states that individuals who fit better in the changing environment leave more progeny, which survive better and thus get selected by nature,

Here, fitness is based on the characters that can be inherited.

Natural selection is based on some factual observations:

  • Natural resources are limited.
  • Populations are stable in size, except for seasonal fluctuations.
  • Members of a population vary in characteristics, even when they look superficially similar.
  • Most of the variations are inherited.

Darwin had stated that inheritable variations enhance resource utilization for few individuals, enabling them to reproduce better.

This leads to a change in the characteristics of the population, giving rise to new forms.
Darwin’s finches in the Galapagos Island are an example of __________.

Charles Darwin made a sea voyage around the world in a ship named H.M.S. Beagle.

When he arrived at an island called the Galapagos island, he saw some finches and observed differences in the shapes of their beaks.

He concluded that this change is due to the different eating habits of the finches thus, he gave the concept of Adaptive radiation.
In the origin of species by Darwin the concept of competition was taken from which of the following?

In the origin of species by Darwin, the concept of competition was taken from T. R Malthus. He was an English economist who proposed the famous Malthusian theory of population growth. According to this theory, a population grows exponentially while the resources to sustain that population remains linear, resulting in a calamity that reduces back the population. Darwin wrote the book 'On the Origin of Species' in which he explained the theory of evolution by natural selection as 'descent with modification'.

The Malthusian theory influenced Darwin’s theory of evolution where he stated that there exists a ‘struggle for existence’ in nature and ‘survival of the fittest’. ‘Struggle for existence’ refers to the competition for available resources required for survival.
The most accepted line of descent in human evolution is _______.
Ramapithecus → Homo habilis → Homo erectus → Homo sapiens
Australopithecines → Ramapithecus → Homo erectus → Homo habilis → Homo sapiens

The most accepted line of descent in human evolution is: Ramapithecus → Homo habilis → Homo erectus → Homo sapiens

Ramapithecus were primates that existed 15 million years ago. They were hairy and walked like present-day apes such as gorillas and chimpanzees. Ramapithecus were more man-like.

Homo habilis are the first known hominid (human-like) species that existed about 2 million years ago. They had a brain capacity of 650-800 cc. Their bones were discovered among that of Australopithecines.

Homo erectus existed around 1.5 million years ago. They had a large brain size of 900cc. They used to eat meat. Their fossils were discovered in Java in 1891. As their name suggests, they were the first hominid species to have an upright posture.

Homo sapiens existed in Africa and spread to other continents. Modern man (Homo sapiens sapiens) arose during the ice age between 75,000 - 10,000 years ago.
Of the following which classical example was used by Lamarck to prove his Theory of Acquired Characters and Inheritance?

Jean-Baptiste Lamarck was a French biologist who was one of the first to propose biological evolution.

His theory is called Lamarckism and is based on two basic principles:

  • Inheritance of acquired characters
  • Use and disuse of organs during the lifetime of an organism.

He proposed that changes in environment necessitates new needs in organism.

This leads to new uses of pre-existing features or disuse of pre-existing features, causing a physical change in the features.

He also stated that these changes were then acquired by the offspring in the next generation.
Which scientist gave the theory of mutation?

Different Theories Related to Evolution

Mutation Theory by Hugo:

  • Sudden variation in inherited characters is called Mutation.
  • The Theory of mutation was given by Hugo by his observation of plants.
  • He observed that some of the plants are different from their parent plants.
  • The causes of mutation are
  • Change in number of genes
  • Change in gene arrangement
  • Change in gene structure

Lamarck Theory

  • Jean Baptiste Lamarck's theory is also known as the Theory of acquired character.
  • With changing environmental conditions, more used organs get strengthened and less frequently used organs get disappeared.

Darwin Theory

  • Darwin gave the theory of natural selection.
  • Each species reproduces to maintain its race.
  • The species struggle for survival with changing environmental conditions.
  • The species adapts with the surroundings survives and rest extinctions.

Mendels Theory

  • Mendel used a number of contrasting visible characters of garden peas-round/wrinkled seeds, tall/short plants, white/violet flowers, and so on.
Which of the following is a neurohormone?

Neurohormone is a hormone that is produced by neurosecretory cells and released by nerve impulses (e.g., norepinephrine, oxytocin, vasopressin).

Neurohormones like vasopressin and oxytocin are synthesized by hypothalamus but secreted from posterior pituitary. Other neurohormones include adrenaline and noradrenaline secreted from adrenal medulla. These also act as neurotransmitters.
Which of the following hormones is catabolic in action?

Glucagon hormones is catabolic in action. Circulating concentrations of glucagon, a catabolic hormone that affects these metabolic pathways, are elevated during critical illness. Insight in the nutritional regulation of glucagon and its metabolic role during critical illness is lacking.

Hurthle cell cancer is a rare cancer that affects the thyroid gland. The thyroid is a butterfly-shaped gland in the base of the neck. It secretes hormones that are essential for regulating the body's metabolism. Hurthle cell cancer is also called Hurthle cell carcinoma or oxyphilic cell carcinoma.
Which of the following hormones secretes a gastric secretion?

Gastrin is a peptide hormone that stimulates the secretion of gastric acid (HCl) by the cells of the stomach.

  • It helps in gastric motility. It is secreted by the gastric glands of the stomach, duodenum, and pancreas.
  • It also stimulates the mucosal secretions in an acid-secreting part of the stomach.
  • The stimulation for the secretion of gastrin is the presence of peptides derived from dietary proteins.
It enhances the penetration of UV radiation through the skin.
Skin may vary frequently in the amount of melanin it contains.
Individuals with high concentration of melanin in their skin are at a greater risk for skin cancer.
It enhances the penetration of infrared radiation through the skin.

The skin may vary frequently in the amount of melanin it contains.

Melanosomes cover the upper part of the keratinocytes, where they prevent damage from UV light by absorbing it. In general, the more melanin there is in the skin, the more UV light that can be absorbed.
The parathyroid hormone does not regulate the concentration of ________ ions in the urine.

The parathyroid hormone does not regulate the concentration of bicarbonate ions in the urine.

The parathyroid hormone stimulates the following functions: Release of calcium by bones into the bloodstream. Absorption of calcium from food by the intestines. Conservation of calcium by the kidneys.

Match the following:

Diseases Hormones involved
a. Grave's disease 1. Aldosterone hormone
b. Addison's disease 2. Insulin hormone
c. Diabetes mellitus 3. Thyroid hormone

The correct match is: a - 3, b - 1, c - 2

  • Graves' disease is an immune system disorder that results in the overproduction of thyroid hormones (hyperthyroidism).
  • Addison's disease, also called adrenal insufficiency, is an uncommon disorder that occurs when your body doesn't produce enough of certain hormones. In Addison's disease, your adrenal glands, located just above your kidneys, produce too little cortisol and, often, too little aldosterone.
  • Diabetes mellitus (diabetes) is a chronic and potentially life-threatening condition where the body loses its ability to produce insulin, or begins to produce or use insulin less efficiently, resulting in blood glucose levels that are too high (hyperglycaemia).
What is the sequence of zones in the adrenal cortex?

The sequence of zones in the adrenal cortex: Zona glomerulosa - Zona fasciculata - Zona reticularis.

The adrenal cortex makes up a large part of your adrenal gland. It consists of three layers: zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata and zona reticularis. Each layer produces different hormones that regulate vital organ functions and bodily processes.

The sequence of zones in the adrenal cortex: Zona glomerulosa - Zona fasciculata - Zona reticularis.

The adrenal cortex makes up a large part of your adrenal gland. It consists of three layers: zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata and zona reticularis. Each layer produces different hormones that regulate vital organ functions and bodily processes
Hypertension, hyperglycemia, nervousness, sweating and complete exhaustion are the symptoms observed in:

Hypertension, hyperglycemia, nervousness, sweating and complete exhaustion are the symptoms observed in hyper-secretion of epinephrine and nor-epinephrine.

Epinephrine and norepinephrine are very similar neurotransmitters and hormones. While epinephrine has slightly more of an effect on your heart, norepinephrine has more of an effect on your blood vessels. Both play a role in your body's natural fight-or-flight response to stress and have important medical uses as well.
Which of the following hormones is known as the life saving hormone?

Aldosterone of the adrenal cortex is life-saving hormone because it serves to retain sodium and water to maintain a sufficient blood volume for circulation. So, it maintains the osmolarity and volume of ECF. The pituitary gland regulates secretion of other endocrine glands. Pineal gland secretes melatonin that regulates body’s daily rhythms. Thyroid hormones regulate the basic metabolic rate.

Hormones released into blood by diffusion.

According to the 'free hormone hypothesis', steroid hormones exert their effects after dissociating from the carrier proteins. It is thought that, because of their lipophilic nature, free steroid hormones enter target cells primarily by passive diffusion through the cell membrane.
Which of the following is a steroid hormone?

Estrogen is a steroid hormone.

In females, it helps develop and maintain both the reproductive system and female characteristics, such as breasts and pubic hair. Estrogen contributes to cognitive health, bone health, the function of the cardiovascular system, and other essential bodily processes.
What is the similarity between enzymes and hormones?
They are similar with respect to their chemical composition.
They are similar with respect to their molecular weight.
They are similar with respect to the way they participate in a reaction.
They are both effective in low concentration.

The similarity between enzymes and hormones is they are both effective in low concentration.

Hormones and Enzymes play a vital role in our body by controlling and regulating many functions. Hormones are known as chemical messengers as they trigger many functions while enzymes are catalysts as they affect the rate of a reaction.

The English physician E. H. Starling discovered in collaboration with the physiologist W. M. Bayliss secretin, the first hormone, in 1902. Three years later they introduced the hormone concept with recognition of chemical regulation, early regulatory physiology took a major step forward.
Which of the following is not a mixed/composite gland?

The pineal is not a mixed/composite gland.

  • The pineal gland was described as the “Seat of the Soul” by Renee Descartes and it is located in the center of the brain. The main function of the pineal gland is to receive information about the state of the light-dark cycle from the environment and convey this information to produce and secrete the hormone melatonin.
  • A mixed gland is a gland which has both endocrine and exocrine functions. The exocrine component has ducts, through which its secretions pass. The pancreas is a gland with both endocrine (insulin production) and exocrine (production of digestive enzymes) functions.

By chemical nature, hormones are never monosaccharide derivatives.

  • Hormones can be classified according to their chemical nature, mechanism of action, nature of action, their effects, and stimulation of Endocrine glands. i. This category of hormones are divided to six classes, they are hormones steroid; amines; peptide; protein; glycoprotein and eicosanoid.
  • Galactose sometimes abbreviated Gal, is a monosaccharide sugar.

The name glucocorticoid (glucose + cortex + steroid) is composed from its role in regulation of glucose metabolism, synthesis in the adrenal cortex, and its steroidal structure.

The principal glucocorticoid hormone is cortisol, which regulates the metabolism of proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids.
The hormone secreted by pars intermedia of hypophysis is:

Pars Intermedia of pituitary gland secretes only one hormone called Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone (MSH). This hormone causes dispersal of pigment granules in the pigment cells, thereby darkening the colour in certain animals like fishes and amphibians.
Adrenal medulla consists of a cluster of _____ nerves and those cells are also known as _____ cells:

Adrenal medulla consists of a cluster of sympathetic nerves and those cells are also known as chromaffin cells.

The adrenal medulla is part of the adrenal gland. It is located at the center of the gland, surrounded by the adrenal cortex. It is the innermost part of the adrenal gland, consisting of chromaffin cells that secrete catecholamines, including epinephrine (adrenaline), norepinephrine (noradrenaline), and a small amount of dopamine, in response to stimulation by sympathetic preganglionic neurons.

Process of parturition is facilitated by both relaxin and Oxytocin.

Parturition is the act of giving birth to the young; childbirth. Fully developed foetus and placenta send signals for parturition which in turn induces mild uterine contractions by stretching of cervix referred to as foetal ejection reflex. Stretching of cervix exerts positive feedback on the posterior pituitary to secrete oxytocin. Oxytocin exhibits both direct and indirect (via prostaglandins) effect on the uterus to facilitate uterine contractions to push the foetus downward which in turn stretches cervix more and leads to childbirth. Relaxin is secreted by corpus luteum at the end of pregnancy. It serves to relax the pelvic ligament and cervix to facilitate the birth of young one.
Thyroid is the largest endocrine gland present in human body. This gland release thyroxin hormone that help in metabolism of carbohydrates, fats and proteins.

Match the following :

HormoneNature
a) Parathormonei) Polypeptide
b) Oxytocinii) Amino acid Derivative
c) Sex hormoneiii) Peptide
d) Norepinephrineiv) Steroid

The correct match is: a)-i, b)-iii, c)-iv, d)-ii

  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is secreted by the parathyroid glands as a polypeptide containing 84 amino acids.
  • Oxytocin (Oxt or OT) is a peptide hormone and neuropeptide normally produced in the hypothalamus and released by the posterior pituitary.
  • Sex hormones, also known as sex steroids, gonadocorticoids and gonadal steroids, are steroid hormones that interact with vertebrate steroid hormone receptors.
  • Norepinephrine is synthesized in neurons starting with the amino acid tyrosine, which is obtained from the diet and can also be synthesized from phenylalanine.
Old people usually exhibit weaker immune power due to degeneration of:

Old people usually exhibit weaker immune power due to the degeneration of thymus gland.

Thymus is degenerated in old individuals resulting in a decreased production of thymosins. As a result, the immune responses of old persons become weak. Thymosin stimulates the release of T-cells that are a part of immune system.

Thyroid gland do not secrete Melatonin.

Melatonin is a hormone secreted by the enigmatic pineal gland in response to darkness, hence the name hormone of darkness. It has generated a great deal of interest as a therapeutic modality for various diseases particularly sleep disorders.
The hormone causing release of milk after the birth of young one is:

The hormone causing release of milk after the birth of young one is oxytocin. The oxytocin reflex is also sometimes called the “letdown reflex” or the “milk ejection reflex”.

The two main physical functions of oxytocin are to stimulate uterine contractions in labor and childbirth and to stimulate contractions of breast tissue to aid in lactation after childbirth.

Thermostat for the body is hypothalamus. The hypothalamus functions as a type of thermostat for the body. It sets a desired body temperature, and stimulates either heat production and retention to raise the blood temperature to a higher setting or sweating and vasodilatation to cool the blood to a lower temperature.
Hormone which acts on hypothalamus to decrease food intake, stimulate satiety and increase energy output is:

The hormone which acts on the hypothalamus to decrease food intake, stimulate satiety and increase energy output is Leptin.

Leptin is the hormone that is secreted by the Adipose cells and works on the hypothalamus to induce satiety. It is important in maintaining energy balance.

The hunger hormone or ghrelin acts antagonistically to the Leptin.

Match the following :

HormoneTarget tissue/cell
a) Follicle stimulating hormonei) liver
b) Luteinising hormoneii) kidney tubule
c) Cortisoliii)sertoli cells
d) Aldosteroneiv) interstitial cells

The correct order is: a)-iii, b)-iv, c)-i, d)-ii

  • LH stimulates Leydig cell T production, and FSH stimulates in Sertoli cells, in synergy with T, the production of regulatory molecules and nutrients needed for the maintenance of spermatogenesis.
  • Luteinizing hormone (LH), also called interstitial-cell stimulating hormone (ICSH), one of two gonadotropic hormones (i.e., hormones concerned with the regulation of the gonads, or sex glands) that is produced by the pituitary gland.
  • The presence of glucocorticoids, such as cortisol, increase the availability of blood glucose to the brain. Cortisol acts on the liver, muscle, adipose tissue, and pancreas. In the liver, high cortisol levels increase gluconeogenesis and decrease glycogen synthesis.
  • Aldosterone is a type of steroid hormone that acts primarily in renal collecting ducts to stimulate reabsorption of Na+ as well as secretion of K+ and H+.

Read the following and choose the correct option.

i. Major pineal hormone is melatonin.

ii. In human beings, melatonin secretion increases in light and decreases in dark.

iii. Abnormally high levels of melatonin in children causes delayed sexual development.

Only statements i and ii are correct.

Melatonin is a hormone secreted by the pineal gland in the brain. It helps regulate other hormones and maintains the body's circadian rhythm. Abnormally high levels of melatonin is children cause delayed sexual development.
Keratinized dead layer of skin is made of:

Keratinized dead layer of skin is made of stratified squamous epithelium.

Keratinized dead layer of skin is made of stratified squamous epithelium. It is a type of compound epithelium. Cells of this tissue are arranged in many layers (stratified). Cells forming different layers of this epithelium are not similar; deeper layers vary from cuboidal to columnar cells but they become polygonal and finally flattened (squamous) towards the free surface. The flattened cells of superficial layer contain a fibrous protein, the keratin and become dead cells (keratinized)). Horny, scale-like remains of dead squamous cells, ultimately flakes away. This epithelium is waterproof and highly resistant to mechanical injury.
The type of epithelial cell which line the inner surface of Fallopian tubes, bronchioles and bronchi are known as:

The type of epithelial cell which line the inner surface of Fallopian tubes, bronchioles and bronchi are known as ciliated epithelium.

Ciliated epithelium (columnar) is present as a lining in body structures where mucus is present and the cilia or microvilli present on the exposed surface of the epithelial cells push the mucus towards the outside example in bronchioles and bronchi to remove dust particles and pathogen. It is also present in the fallopian tube or the oviduct to push the egg or ova towards the uterus.
Which of the following is a specialised type of epithelial cells that possesses the ability to contract and line the secretory and duct portions of salivary, sweat, lacrimal and mammary glands?

Myoepithelium is a specialised type of epithelial cells that possesses the ability to contract and line the secretory and duct portions of salivary, sweat, lacrimal and mammary glands.

Myoepithelial cells (MEC) are found in the secretory units of many mammalian exocrine glands such as mammary, sweat, lacrimal and salivary glands. They are interposed between the secretory cells and the basal lamina.
Which one of the following contains the largest quantity of extracellular material?

Areolar tissue contains the largest quantity of extracellular material.

The extracellular matrix is that component of a matrix  which are secreted to provides structural and biochemical support to the surrounding cells. Areolar tissue contains the largest quantity of extracellular material like fibres and ground substances which help to provide structural support to neighbouring cells.
Which of the following cells are found in areolar tissue?

Areolar Tissue is a common form of loose connective tissue. Areolar tissue is found in many locations in the body. It consists of a meshwork of collagen, elastic tissue, and reticular fibres - with many connective tissue cells in between the meshwork of fibres. The fibres that form the mesh structure of areolar tissue include:

Collagen fibres, elastic fibres, reticular fibres

The different types of cells embedded within the areolar tissue include:

Fibroblasts, plasma cells, adipocytes, mast cells and macrophages (The histiocyte is a tissue macrophage).
Cells of air sacs of the lungs comprise __________________.

Cells of air sacs of the lungs comprise squamous epithelium.

Simple squamous epithelium lines air sac or alveoli. These squamous epithelial cells are permeable and allow the oxygen from the air to enter the blood in the capillaries of the lung,

So, the correct answer is option 'Squamous epithelium'.

Specialized connective tissues are the tendons, ligaments, bone, cartilage, blood and adipose tissue. Tendons and ligaments are used to join the muscle to the bone and bone to bone respectively. They help in providing the movements at those joints as well provide nutrients and various body fluids to those parts. Bones provide the structural framework to the body and are composed of osteocytes and osteoblasts. They secrete the components which are responsible for the formation of the bones. The cartilage consists of the chondrocytes and chondroblasts which help in the secretion of the extracellular matrix material (ECM). They help in the formation of the cartilage.
Histamines or inflammation producing substance are formed by:

A mast cell is a type of white blood cell that contains many granules rich in histamine and heparin. Specifically, it is a type of granulocyte derived from the myeloid stem cell that is a part of the immune and neuroimmune systems. Mast cells are primarily known for their role in allergy and anaphylaxis (shock). Mast cells play a key role in the inflammatory process. When activated, a mast cell can either selectively release mediators or compounds that induce inflammation, from storage granules into the local site.

So, the correct answer is 'Mast cells'.
The Wharton's jelly in umbilical cord is _______________.

The Wharton's jelly in umbilical cord is Mucoid connective tissue.

The Wharton’s jelly in the umbilical cord is a mucous or mucoid connective tissue. It originates in the extraembryonic mesoderm and is mainly composed of myoblast-like stromal cells.

So, the correct answer is 'Mucoid connective tissue.'
Cells of cartilaginous tissue are called as ______________.

Cells of cartilaginous tissue are called as mhondrocytes.

The chondrocyte is a cell that has secreted the matrix of cartilage and becomes embedded in it. The melanocyte is a mature melanin-forming cell, typically in the skin. The osteocyte is a bone cell, formed when an osteoblast becomes embedded in the matrix it has secreted. Choanocytes are cells that line the interior of asconoid, syconoid and leuconoid body type sponges that contain a central flagellum, or undulipodia, surrounded by a collar of microvilli which are connected by a thin membrane. They make up Choanoderm, a type of cell layer found in sponges.
Most of the cartilages in vertebrate embryo are replaced in adult by ___________.

Most of the cartilages in vertebrate embryo are replaced in adult by bones.

Endochondral ossification is the process by which growing cartilage is systematically replaced by bone to form the growing skeleton in vertebrate embryo.

This process occurs at three main sites: the physis, the epiphysis, and the cuboidal bones of the carpus and tarsus.

It is the mechanism responsible for the formation of all long bones of the axial skeleton (vertebrae and ribs) and the appendicular skeleton (limbs).

So, the correct option is 'Bones'.
Wall of internal organs (stomach, intestine, blood vessels) contains muscles.

Smooth muscles are unstriated muscles. The cells of smooth muscles are spindle-shaped, non-striated, involuntary and uninucleated. They are present in the walls of hollow internal organs such as stomach, intestines, urinary bladder, uterus and in the passageways such as blood vessels (arteries and veins).
Which of the following category includes blood and adipose tissues?

Option (A)

The nerve tissue is a highly specialised tissue found in all animals.

They aid in the transmission of messages from the brain to other regions of the body, as well as the other way around.

Option (B)

This is a type of tissue that aids in the movement of body parts.

They are usually linked to the bones and aid in movement.

Muscle tissue is divided into three types: skeletal, cardiac, and smooth.

Option (C)

Cells in epithelial tissues come in a variety of forms, sizes, and configurations.

They line the interior bodily organs and cavities, as well as covering the body's surface.

Option (D)

Connective tissue is a group of tissues that connects the body's various sections.

Connective tissue comes in a variety of forms.

Blood is a fluid connective tissue that delivers oxygen and collects waste from various regions of the body.

The adipose tissue is a connective tissue that contains fat cells that are important in fat storage.
Which one of the following is a sesamoid bone?

Patella is a sesamoid bone.

Sesamoid bone is a bone embedded within a tendon. Sesamoids are found in several joints in the body. For example, kneecap or patella is a sesamoid bone.
The cells lining the blood vessels belong to the category of:

The cells lining the blood vessels belong to the category of squamous epithelium.

The smooth muscle cells don't have any striations or any stripes. Hence they're referred to as smooth muscle cells. They are conjointly referred to as involuntary muscles. The cells have one nucleus and therefore the cells are spindle-shaped.

Simple squamous epithelial tissue is found wherever diffusion and filtration are needed. Cells lining our blood vessels belong to the squamous epithelial tissue. Squamous cells look like skinny, flat plates. They have horizontal planate, elliptical nuclei because they possess a skinny planate kind of cell.
Identify the tissue, matching with its characteristics and location.
Cardiac muscles, unbranched muscles, found in the walls of heart
Striated muscles tapering at both ends, attached with bones of ribs
Skeletal muscles, show striation and closely attached with bones of the limbs
Smooth muscles, show branching, found in the walls of heart

Above given picture is that of Skeletal muscle. Skeletal muscle is a form of striated muscle tissue. These are under the voluntary control of the somatic nervous system. Mostly, skeletal muscles are attached to bones by the bundles of collagen fibers known as tendons. Other options are not matching with the given image.
Which of the following statements is incorrect?
The epithelial layer regulates the movement of materials between them.
The epithelial layer does not regulate movement of materials between them.
The epithelial layer in intestine has microvilli that provides large surface area for absorption.

Epithelial cell layer covers the organs and cavities inside the body and also covers the whole body with skin. It provides a large surface area provided by microvilli. In lung alveoli, gas exchange takes place. In blood vessels, exchange of gases, minerals takes place. In kidney tubules, various salts are exchanged. For this purpose, the outer lining made by epithelial layer should be selectively permeable as per the requirement. In all these mechanisms, the composition of epithelial layer changes as per requirement as an exchange of different material demands different cellular composition. So, exchange of materials between body and external environment is regulated by epithelial layer.
Single layer of flattened calls with boundaries is observed in all of the following except.

1. Endothelium refers to cells that line the interior surface of blood vessels and lymphatic vessels, forming an interface between circulating blood or lymph in the lumen and the rest of the vessel wall. It is a thin layer of simple, or single-layered, squamous cells called endothelial cells. 

2. The esophageal lining is protected by a stratified squamous epithelium.  Because this epithelium is normally not exposed to dryness or to abrasion, it is non-keratinized.

3. The respiratory or gas-exchange surface consists of millions of small sacs, or alveoli, lined by a simple squamous epithelium. This epithelium is exceedingly thin to facilitate diffusion of oxygen and carbon-di-oxide.

So, the correct option is 'Lining of oesophagus'.
The type of epithelial cells which line the inner surface of fallopian tubes, bronchioles and uterus are known as:

The type of epithelial cells which line the inner surface of fallopian tubes, bronchioles and uterus are known as Ciliated epithelium.

Ciliated epithelium is made of simple columnar cells but possesses fine hair-like cilia on their free surfaces. 

These cells are found in the respiratory tract, from the posterior third of the nose to the bronchioles, also present in the uterus and fallopian tubes of females.

Ciliated epithelium performs the function of moving particles or fluid over the epithelial surface.
Large irregular ovoid cells found in areolar tissue are:

Large irregular ovoid cells found in areolar tissue are mast cells.

Mast cells are a kind of white blood cells which are oval or round. These have granular cytoplasm. These cells are associated with allergic reactions. A type of white blood cell that is found in connective tissues all through the body, especially under the skin, near blood vessels and lymph vessels, in nerves, and in the lungs and intestines.
In which part of angiosperms is filiform apparatus found?

Synergids show a filiform apparatus attached to their upper wall. It attracts and guides the pollen tube.

Synergid cells are two small, specialized cells in the embryo sac adjacent to the egg cells of the female gametophyte.

It nourishes the ovum and functions in guiding the pollen tube.
The flower that has only male or female reproductive parts is known as:

The flower that has only male or female reproductive parts i.e., either stamens or carpels are present are unisexual flowers.

Examples of unisexual flowers are Bitter gourd, papaya, pumpkin, and cucumber.
Female germ cells are situated in the:

Female germ cell is located in the ovary of the pistil [female part of the plant].

Ovary, in botany, is an enlarged basal portion of the pistil, the female organ of a flower. The ovary contains ovules, which develop into seeds upon fertilization. The ovary itself will mature into a fruit, either dry or fleshy, enclosing the seeds.
Pollen tube grows from the _____ and reaches till __________.

The pollen tube grows through a stylar canal or a stylar transmitting tissue, and reaches the locule cavity of the ovary where the ovule is located.

In most angiosperms, from pollen landing on the stigma to fertilization inside the ovary, the pollen tube has to traverse an intermediate territory, the style.
During germination, a seedling develops from a/an:
The process by which the seed develops into the seedling is called germination. During this process, the embryo gets developed into a seedling. This seedling gradually grows into a new plant.

Arrange the following in the correct sequence for sexual reproduction in a plant.

P - Discharge of male gamete

Q - Germination of pollen to form pollen tube

R - Pollination

S - Fertilisation

The steps of sexual reproduction in plants are:-

Pollination-  the pollen grains are carried by wind, water or insects and animals to reach the stigma of the flower. This process of transfer of pollen grains is called pollination.

Germination-  the pollen tubes begins to grow towards the egg cell. These tubes are a pathway for the sperms or male gamete to reach the egg within the ovule.

Discharge of male gamete: The pollen tubes reach the ovule where it penetrates the ovule to reach the female gamete or egg.

Fertilization- the male gamete travel down the pollen tubes and fertilize an egg. In angiosperms, double fertilization takes place where both egg and the polar nuclei in the embryo sac are fertilized by the male gametes.
Which of the following is present in the centre of a flower?
Carpels, present in the centre of a flower, form the female reproductive part. It is surrounded by male reproductive structures called stamens. The carpels and stamens are surrounded by petals.

Which of the following statements is/are false?

a. Flowers that contain only one sex organ are called unisexual flowers. 

b. A new seed of a plant is formed when the male gamete present in a pollen grain unites with a female gamete present in the ovule. 

c. Each ovule contains many female gametes of a plant.

'Each ovule contains many female gametes of a plant' is a false statement.

The flowers which contain only the male or female reproductive organs are called unisexual flowers. They are called incomplete flowers. To reproduce, they undergo cross-pollination. They do not have both stamen and carpels.

When the pollen tube reaches the ovule, it pushes the male gametes into the egg cell. Here, the fusion of the male and the female gamete occurs. This is called fertilisation.

Which of the following statements are INCORRECT?

1. Geitonogamy is the pollination of a flower by the pollen from another flower of the same plant.

2. Interfascicular cambium is developed from the cells of medullary ray.

3. Age of a tree can be estimated by diameter of its bark.

4. Lenticels are involved in transpiration.

Statement 3 is incorrect.

Age of tree can be estimated by number of annual rings. 

Geitonogamy involves the transfer of pollen grains by a pollinator, from the anther of one flower to the stigma of another flower of the same plant.

Interfascicular Cambium is a cambium found in between vascular bundles. It forms the secondary meristems. The interfascicular and fascicular cambium unite forming a continuous ring of meristematic tissue known as vascular cambium.

Lenticels are the small pores that occur on woody branches of trees. Lenticels participate in gaseous exchange and transpiration.

Which of the following statements are FALSE?

1. Double fertilisation is a characteristic of gymnosperms.

2. Scattered vascular bundles are a characteristic feature of dicot stems.

3. Pollination by snails is called malachophily.

4. Apogamy is the formation of sporophyte directly from the gametophyte without gamete formation.

Statements 1 and 2 are false.

Double fertilization is a major characteristic of flowering plants (angiosperms).

In monocot stems, the vascular bundles are scattered throughout the ground tissue. Like monocot roots, monocot stems are protected by an outer layer of dermal tissue called the epidermis.
The condition in which stamens are fused by their anthers and the filaments are free is called:

The condition in which stamens are fused by their anthers and the filaments are free is called Syngenesious.

The syngenesious or synantherous condition of androecium is a feature of the family Asteraceae wherein, the anthers of the filaments are fused to form the tubular mass or group and their filaments remain free.

Hovering birds are the hummingbirds that are the most common flower-visiting birds and are attracted to bright colored flowers that produce nectar. These birds have a long beak and they do not sit on the flower, they hover over it. The flowers of such plants hang (are pendent) so that birds can hover over it and insert the beak in the flower. This type of pollination by means of birds is called ornithophily. The example which is pollinated by hummingbirds is Bignonia.

Superior ovary is found in hypogynous flowers.

In hypogynous flowers, the perianth and stamens are attached to the receptacle below the gynoecium; the ovary is superior to these organs, and the remaining floral organs arise from below the point of origin of the carpel.
Fertilisation of egg by two male gametes
Fertilisation of two eggs in the same embryo sac by two sperms brought by one pollen tube
Fertilisation of the egg and central cell by two sperms brought by different pollen tubes
Fertilisation of the egg and the central cell by two sperms brought by the same pollen tube

Double fertilization is a fertilization method in which there is fusion of female gametophyte with two male gametes. It is seen in angiosperms. It involves fertilization of the egg and the central cell by two sperms brought by the same pollen tube. Fusion of haploid egg and haploid sperm results in the formation of diploid zygote. Fusion of two polar nuclei with haploid sperm result in the formation of triploid endopserm nucleus.

The fruit in jack fruit develops from a spadix inflorescence and thus is called sorosis.

Synconus also develops from an inflorescence but the type of inflorescence is hypanthodium.

Pome and amphisarca are simple succulent fruits that develop from a single flower.
The Gynoecium of flower having two or more carpel fuse together are called:
Gynoecium is the female reproductive part of flower. It consists of single or more than two carpel( pistil). When these carpels are fused together, they are called syncarpous.
Which of the following plants contain unisexual flower?

Papaya plant produce either male or female flower in separate plants. 

The flower which contains either male or female reproductive part is called unisexual flower.
The flower which possesses both androecium and gynoecium is called:

A hermaphrodite is an individual that produces functional male gametes and female gametes (sex cells) during its lifetime.

Examples- tunicates, few snails, earthworms etc
In some plants anther and stigma mature at same time. This condition is called:

Homogamy – In this case the anther and stigmas of a bisexual flower mature simultaneously. The pollen grains reach the mature stigma either by contact, wind, gravity, rain drop or even insects. Self pollination brought about by contact is called direct autogamy and remaining agencies perform indirect autogamy.
Sexual reproduction in flowering plants centres around the flower. Within a flower, there are usually structures that produce both male gametes and female gametes

Match the column-I and column-II

Column - I Column - II
(i) Viroid
 (a) Ramachandran
(ii) Cell
 (b) Leewenhoek
(iii) Virus
 (c) T.O. Diener
(iv) Triple helical structure of collagen
 (d) Ivanowsky
i - b, ii - a, iii - c, iv - d
i - a, ii - b, iii - d, iv - c
i - c, ii - b, iii - d, iv - a
i - d, ii - b, iii - c, iv - a

(i) Viroid - (c) T.O. Diener -Viroids are the smallest infectious pathogens known. They are composed solely of a short strand of circular, single-stranded RNA that has no protein coating. The term Viroid was introduced by T.O.Diener.

(ii) Cell - (b) Leeuwenhoek -Leeuwenhoek (1674), with the improved microscope, discovered the free-living cells in pond water for the first time. 

(iii) Virus - (d) Ivanowsky   - Dmitri Ivanovsky, in studying a disease that affects tobacco plants, paved the way for the discovery of the infectious particle known as a virus. A virus is a small infectious agent that replicates only inside the living cells of an organism.

(iv) The triple helical structure of collagen - (a) Ramachandran -collagen is the most abundant protein in your body. It is the major component of connective tissues that make up several body parts, including tendons, ligaments, skin, and muscles. Prof.Ramachandran proposed the  Triple helical structure of collagen.
The walls of diatoms are easily destructible
'Diatomaceous earth' is formed by the cell walls of diatoms
Diatoms are chief producers in the oceans
Diatoms are microscopic and float passively in water

The walls of diatoms are easily destructible the wrong statement:

Diatoms are a type of protists that are categorized under the group called Chrysophytes. These organisms are microscopic and float passively in water currents. These are chief producers in the ocean as they are found in the large amount and are photosynthetic in nature. Their cell wall is made up of silica and thus it is not destructible. When diatoms die, they left their cell wall in their habitat which accumulates over billions of years over the earth surface and is called 'Diatomaceous Earth' which is used in polishing or filtration of oils.
Which of the following is not an edible variety of mushroom?

Amanita phalloides is not an edible variety of mushroom.

Amanita phalloides is sometimes confused with its member Amanita caesarea, which is an edible mushroom, but both appear to look the same. Thus, appropriate knowledge about the mushrooms is necessary to identify between the edible and the non-edible species.

Zygospore is formed from Gametangial copulation.

Gametangia are the sex organs of fungi. The male and female gametangia are born on two different fungal hyphae. The two gametangia from different sex unite together and form a fertilization tube through which the male gamete migrates into the female gametangium. This process of fusion of gametes in fungi is known as Gametangial copulation.

When the two gametes of the opposite sex come together it is known as a gametic union. A zygote is formed by the fusion of male and female gametes. oogamy is a form of sexual reproduction. It is a form of anisogamy (heterogamy) in which the female gamete (e.g. egg cell) is significantly larger than the male gamete and is non-motile.

Aflatoxin is produced by Aspergillus flavus.

Aflatoxins are naturally occurring mycotoxins, that are produced by Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus, species of fungi. Aflatoxins are toxic and among the most carcinogenic substances known.

Slime mould one is a saprophytic protist.

Saprophytic protists are organisms that release enzymes into the surrounding which convert organic matter into a simpler form that will be absorbed by the body surface of the organism. slime moulds are saprophytic protists. desmids are green algae, Nostoc is a cyanobacterium and Gonyaulax is a dinoflagellate in which nutrition is photosynthetic.
T.O Diener (1971) discovered a new infectious agent that was smaller than viruses. It was:

T.O Diener (1971) discovered a new infectious agent that was smaller than viruses. It was viroids.

T.O Diener (1971) discovered a new infectious agent that was smaller than viruses. It was viroid. The viroid caused potato spindle tuber disease. It lacked the protein coat around the genetic material RNA.

Read the following statements regarding archaebacteria.

I. Their cell wall lacks peptidoglycan.

II. They contain membrane bound organelles.

III. These have distinct ribosomal RNA sequence.

IV. Lipid in cell membrane of archaebacteria have different structure than those in all other organisms.

Choose the incorrect option.

Archaebacteria are the prokaryotic organisms. These organisms contain the cell membrane which is made up of the amino acids and glycolipids which are linked by an ether linkage. There is no peptidoglycan as in the bacterial cell wall. They are prokaryotes which do not have membrane-bound organelles. They have 16S rRNA genes which are genetically different from the other organisms. The lipids in archaebacteria form an S-layer with the amino acids and glycolipids.
In the light of recent classification of living organisms into three domains of life (bacteria, archaea and eukarya), which one of the following statement is true about archaea?
Archaea completely differ from both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.
Archaea have some novel features that are absent in other prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

The archaebacteria are placed in a different kingdom from the plants and animals. The archaebacteria are the organisms that have certain properties which are not common to the organisms placed in bacteria and eukarya. The group contains methanogens that can produce methane gas. The DNA of these organisms is generally present in a relaxed state or as positively coiled. The cell wall of these organisms does not contain lipids, peptidoglycan, etc.
Which of the following is the correct sequence of three steps in the sexual cycle of fungi?

The sexual cycle of fungi involves the following three steps:

1. The protoplasm of two motile or non-motile gametes fuses by the process of plasmogamy. It is fusion of two haploid cells without nuclear fusion.

2. Karyogamy involves fusion of nuclei of the two gametes.

3. Meiosis in zygote results in haploid spores.

Chitinous cell wall is present in Fungi.

Fungi are eukaryotes that lack chlorophyll and are heterotrophic. The body structure of fungi is unique. It is composed of branched and filamentous hyphae, which form a net-like structure known as mycelium. The hyphae have a thin, rigid wall made up chiefly of chitin, a nitrogen-containing polysaccharide.

Read the following statements regarding euglenoids and select the incorrect ones.

(i) These are mostly freshwater organisms found in stagnant water.

(ii) Their body is covered by a protein rich layer called pellicle which makes their body flexible.

(iii) They are photosynthetic in the presence of sunlight but become heterotrophs in the absence of sunlight.

(iv) They usually possess two flagella, one long and one short.

(v) Euglenoids are multicellular ciliate protists.

Protozoan, life form, generally single-celled and heterotrophic (utilizing natural carbon as a wellspring of vitality), having a place with any of the real ancestries of protists and, as most protists, ordinarily minuscule. All protozoans are eukaryotes and in this manner have a "genuine," or layer bound, core.
Which statement is true about domain archaea?
They differ from both prokaryotes and eukaryotes
They have some novel features absent in other prokaryotes and eukaryotes

Domains Archaea contains single-celled microorganisms. These are prokaryotes. They do not have a true nucleus or membrane-bound organelles. They lack peptidoglycan in the cell wall. However, they have some novel features absent in other prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Instead of ester bonds like in prokaryotes and eukaryotes, they have ether bonds connecting fatty acids to molecules of glycerol.

Lichens are the associations of Fungus and algae.

Lichens are association (mutually beneficial) between fungus and alga. The fungal partner is mycobiont and algal partner is phycobion. The mycobiont is usually an ascomycete and phycobiont is usually green algae Lichens can grow in extremely inhospitable conditions In many ecosystems they are the pioneer species. The role of mycobiont is providing body structure and anchorage and absorption of minerals and water. The role of phycobiont is mainly in providing food through photosynthesis.

Kingdom Monera is divided into Archaebacteria and Eubacteria.

R. H. Whittaker proposed the five-kingdom classification including monera, protists, fungi, plants and animals. woese divided the kingdom Monera into two groups: - Archaebacteria and Eubacteria. these organisms are unicellular prokaryotes that do not have well-developed cell organelles such as the nucleus, mitochondria, chloroplast, etc.

In which of the following ways do substances move over small distances in plants?

A. Diffusion

B. Cytoplasmic streaming

C. Translocation

Over small distances substances move by diffusion and by cytoplasmic streaming supplemented by active transport.

Water and minerals are taken up by roots and leaves prepare the food. These are then transported to the other parts of the plants. Diffusion is the main pathway of transportation in plants.

Cytoplasmic streaming, also called protoplasmic streaming, is the movement of the fluid substance (cytoplasm) within a plant or animal cell.

Which of the following statements is/are false?

A. In rooted plants, the transport in xylem is multidirectional.

B. Special proteins help moving substances across membranes without expenditure of ATP energy in facilitated diffusion.

C. In active as well as passive transport, a major role is played by different proteins in the membrane.

False Statement - In rooted plants, the transport in xylem is multidirectional.

In rooted plants, transport in xylem of water and minerals is essentially unidirectional from roots to the stems.
